[John Falco]: Councilor Felder.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: After this resolution tonight, I received a number of calls from residents on Harvard Street regarding a change that they recently made

[John Falco]: at the intersection of Harvard and Mystic Ave.

[John Falco]: And what's happening is a lot of the cars are backing up and the queues going all the way down Harvard Street.

[John Falco]: It's virtually impossible to get out of your driveway.

[John Falco]: There's been some, from what I'm hearing, numerous near accidents.

[John Falco]: And I'm just asking that the traffic engineer just take a look at this and

[John Falco]: and actually contact the neighbors as well to get their input.

[John Falco]: I'm not sure how much input was gathered from the residents before they made this change, but it's a change that has impacted the neighborhood.

[John Falco]: And I just wanted to bring that forward.

[John Falco]: And I ask that this be moved to the traffic engineer for further review and move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I received a call from a resident on Wildwood Road regarding, back a few years ago, there was some major type of pipe repair.

[John Falco]: I believe it was,

[John Falco]: with the street.

[John Falco]: And what they did is they actually stored, they used actually wildwood as a staging area where they stored the pipes before they installed them and over time, I guess they were there for a while, over time what they did is they left kind of like a depression in the road, it's not like a pothole, but the road slopes off.

[John Falco]: in front of 31 Wildwood.

[John Falco]: So when it rains now, there's a significant say puddle that runs pretty much the length of 31 Wildwood road.

[John Falco]: I was going through some documents with regard to the Encore agreement.

[John Falco]: And we have the surrounding community agreement with Encore.

[John Falco]: That's been in place for many years now.

[John Falco]: And back in 2019 at the Mayor Burke, there was a committee that was set up.

[John Falco]: And the committee was basically the Metric Community Fund.

[John Falco]: And what it did is the casino gives $125,000 a year as part of the agreement.

[John Falco]: And it's in section five, the Medford Community Fund.

[John Falco]: The parties recognize the importance of supporting the Medford community and share a mutual desire to utilize this agreement to provide ongoing support to the many important nonprofit organizations throughout the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: It goes on to in section 5.2a, an annual payment of $125,000 is made from Encore each year to the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Back in 2019, Mayor Berk had set up a committee that put it, and that committee put a process in place where they were called AIM grants, A-I-M, AIM grants.

[John Falco]: I believe it was All In for Medford, All In Medford.

[John Falco]: And those two nonprofits could apply for those grants, the grants were given out, and we would give out the whole $125,000.

[John Falco]: And there was some really, some great nonprofits that received money.

[John Falco]: There's a list of them, Mystic Valley Elder Services, Community Cupboard Food Pantries, Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility, Friends of Medford Rowing, Veterans Preservation Project, Medford Education Foundation, Mystic River Watershed, Cache, Trees Medford, West Medford Open Studios, Friends of the Medford Family Network, Medford Farmers Market, and the list goes on.

[John Falco]: My point is this.

[John Falco]: That committee has not met in two years and the city has received $125,000 each year.

[John Falco]: So that means that there's $250,000 that has come in and no process has been, as far as I know, that committee has not met to disperse those funds or to even get that process going where nonprofits can apply for funds.

[John Falco]: So my question to the administration is what is the plan?

[John Falco]: What is the plan for this committee to meet

[John Falco]: and get the ball rolling with regard to giving out this $250,000 that has come in from Encore Casino within the past two years.

[John Falco]: There are plenty of nonprofits throughout our community that could use this money.

[John Falco]: $250,000 can go a long way in the nonprofit community.

[John Falco]: And there are plenty of nonprofits throughout our city.

[John Falco]: This needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: As far as I can tell this, I mean, they haven't met in two years.

[John Falco]: So what's the plan to me?

[John Falco]: This money needs to be, like I said, plenty of nonprofits can use this money.

[John Falco]: There's $250,000 that could go out.

[John Falco]: It's here, it's with the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: It's part of the Encore Casino Agreement.

[John Falco]: My question is to the administration, what is the plan?

[John Falco]: When is this going to begin?

[John Falco]: This committee met last under Mayor Burke.

[John Falco]: I don't think it has met once under this administration.

[John Falco]: So my question is, what is it going to be?

[John Falco]: This is valuable.

[John Falco]: We recently received word that the administration has hired someone to run the parking program, which is great news, but I would like to know, we should, I'd like to receive an update from the administration as to what is the timing of the transition process?

[John Falco]: Is it moving on time?

[John Falco]: You know, is it, when you think about it, there's only, I think about maybe 72 days or around that period of time before the end of the year.

[John Falco]: This needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: When I talked to someone at the parking company, I believe they said it was going to be, it takes a while to transition this process.

[John Falco]: It's not an easy process.

[John Falco]: It's not like you flip a switch and all of a sudden everything transitions over to the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: The administration just hired someone, which is definitely good news, but there is a lot of work that needs to be done.

[John Falco]: We need to receive an update from the administration as to whether or not this is going to be completed on time.

[John Falco]: At 1231, is this city going to be ready to take on a parking program?

[John Falco]: The city's never run a parking program before.

[John Falco]: So I have concerns there.

[John Falco]: I just want to make sure that those concerns are addressed.

[John Falco]: I'm sure my colleagues have concerns as well.

[John Falco]: And I'd also like to specifically know if the

[John Falco]: Administration has reached out to Republic Parking for an extension.

[John Falco]: Someone had told me that the other day, that that's what they had heard.

[John Falco]: I'm not sure if that's true, but they had heard that from someone within the Park Method office.

[John Falco]: So I just want clarification on that as well.

[John Falco]: The administration said they were taking it in-house, but it sounds like maybe they're not taking it in right away.

[John Falco]: So if we can get an answer to that question, I greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much.

[John Falco]: That's fine with me.

[John Falco]: And if I may amend further,

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: And in that intersection of Cotting, West, North, and Auburn, there are a number of issues going on there with

[John Falco]: people coming down Cotting Street the wrong way, speeding, the lack of crosswalks in the area.

[John Falco]: So there are a number of issues.

[John Falco]: I've also received it and I believe everybody on this council has received an email as well that I'll read.

[John Falco]: just now so everybody can hear about the issues.

[John Falco]: This here is from people that live in the neighborhood.

[John Falco]: So dear city council members, I am writing with the support of 28 neighbors to respectfully ask that the resolution 21-543 that Councilor Falco added to the agenda tonight.

[John Falco]: regarding a traffic study at the intersection of Auburn, West, North, and Cotting Streets be approved and moved forward rapidly.

[John Falco]: Ideally also for the bridge just up the street where Mystic Valley Parkway crosses the river and intersects with Auburn.

[John Falco]: Because of the way Cotting, North, West, and Auburn intersect, it is often impossible for drivers coming up one street to have a clear view of the oncoming cars from other directions.

[John Falco]: Most cars do not come to a full stop at the stop signs, but even if one does, one's view is frequently blocked by either a parked car or just the angle at which the roads intersect.

[John Falco]: An example is turning left onto North Street from Cotting.

[John Falco]: It is not a simple four-way stop with two perpendicular streets and requires additional support to be made safe.

[John Falco]: No speed bumps are in place to force people to slow down or discourage driving up one-way streets the wrong way.

[John Falco]: There are not sufficient curb cuts for strollers and wheelchairs, and most importantly, there is no kind of crosswalk in any direction.

[John Falco]: Cars frequently drive up both Cotting and West the wrong way, despite the signage.

[John Falco]: This person refers to when her husband in her

[John Falco]: and politely stopped, asked drivers to turn around, that this is dangerous for many of the kids that ride bikes and scooters in the neighborhood, that they're going down the wrong way, they get yelled obscenities, and there's a lot of unfortunate back and forth between the neighbors or the people that are just driving down the wrong way.

[John Falco]: Parents with kids often discuss how dangerous the street is when we meet at Cummings Park.

[John Falco]: Crossing these streets with my two children in a stroller feels incredibly dangerous.

[John Falco]: One has to be hypervigilant, constantly looking in multiple directions to make sure a car can see us and won't zoom across and hit us.

[John Falco]: The bridge where Mystic Valley Parkway crosses the Mystic River is equally concerning.

[John Falco]: Currently, there is debris from a recent accident scattered across the pedestrians' sidewalk.

[John Falco]: And once again, the guide rail has been severely damaged in a crash.

[John Falco]: It seems like these crashes occur every few weeks, making

[John Falco]: making me wonder what factors are making that turn especially dangerous.

[John Falco]: Lighting, speed, something else, and how can they be addressed?

[John Falco]: Aside from the risks to pedestrians and drivers, these crashes must be costing the city significantly in repairs every time the guide rail gets fixed and a crew must come out to ideally clean up.

[John Falco]: I'm including here multiple concerned neighbors who live in the area and cross these intersections frequently.

[John Falco]: As we are hopeful, a comprehensive plan can be taken up.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your help and attention to this matter.

[John Falco]: Gratefully, Sophie Ricks, and she lives on Cotting Street, so she's experiencing this on a daily basis.

[John Falco]: And then there's also a list of 25 neighbors on the surrounding streets, Cotting,

[John Falco]: Auburn, Northwest, Winter Street, Martin Street.

[John Falco]: So there's a lot of neighbors here that are concerned about this.

[John Falco]: This has become a very dangerous area to get around as a pedestrian, as a cyclist, and as a motorist.

[John Falco]: So what I'm recommending is that we, I believe it worked last time and I think it can work again, and that is actually an onsite committee, the whole meeting.

[John Falco]: We did that back last year.

[John Falco]: I think it was very successful.

[John Falco]: I mean, as Councilors, we actually all went to the site.

[John Falco]: We were there with the traffic engineer.

[John Falco]: We talked about the various issues with the neighbors.

[John Falco]: They're there every day.

[John Falco]: They experience this every day, and these are major quality of life issues that need to be addressed.

[John Falco]: So I would ask, Mr. President, if you could set up a committee of the whole sooner than later.

[John Falco]: On-site.

[John Falco]: On-site committee of the whole meeting.

[John Falco]: That works for me.

[John Falco]: I think that, I feel like when we did that last time, we really addressed, we addressed a multitude of issues in the neighborhood that we went to.

[John Falco]: I feel like, you know, we worked together really well on that with the traffic engineer.

[John Falco]: And I think we can do the same thing down here.

[John Falco]: Get everybody on the same page.

[John Falco]: If we could have it at the intersection of Auburn, North Cotting and West, that would be ideal.

[John Falco]: There's many, there are many issues that need to be addressed.

[John Falco]: And I know there was a neighbor that would like to speak as well.

[John Falco]: So I'd love to, we'd love to hear from you.

[John Falco]: And this resolution is related to the last resolution.

[John Falco]: As we all know, Alicia Dudley Benjamin recently left this position.

[John Falco]: And my question basically is to the administration, what is the plan moving forward for this role?

[John Falco]: Alicia held the role of financial director, CFO, auditor, and I know she also helped out with a number of treasury functions as well.

[John Falco]: And I believe, you know,

[John Falco]: it's these are vital, vital, you know, roles to the daily operations of our city.

[John Falco]: And, you know, I think it's our fiduciary responsibility to be asking the questions as to what is the plan moving forward for the administration?

[John Falco]: Is this going, are they going to hire for this role?

[John Falco]: We're full time personally looking, is it going to be on a temporary basis, but we need to have this information.

[John Falco]: I think it's our responsibility to ask these questions.

[John Falco]: And I know that the assistant that was recently hired just this year is still in training or was in training, just trying to come up to speed when Alicia left.

[John Falco]: And I know he's doing a good job, but we need to know what's the plan moving forward.

[John Falco]: And so the question is basically to the administration, what's the plan?

[John Falco]: Like I said, these are vital roles.

[John Falco]: This position needs to be addressed ASAP.

[John Falco]: It's $190 million budget, $191 million budget, and we need answers to these questions.

[John Falco]: So I ask for my colleague's support and move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Now more than ever, we must think,

[John Falco]: have increased awareness about the dynamics of power and vigorously pursue ways to create inclusive and competent work environments.

[John Falco]: Although personnel issues are not in the purview of the Medford City Council, we have the responsibility to the employees and to the citizens of Medford to maintain a community of equity and inclusion and to advocate for full transparency.

[John Falco]: In the instances described, Mayor Lungo-Koehn and a leadership team have failed Medford and I will not stand by and allow our talented city staff to be tarnished or degraded.

[John Falco]: Every single city council have voted to take an independent and impartial investigation into this matter, requested appropriations from the mayor to do so.

[John Falco]: In a public document from Mayor Lungo-Koehn to the president of the city council dated June 28th, 2021, the mayor denied this request because

[John Falco]: It, and I quote, is nothing more than a political ploy.

[John Falco]: For the mayor of the state, the council's request to seek an independent investigation regarding this matter is a political ploy, is an absolute insult, not only to the members of this council, but to the two employees making these allegations.

[John Falco]: The statement by the mayor downplays the seriousness

[John Falco]: of these allegations dismisses the integrity and reputation of the employee.

[John Falco]: It calls into question mayor's integrity and motivation in investigating these matters.

[John Falco]: During the council's emergency meeting on June 23rd, city solicitor Kim Scanlon was asked to describe the process of how the third party investigator was selected.

[John Falco]: City solicitor Scanlon stated, and I quote, made a recommendation and listed down

[John Falco]: to two candidates, and earlier today, the mayor agreed to the first candidate.

[John Falco]: This is in complete and total contrast to what the mayor stated in the June 28th letter to President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: In that letter, the mayor stated the following, I did not participate in the selection of the third party then or now.

[John Falco]: A statement released to the Medford transcript by the city on June 24th, the mayor directed the city solicitor to engage the services of an independent third party selected by the city solicitor.

[John Falco]: And you wonder why the council sought to hire an outside counsel and an investigator.

[John Falco]: For the mayor to deny the council's request for funds is simply outrageous.

[John Falco]: The resolution tonight is basically to get more information

[John Falco]: with regard to the private investigator that was hired by the administration on or before June 23rd, 2021.

[John Falco]: The bullets points state exactly what I'm looking for.

[John Falco]: That's a copy of the signed contract for the investigatory services, a description of the procurement process used for this contract, a detail of funding source, line item and scope of services to be provided

[John Falco]: and a copy of the city ordinance the city solicitor is relying on as a basis for the procurement and hiring by the administration for this contract.

[John Falco]: You know, if it's something that we think we need an attorney for, and maybe if you didn't agree with it, you'd say no.

[John Falco]: That's the way I feel about it.

[John Falco]: Mr. President, can I ask one last question?

[John Falco]: As far as the, so as far as the setup for the

[John Falco]: Diversity and Inclusion Office and the Human Resources.

[John Falco]: Madam Mayor, could you or Alicia just explain the set up.

[John Falco]: So we have the new role of, I just wanna make sure I have this straight, because then I'll be asked.

[John Falco]: So you have the new.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I had the honor to play football for Bud Kelly

[John Falco]: from 1985, 1986, and 1987.

[John Falco]: And I remember as a sophomore coming to Medford High School and being on the varsity team, it was quite intimidating.

[John Falco]: You had a lot of juniors and seniors that played.

[John Falco]: It was a great team in 1985.

[John Falco]: He was the head coach.

[John Falco]: But coming in as a sophomore, everyone at this council was really hit upon it.

[John Falco]: It was family.

[John Falco]: You came in, it didn't matter where you came from.

[John Falco]: It didn't matter who you were, you were family.

[John Falco]: And he preached that repeatedly.

[John Falco]: And it was about, you know, family, loyalty, being together, having fun, but also being serious too.

[John Falco]: When he had to be tough, he was tough, but he was fair.

[John Falco]: He was fair with everyone.

[John Falco]: It was probably one of the,

[John Falco]: You think about, you know, you play sports, you're part of clubs or groups.

[John Falco]: And it was probably one of the most fun moments of my life, you know, young life growing up, being 15 years old and being part of that.

[John Falco]: And, uh, you know, he was the last coach to win a GBL title in football.

[John Falco]: It's been quite some time.

[John Falco]: It's been, uh, almost 30 years now, actually more than 30 years.

[John Falco]: Uh, but he was, uh, he was, you know, I remember seeing him after graduating and going to high school games, you'd see him as the AD then.

[John Falco]: And, uh,

[John Falco]: He was just a great guy, always a good friend, and someone who could really make you laugh.

[John Falco]: And, you know, he was a great family man.

[John Falco]: I remember those games in 1985.

[John Falco]: After we won, we'd always drive through Medford Square, pull up on the bus, and I think his wife worked at the dress shop right behind City Hall.

[John Falco]: And he'd stop the bus after every win, and everybody would be singing the Mustang Spice Song, and traffic would come to a stop.

[John Falco]: And literally he'd get out of the bus, he'd run across the street, his wife would come out and everybody that worked at the shop and he'd give his wife a kiss.

[John Falco]: And then he'd come back onto the bus and we'd make our way to the high school.

[John Falco]: And, uh, you know, it was just a really fun way to celebrate a victory.

[John Falco]: He was a great family man.

[John Falco]: And, uh, there was a lot of pride there in blue and white.

[John Falco]: If you play Mustang football, blue and white was running through your veins.

[John Falco]: If you played any sport, blue and white was running through your veins and he would preach that repeatedly.

[John Falco]: And, you know, the community is, this is a big loss to the community.

[John Falco]: And my, you know, thoughts and prayers and condolences go to the Kelly, to Judy Kelly and the family.

[John Falco]: And he will, he will be missed.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: you know, and thank you to, you know, thank you for Council Vice President Knight for bringing the resolution tonight.

[John Falco]: Thank you Post 45.

[John Falco]: And it's important that those 8,700 veterans are remembered.

[John Falco]: And I had the opportunity to, I was actually with Vice President Knight and we did, you know, put the flags down at the cemetery.

[John Falco]: And it's quite humbling as you walk, you know, among the graves and you're putting them in the ground and it's, you know, literally you have bags and bags of flags, you know,

[John Falco]: you know, that represent, you know, the many residents that, you know, volunteer, you know, that were in the Army and Navy, Air Force, Marines, and you name it.

[John Falco]: And in many of them, you know, making that ultimate sacrifice.

[John Falco]: And when you see that, and you see that the graves and you're walking, you know, row by row, it's, it's amazing that the dedication and commitment to our, to our country into, you know, many of the freedoms that we enjoy today, we have because of that.

[John Falco]: And you think about the 77th anniversary of D-Day.

[John Falco]: And I had the opportunity about 20 years ago to visit the D-Day beaches in France.

[John Falco]: And you walk down the beach and you turn and you see the cliffs in front of you.

[John Falco]: And you try, I mean, you can't even imagine that people walking into that and all that fire coming off, you know, all the, you know, you know, just,

[John Falco]: the fire from the machine guns and whatnot coming.

[John Falco]: I mean, they were just walking into pure hell.

[John Falco]: And you think about the sacrifice and the commitment that they made.

[John Falco]: And it's amazing.

[John Falco]: It's just, I mean, to be there and to see it firsthand, I mean, you see it in the movies, you see it on TV and the different documentaries, but to see it, you hit on the head, the greatest generation.

[John Falco]: I mean, to make that sacrifice,

[John Falco]: It's just amazing.

[John Falco]: And, you know, it is truly the greatest generation.

[John Falco]: They should be remembered.

[John Falco]: They'll always be remembered.

[John Falco]: And you can never thank them enough.

[John Falco]: And I think, in the end, if you know a World War II veteran, if there's someone in your neighborhood, it's important, I think, that you really talk to them and hear it firsthand, if you can, because the sacrifices that were made, you know, you don't see a lot of that today.

[John Falco]: And it's really a special generation that will, you know, I think always have a special place, you know, in our country.

[John Falco]: So I thank you so much for all your time and your effort that you put in day in and day out.

[John Falco]: I know you don't have an easy job.

[John Falco]: It is very busy.

[John Falco]: During my past four visits to get gas for my car, I've looked at the seal on the gas pump.

[John Falco]: It indicates the date when the pump was last inspected by the city's sealer of weights and measures.

[John Falco]: Frankly, I've been shocked by how long it has been since these pumps were looked at by the city sealer of weights and measures.

[John Falco]: In some cases, it has been as long as three, four years.

[John Falco]: For people who don't know, the City Stealer of Weights and Measures is the city employee appointed by the mayor who checks the accuracy of pumps at the gas station, scales at food stores, in the deli or produce departments, or anything that a merchant uses to measure goods that are being sold to the public.

[John Falco]: If these pumps or scales are not accurate, the customer will pay more for the gas that they buy for their car or the fruit or cold cuts that they buy for their family.

[John Falco]: Pumps and scales that have been unchecked or not properly calibrated by the city ends up with people paying more than they should pay.

[John Falco]: And what is worse, they will never know it.

[John Falco]: Anytime this happens, it is obviously unfair.

[John Falco]: But if it happens because the city has not done its job, it shows a callous disregard for a hardworking residents.

[John Falco]: So Mr. President, in addition to the requesting a full list for entities that zero

[John Falco]: In addition to requesting a full list for entities that sealer of weights and measures monitors in the date of last inspection and expiration of seal.

[John Falco]: I also ask that the mayor advise this council who the sealer of weights and measures is, and when he or she began in that position.

[John Falco]: This is something that, you know, even with COVID could have been done.

[John Falco]: And as far as I can tell, and I've traveled to numerous gas stations throughout the city,

[John Falco]: just to do my own research, I went to probably six to eight gas stations and they're all expired.

[John Falco]: This needs to be looked at.

[John Falco]: And I also believe that this is a revenue source for the city that they're not taking in.

[John Falco]: So this is lost revenue to the city, but it is completely just unfair to the taxpayer that actually buys gas on a regular basis.

[John Falco]: And we all do that.

[John Falco]: So on that, I'd like to move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: To find out what the fee is for each of the inspections.

[John Falco]: to gas inspections, scale inspections at the supermarket.

[John Falco]: I was notified by a resident last week about the condition of the curbing down at the Freedom Way and McGlynn School.

[John Falco]: And they sent me a number of photos, I took a drive down by myself as well just to take a look.

[John Falco]: And I know back a few years ago, I believe the prior administration had started a project with regard to replacing the curbing at the McGlynn School and I believe

[John Falco]: It might be finished, it might be partway finished.

[John Falco]: I know that there is extra curbing that's on the side of the road, but there's still plenty of curbing around the school that some of it's completely obliterated.

[John Falco]: It looks like it's just dust on the ground.

[John Falco]: So I just wanted to get some sort of an update from the administration as to when that's going to be finished or if it's going to be finished.

[John Falco]: It doesn't look like there's enough curbing to finish the job.

[John Falco]: but it does need to be addressed and the company needs to be replaced.

[John Falco]: If someone comes from outside of the city and they see our schools like this, it's a disgrace.

[John Falco]: It doesn't say much about what we're doing about our city and how we're treating our buildings.

[John Falco]: We need to make sure we're safeguarding our buildings and our school properties for the future generations of the city.

[John Falco]: And this is a problem that needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: So at this point, I'd just like to move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Yes, thank you, Councilor, for bringing this forward.

[John Falco]: Raising the reality of inclusion and equity is not a part-time effort.

[John Falco]: It requires the attentive focus of a full-time diversity officer who has time to see the issue at every level.

[John Falco]: This includes hiring practices to help make sure that the faces in City Hall reflect the faces of our community.

[John Falco]: And it also includes the continual analysis of our municipal contracts.

[John Falco]: Who are the companies that we have, that we contract with?

[John Falco]: What is the percentage of contracts that the city has with minority businesses or businesses that are owned by women?

[John Falco]: Correct.

[John Falco]: get a lot of customers, which I guess would be a good thing.

[John Falco]: No, no, sir.

[John Falco]: Yes, sir.

[John Falco]: Are they same size, same number of tanks?

[John Falco]: I'm just kind of curious.

[John Falco]: Do we have anything on file that we can look at?

[John Falco]: To me, I'm curious about that.

[John Falco]: That's just, you know, I mean, to me, there's a lot of

[John Falco]: I'm not a gasoline expert.

[John Falco]: I mean, but I know there's a lot of gas in that area.

[John Falco]: I mean, you're talking, what, I think between the three tanks, there are like 60,000 gallons worth of gas?

[John Falco]: And then I would imagine, if I'm correct, the gas station across the street is pretty sizable as well.

[John Falco]: I don't know what they have, but I would imagine it might be something similar.

[John Falco]: So I'm just curious as to what, you know, that gas station has across the street.

[John Falco]: And I don't know, but I mean, I'm not sure what are the gas stations in the community.

[John Falco]: I'm not sure how they set up, but I mean, that's, to me, that's just kind of curious about that.

[John Falco]: With regard to gasoline, so I have questions regarding gasoline delivery.

[John Falco]: How often will this be, will you be getting gas deliveries?

[John Falco]: Is that something that you would be able to answer?

[John Falco]: One time per day to fill up?

[John Falco]: Approximately, yes.

[John Falco]: And is that coming at a certain time?

[John Falco]: And if it's not at a certain time, is it going to be between certain hours?

[John Falco]: Will it be coming late at night or early in the morning?

[John Falco]: So is there,

[John Falco]: So one of my concerns would be, and we haven't heard from the neighbors yet.

[John Falco]: I mean, could there be a gas delivery at five in the morning?

[John Falco]: Is that something that could happen?

[John Falco]: Are these large tanker trucks that are delivering the fuel?

[John Falco]: And I'm just thinking with regard to the neighbors, you know, especially if you're going late at night, early in the morning, do these have diesel engines, these trucks?

[John Falco]: You know, diesel engines are usually louder, so.

[John Falco]: Does that make sense?

[John Falco]: That makes sense.

[John Falco]: I'm just trying to think of the impact it's going to have on the neighborhood.

[John Falco]: And I know, for me, if I lived in the neighborhood, I would have questions like this.

[John Falco]: how is it going to impact the residents?

[John Falco]: That's so, you know, quality of life issue, noise, traffic, you know, these are all things that, you know, I have questions about.

[John Falco]: When I look at a project like that, that's why I ask these types of questions.

[John Falco]: It does have an impact.

[John Falco]: As minimal as you may think it seems, I'm not saying that you think it's minimal.

[John Falco]: Some people might think it's minimal, but if you live in the neighborhood, it's a concern.

[John Falco]: So that's why I'm asking these questions.

[John Falco]: Is there a, so as far as the safety devices that are set up, I mean, I would imagine there's all kinds of safety devices within the pumps and whatnot.

[John Falco]: We buy the best that money can buy.

[John Falco]: With regard to the parking lot and the new plantings, which I think that's the vast improvement.

[John Falco]: One of the complaints I received is that at times the lot can be dirty, trash.

[John Falco]: So is there a maintenance plan for that parking lot?

[John Falco]: Put it this way.

[John Falco]: You're just saying that I think the plant things on Woodruff and the Woodruff side, they were in tough shape.

[John Falco]: So to me, when I hear that, that means that maybe they haven't been maintained.

[John Falco]: They have, you know, so therefore, you know, BJ's maybe hasn't been on the ball with regards to the maintenance.

[John Falco]: I mean, is there a maintenance plan in place where this is going to be, you know,

[John Falco]: maintained on a regular basis, cleaned on a regular basis.

[John Falco]: You know, if you're putting down mulch yearly, can you talk a little bit about that?

[John Falco]: So do you have a maintenance plan?

[John Falco]: Is there something in writing a maintenance plan that BJ's has for this parking lot?

[John Falco]: We have an internal document.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Is that something you can send to us?

[John Falco]: It'd be nice to know.

[John Falco]: I mean, like I said before, that's one of the complaints I get.

[John Falco]: I know when I'm walking through there, sometimes, you know, it looks like, you know, I'm not sure how often you have a street sweeper come through.

[John Falco]: But you mentioned, this is, I mean, for some people, this is their front yard.

[John Falco]: And they're literally looking at this all the time.

[John Falco]: So therefore, you know what, it should be clean all the time.

[John Falco]: That's the way I look

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I appreciate you answering all our questions.

[John Falco]: You were just talking about the fence.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: As our budget season is quickly approaching, it is time to look at all of our various accounts to see where money is and how it's being spent and to make sure that we finish the year in good shape and start off the next fiscal year in good shape.

[John Falco]: Back in 2010, then Mayor McGlynn signed a billboard agreement with Clair Channel.

[John Falco]: And the agreement stated that Clear Channel would make a lump payment, an impact fee payment to the city in the year, in the 11th year of the agreement, which would be fiscal year 2021 of $250,000.

[John Falco]: And I came across this through some research, basically after the budget was passed.

[John Falco]: And when I asked the administration, I was told that this was not factored into the budget,

[John Falco]: And that came from the CFO.

[John Falco]: And then I was forwarded on to the chief of staff, Dave Rodriguez.

[John Falco]: Dave did tell me that they learned of the payment after the budget was prepared and therefore was not part of the budget.

[John Falco]: And at that point in time, I asked, well, how's the money being spent?

[John Falco]: And the explanation I received was that the city's current plan is to use it for one time unanticipated costs

[John Falco]: and emergency health safety costs that cannot be covered by the CARES or FEMA.

[John Falco]: For example, let's see, there's an engineer that contacted the mayor's office in a panic that the road work at the bottom of Bedford High School is scheduled to be done.

[John Falco]: This is back in August, that they didn't have enough, let's see, that the, was gonna be canceled due to not having necessary funds available.

[John Falco]: And the mayor was able to okay this by using these funds from, that they had from the,

[John Falco]: from the impact fee.

[John Falco]: The section of Harris Park did not have fence, which the city staff were concerned about from a safety perspective.

[John Falco]: And they were able to repair this using these funds.

[John Falco]: They used these funds for roading control in response to complaints received throughout the community.

[John Falco]: And they also used it for road and safety, pedestrian improvements around the city, particularly around the schools.

[John Falco]: So if we could get, so basically if I could get a detailed itemized listing of how the $250,000 was spent from the billboard agreements, and if we could send that to the CFO and to the chief of staff.

[John Falco]: with COVID and it's, you know, it's amazing how, you know, you put your own safety and well-being on the line every day, you know, in a normal day, and then you put COVID into it as well.

[John Falco]: This is really, I mean, I love to see data and this is great.

[John Falco]: You can look at this over the past three, four years, and you can really see

[John Falco]: the uptick in the number of calls and it's, you know, I haven't had a chance to really read it yet.

[John Falco]: I may have just received it when I came to the meeting, but I know I'll be reading it over and I'll definitely be giving you a call probably with more in-depth questions.

[John Falco]: I also wanted to thank Detective Stanton, especially this domestic violence piece in the back of the report.

[John Falco]: A quick question with regard to the lease.

[John Falco]: At the end of the lease, do we have the option to buy the vehicles?

[John Falco]: You own them outright.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: That was my, that's, that was my big question.

[John Falco]: So we own at the end of the lease.

[John Falco]: Perfect.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I also want to thank Councilor Scarpelli for bringing this forward.

[John Falco]: Very important issue.

[John Falco]: You know, Desi's pushing for full-time return to in-school, full return to in-person learning.

[John Falco]: And this can't be achieved without significant changes in our social distancing guidelines.

[John Falco]: If you take a look around our country, there are 28 states that have prioritized teacher vaccination and the state of Massachusetts still has not prioritized teacher vaccinations.

[John Falco]: I received a number of calls over the past week regarding pickleball.

[John Falco]: It's been around for many years, but I think in our area, it's gaining popularity.

[John Falco]: And from what I've been told, it's gaining a lot of popularity with our senior residents.

[John Falco]: similar to tennis, but not quite like tennis, it's similar to tennis.

[John Falco]: And like I said, it's become very popular.

[John Falco]: But currently our parks are lined for pickleball.

[John Falco]: It was an update with regards to our parks and open space.

[John Falco]: know, if you take a look at the city of Medford, you know, we have many parks, many parks throughout our community, and all different sections of the city, all different neighborhoods, and we pride ourselves on our parks and open space.

[John Falco]: And, you know, so what this resolution is, it's basically a proposal that all of our tennis courts be lined to retrofitted so that they can be used for pickleball.

[John Falco]: it would give the availability for people to play pickleball in any neighborhood, not just have to go to one particular park.

[John Falco]: So, each of us has received many, many calls I think throughout the years, each and every one of us with regard to potholes, streets that are in disrepair.

[John Falco]: And this year is a program that President Caraviello and I learned about last year at a conference.

[John Falco]: And what it is, is it basically takes recycled asphalt, and actually they use it to pave the street again.

[John Falco]: There are numerous benefits to the process, shorter construction times, it's easier to use around catch basins and manholes and water valves and whatnot.

[John Falco]: It lowers engineering and traffic control costs as well.

[John Falco]: to say the least, the 2022 city budget is going to be a challenge.

[John Falco]: Also, the CDC, Centers for Disease Prevention and Control, established a federal moratorium on residential evictions that I believe will expire on March 31, 2021.

[John Falco]: The purpose of my resolution is to prompt a City Council discussion with an eye on passing an ordinance requiring property owners who are serving tenants an eviction notice to include with it a notice of tenants' rights and resources.

[John Falco]: All too often, tenants are unaware of their rights and do not know that there are resources available to them.

[John Falco]: Stability requires many things, but first among them is knowledge.

[John Falco]: nearing its point of completion.

[John Falco]: But I really, really believe that now more than ever, we need to make sure that the hospital is engaging with the residents to make sure that we can ensure a good quality of life up in that neighborhood when this comes to completion.

[John Falco]: Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Councilor Felkel.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: And I apologize.

[John Falco]: But first and foremost, thank you, Mr. Fuller, for your presentation.

[John Falco]: You had mentioned the soft opening and great surgeons from Tufts Medical and OrthoCare and ENT and Gastro and additional specialists.

[John Falco]: Do you have a date like when you would think that this facility will be fully operational with all of these new specialties?

[John Falco]: So after this coming March-April, you'll start to see things really ramp up?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: And I know there was a question earlier about the branding of this site, you know, people calling it

[John Falco]: Lawson Memorial Hospital, LMH, Circle Health, Hallmark Health.

[John Falco]: Has there been any progress with regard to the branding?

[John Falco]: I know we talked about before, I think you mentioned it might be called the medical village.

[John Falco]: Is there any discussion as to what the end result is or is that still being talked about?

[John Falco]: Do you have any timeline with regard to when that name would change?

[John Falco]: I've received calls from residents in the neighborhood about the traffic at the top of Fell's Ave.

[John Falco]: And when you approach the top of Fell's Ave, if you're heading down towards Fern Road, that side of Fell's Ave, there are some signs there that say, basically, drive slow, children, school bus, stop ahead.

[John Falco]: And at one point in time, there was a crosswalk in front of, I believe it was 185 Fern Road.

[John Falco]: And you can see that.

[John Falco]: It just never got painted again.

[John Falco]: It's faded out and it's a section of the road where really you need some sort of I would think crosswalk because that's where the road really widens when you go towards.

[John Falco]: Fells Ave or if you bear left, you're gonna go towards Hickory Ave and towards Oak Road.

[John Falco]: So there's a really wide point in the road there that is a... Can be a problem when people cross.

[John Falco]: So in the interest of public safety, if we could please have a crosswalk installed by the DPW in that vicinity.

[John Falco]: I think that the police could probably weigh in and the traffic engineer as to where it would be best.

[John Falco]: But in that section, there used to be a crosswalk.

[John Falco]: So if we could have a crosswalk installed

[John Falco]: in that area.

[John Falco]: I greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: So I definitely agree that we need to do that sooner than later.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: One of the most important responsibilities we have each year is to review and either pass or reject the city budget.

[John Falco]: You know, tonight I offer this resolution to shed light on a process that I think is somewhat flawed.

[John Falco]: You know, every year we meet in June with the city of Medford department heads to discuss their budget and discuss the proposed budget for the upcoming year.

[John Falco]: More often than not, it's our only formal meeting that we have with department heads throughout the year.

[John Falco]: And I think more often than not,

[John Falco]: Those meetings become more, we're asking questions probably that are more than just budget related questions.

[John Falco]: Sometimes they're policy questions and whatnot.

[John Falco]: So this here tonight is basically a proactive approach that I'm asking President Caraviello if in the upcoming months of February, March, April, and May, if you could schedule pre-budget hearings with each of our department heads to go over their current budget,

[John Falco]: To take a look at the goals and objectives to see if they're accomplishing

[John Falco]: what they've said that their goals and objectives are for this current year.

[John Falco]: So basically, it's a proactive approach, and it gives us an opportunity to ask department heads questions that sometimes aren't even budget related.

[John Falco]: So it's to hopefully streamline the budget process when we discuss the budget in June.

[John Falco]: So I think that we have to pass this budget, or actually pass or reject this budget each year.

[John Falco]: This is really large, and we need to make sure that we have all the information that we need to make that decision.

[John Falco]: And I think meeting with department heads more than once a year is something that we should be doing.

[John Falco]: Me meeting them once a year to have a quick budget meeting in June, to me, doesn't cut it.

[John Falco]: So I think that what we need to do is budget meetings so we can actually have a nice conversation that is full of information.

[John Falco]: And if there's items that we need to follow up on or they need to follow up on, that's fine.

[John Falco]: We're not doing it last minute in June.

[John Falco]: So therefore, I would ask if you could please schedule budget meetings, maybe two or three a month.

[John Falco]: Starting in February would be ideal.

[John Falco]: So I would respectfully ask for my colleagues to support this and I move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Recently, I received calls from residents regarding the C-Click Fix program.

[John Falco]: For many people that might not know, that's a program that we use to basically, the residents can enter into any type of issues that they're having, and then they're assigned to the appropriate department head where hopefully they can be resolved in a timely fashion.

[John Falco]: Recently, I was notified that

[John Falco]: The issues that were logged by a number of residents were basically cleared out and deleted.

[John Falco]: So they no longer appear on the list of outstanding issues.

[John Falco]: And from what I'm hearing, this is the second time that this has happened.

[John Falco]: I think when the previous administration crossed over to the current administration, they cleared out C-Click Fix.

[John Falco]: And then when recently, I think they may have an upgrade or something, and they did the same thing, they cleared out issues again.

[John Falco]: So what they're doing is basically they're clearing out issues that have never been resolved.

[John Falco]: And I think one of the reasons why it was closed was because it was a seasonal issue.

[John Falco]: It may be an issue that couldn't be dealt with because the weather was getting cold.

[John Falco]: But from my opinion, that doesn't mean that the issue's gone away.

[John Falco]: And I think that's what's happening now is we're losing, there's really no transparency when something like this happens.

[John Falco]: Because if you're just deleting issues because maybe you can't

[John Falco]: take care of them in the wintertime, that doesn't mean that the issue's gone away.

[John Falco]: That means the issue still exists, it should still be in the list.

[John Falco]: And then what happens is they get this email back saying that it's a seasonal issue, and then they ask the person, I believe, if it's been resolved.

[John Falco]: As far as I'm concerned, that's the city's responsibility, is whether or not an issue's been resolved, because the ticket's been assigned to someone in the city.

[John Falco]: So if we could please get an update from the city administration as to what's going on with CClickFix.

[John Falco]: If issues are being deleted, why?

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, if you wouldn't mind, what time did that email come in at?

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: If I may, if I could also amend my resolution to find out what it means when they say fit method and our needs.

[John Falco]: So I guess C-Click Fix needs to work differently in Medford than it does anywhere else.

[John Falco]: So I would like to know if they could please specify what that means.

[John Falco]: Because I think there's a lot of uncertainty right now as to C-Click Fix, how it's managed,

[John Falco]: how it operates, when you're deleting issues that haven't been resolved, I have a problem with that.

[John Falco]: Basically, you're saying the issue doesn't exist anymore when it does.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: On the motion by Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: I just want to thank all my colleagues for their support on this here.

[John Falco]: And Councilor Knight mentioned, I think, an important part about data-driven decision-making.

[John Falco]: And if you don't have the systems in place to give you that data, the decisions aren't going to be, you're really not going to be able to use it as a tool.

[John Falco]: And you're right, Councilor Marks mentioned it before about using it as a tool.

[John Falco]: It's important to have that tool available.

[John Falco]: And Councilor Scarpelli, you hit it on the head.

[John Falco]: With regard to resources, if it's not managed properly, it's not going to help anyone.

[John Falco]: So if you wouldn't mind, if we could also schedule committee the whole with the administration to actually, if it's training fine, but to learn more about the new system, that would be great.

[John Falco]: And to find out what we can get out of it.

[John Falco]: It would be nice to know if there's any type of reporting that we can get out of this system.

[John Falco]: I know when we first went to see quick fix, I asked about that.

[John Falco]: They said there was nothing, which I find hard to believe, but I would hope.

[John Falco]: Well, I would think that there should be some sort of reporting that we can access to see what's being done, what's not being done, what's being resolved, what we can use, how we can look at the data, what type of calls are coming in.

[John Falco]: And it'll really help with the budget process at the end of the year when we take a look at that and see all the work that's been done.

[John Falco]: I know there's work that's getting done.

[John Falco]: But I also know that it needs to be managed correctly and if we're just closing tickets for the sake of closing tickets, it's not very transparent and it doesn't mean that the issue goes away.

[John Falco]: Thank you everyone for your support, and I move approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: President, all seven members are present.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen.

[John Falco]: or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Hearings.

[John Falco]: Do we have time for this?

[John Falco]: Hearings, legal notice 20-673.

[John Falco]: petition for grant of location, National Grid and Verizon, North Andover, Massachusetts, locations of poles, wires, and fixtures, Medford, Massachusetts, city clerk's office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, December 22nd, 2020.

[John Falco]: A link to be posted no later than Friday.

[John Falco]: Excuse me, excuse me.

[John Falco]: I have to read the meeting notice and then at that point I will recognize you and we will begin the process.

[John Falco]: No worries, thank you.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified of that by order of the Medford City Council.

[John Falco]: The Medford City Council will hold the public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday, December 22nd, 2020, a link to be posted no later than Friday, December 8th, 2020, on a petition of Massachusetts Electrical Company, DBA, National Grid, and Verizon New England for permission to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across the public way

[John Falco]: or ways, herein named, said poles, wires, and fixtures to be located substantially in accordance with the plan marked Mitchell Ave., meant for Massachusetts, and filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: Wherever it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires, together with sustaining and protecting fixtures,

[John Falco]: As it may find necessary, said poles to be erected substantially in accordance with the plan filed herewith marked Mitchell Ave, Medford, Massachusetts, and available for inspection.

[John Falco]: In the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103-85, George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[John Falco]: Mitchell Ave, national grid to install one,

[John Falco]: J.O.

[John Falco]: pole on Mitchell Ave beginning at a point approximately 14 feet east of the center line.

[John Falco]: Install one new joint pole P2818 approximately 60 feet northeast of existing pole P3817 near 93 Mitchell Ave.

[John Falco]: Location approximately as shown on plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: This was approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Engineering Division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to this one joint owned J.O.

[John Falco]: pole as described in the petition.

[John Falco]: National grid to install one J.O.

[John Falco]: pole on Mitchell Ave beginning at a point approximately 14 feet east of the center line.

[John Falco]: Install one new joint pole P3818 approximately 60 feet northeast of the existing pole P3817 in 93 Mitchell Avenue.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify dig safe and shall obtain all applicable permits.

[John Falco]: for the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other apparatuses are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer water and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Number four, the new pole location is located within the furniture zone of the concrete sidewalk.

[John Falco]: Any disturbance of the curb-to-curb concrete backing must be repaired to the satisfaction of the city engineer.

[John Falco]: The sidewalk panel must be replaced in kind in the pole surrounded by an expansion joint.

[John Falco]: Number five, the project must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris.

[John Falco]: for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Approved by the superintendent of wires, call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations or aids.

[John Falco]: Plans can be viewed in the city clerk's office, 781-393-2425, Adam L. Herdeby, city clerk.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I would open up the public hearing to those in favor of the petition.

[John Falco]: Is there anyone with us tonight that is in favor of the petition that would like to speak?

[John Falco]: So we have, there was someone from Verizon, right?

[John Falco]: Oh, okay, so let's see.

[John Falco]: National Grid, I'm sorry.

[John Falco]: Offered by Council on 8.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the rules of the Medford City Council be amended as follows.

[John Falco]: New section.

[John Falco]: Public hearings.

[John Falco]: Matters requiring public hearing before the City Council shall be conducted as follows.

[John Falco]: Number 1.

[John Falco]: The petition is read into the record.

[John Falco]: Number 2.

[John Falco]: The petitioner provides an explanation of the matter requiring a public hearing.

[John Falco]: Number 3.

[John Falco]: The public hearing is conducted.

[John Falco]: Number four, following the public hearing, a six calendar day public comment period shall commence.

[John Falco]: Public comments shall be submitted in writing to the clerk.

[John Falco]: Number five, the council shall neither approve nor deny any public require, I'm sorry.

[John Falco]: Number five, the council shall neither approve nor deny any matter requiring public hearing until the conclusion of the public comment period

[John Falco]: and less waived by a majority vote of the council.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Motion to send this to the Rules Committee, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: OK, on the motion by Vice President Caraviello to send this paper to the Rules Committee, that is seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: So let's see, next item is communications from the mayor, 20-687, December 18th, 2020.

[John Falco]: to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts 02155 regarding Community Preservation Committee.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully submit the following recommendations of the Community Preservation Committee to the City Council for their consideration.

[John Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $30,000 from the CPA Historic Preservation Reserve to the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust Incorporated for phase three of the restoration of an historic stone wall at the Brooks Estate.

[John Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $275,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the City of Medford Public Library for the Medford Public Library exterior space project.

[John Falco]: Requesting an appropriation of $76,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for the rehabilitation of the Placed at Park basketball court.

[John Falco]: requesting the appropriation of $15,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for the playground resurfacing at Tufts, Capon and Cummings Park.

[John Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $293,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Parks Division for rehabilitation of Duggar Park Tennis Courts.

[John Falco]: requesting the appropriation of $40,000 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the City of Medford Conservation Commission for the Riverside Avenue stormwater improvements.

[John Falco]: Requesting the appropriation of $322,000 from the CPA General Reserve to the City of Medford Recreation Department for the rehabilitation and improvements at Tufts Pool.

[John Falco]: All projects will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund by category, open space, historic preservation, and general reserve.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehnman.

[John Falco]: So I believe we have Roberta Cameron with us tonight.

[John Falco]: And we have Danielle Evans.

[John Falco]: I'm going to unmute them just in case anyone has any questions.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained therein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website, an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email our city clerk, A Hurtubise, that is A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'd just like to make a general announcement that we are having intermittent,

[John Falco]: internet issues here at city hall.

[John Falco]: And we are unable to actually broadcast the meeting via zoom tonight.

[John Falco]: So if anyone has questions that may be watching on a TV, we ask you to please email the city clerk directly.

[John Falco]: That is Adam her to me is once again, that is a H U R T U B I S E at

[John Falco]: Medford, M-E-D-F-O-R-D dash M-A dot gov.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford High School Hall of Famer, Brian Branson, be recognized and officially honored by the City of Medford for his several decades of unselfish volunteerism and commitment to Medford High student-athletes and sport programs.

[John Falco]: Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: And if I may quickly, I first met Brian Branson when I was 15 years old.

[John Falco]: I was a sophomore at High School.

[John Falco]: And like Councilor Marks mentioned, Brian was the team manager for the football team.

[John Falco]: And believe it or not, I played football.

[John Falco]: And, but he was, he's just an amazing, amazing person in, you know,

[John Falco]: people like Brian are people that you want in your community.

[John Falco]: And I remember being 15 years old and I remember learning, you know, right away from coach Bud Kelly, you know, and he would always talk about, you know, blue and white running through your veins.

[John Falco]: You have blue and white running through your veins.

[John Falco]: And that was all about Mustang football and being dedicated and committed and being someone who was committed to the team, but also committed to the city and working hard.

[John Falco]: And that's someone, and I will tell you something, there is no one that has

[John Falco]: We're blue and white running through their veins and Brian Branson.

[John Falco]: He is a remarkable person who

[John Falco]: just, you know, just very dedicated to our community, dedicated to sports at the high school for years.

[John Falco]: And like Councilor Mark said, I think at least probably 20 years that he was a statistician at the high school, you know, working with the football team and the baseball team.

[John Falco]: And I remember seeing him every Saturday when I played.

[John Falco]: And then after that, I'd come back and he was still there and he was still doing it and he loved it.

[John Falco]: And he loved giving back and,

[John Falco]: And, you know, later on in life, he decided, well, I'm going to be an umpire.

[John Falco]: And I remember saying to him, you sure you want to do that?

[John Falco]: And he wanted to do it and he loves doing it.

[John Falco]: And I know he goes out to Cooperstown every year to, you know, to actually the home of our, actually that's where our city clerk was born and raised.

[John Falco]: But he, Brian would go out there every year to umpire baseball games for the whole weekend.

[John Falco]: And he loved it, and he enjoyed it, and he always gave back.

[John Falco]: And so I think this is a very fitting honor.

[John Falco]: Council Marks, I thank you for bringing this forward.

[John Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli and Council Marks, you both hit it on the head with the words that you had to say.

[John Falco]: He's completely committed to our city, to the youth of our community, and it's a well-deserved honor.

[John Falco]: So on the motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: that are scheduled for the coming months due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

[John Falco]: Location dates to be determined by resident request, seeking up to five locations between November and March, requesting one lunch,

[John Falco]: and or dinner in one dessert truck per location and or date.

[John Falco]: 20-663 offered by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Whereas COVID-19 cases are spiking across the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Governor Baker has chosen to take no further action to protect

[John Falco]: the health of residents and whereas super spreader events have seriously impacted residents of Medford, including members of our city and school staff.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the city administration explore any and all options to increase COVID-19 mitigation action actions in the city of Medford and provide an update on any plans to protect

[John Falco]: residents from COVID-19 community spread no later than the December 15th meeting of the Medford City Council, Council Affairs.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Peers.

[John Falco]: Any other comments?

[John Falco]: You are correct because I remember, I think it was Councilor Morell's paper.

[John Falco]: No, no, no.

[John Falco]: I understand and I agree.

[John Falco]: I mean, we should have something in writing.

[John Falco]: We definitely do.

[John Falco]: you know, some sort of an update from the administration.

[John Falco]: We haven't received one.

[John Falco]: What was it, Councilor Morell, if you don't mind, do you know the last time we actually received?

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: And if actually, you know, if I could actually vice president, if you wouldn't mind coming up, I just have a couple, if you wouldn't mind, I'd like to have met here.

[John Falco]: Thank you for bringing this forward, because I think it is very important.

[John Falco]: And I think Councilor Morell, thank you for bringing our resolution forward a few months ago.

[John Falco]: And I think it's important that we receive periodic updates.

[John Falco]: Actually, they should be monthly updates, but we should be notified on a regular basis.

[John Falco]: Because I know I'm getting all kinds of questions with regard to, I think some of the data, general questions as to, and I think a lot of it is education with regard to,

[John Falco]: You know, I got a lot of questions about, you know, what is the threshold for notifying the community about potential exposure?

[John Falco]: So if there are, you know, how is a cluster determined?

[John Falco]: And I think they had about 250 people at the theater.

[John Falco]: I'm not sure how that works, but I think that we need to get answers on that.

[John Falco]: Did they approve the event?

[John Falco]: So it became, I think the person that was performing was supposed to be singing in public, on the stage.

[John Falco]: And that's a clarification I'd like to receive.

[John Falco]: Who requested the modifications to the event?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: And the event changed, I think, right beforehand.

[John Falco]: Communications from the Mayor, 20656, November 25th, 2020, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council authorize me, as Mayor, on behalf of the City of Medford, to enter into a tax increment financing, TIF, TIF,

[John Falco]: agreement with Monogram Gourmet Foods LLC in accordance with the Massachusetts Economic Development Incentive Program, EDIP, and Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 23A, Chapter 40, Section 59, and Chapter 59.

[John Falco]: I will be present at the meeting with members of the administration, Chief Assessor Ellen Bordeaux, Jeffrey Monica from Monogram Gourmet Foods, and Maria DeStefano from the Massachusetts Office of Business Development to discuss the agreement as well as Monogram Gourmet Foods plan for the proposed operation in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: The meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties.

[John Falco]: With the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen and or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk, Adam Hertubez at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation

[John Falco]: on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen,

[John Falco]: or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk and his email address is

[John Falco]: H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at Medford-MA.gov.

[John Falco]: That is A Hertubis at Medford-MA.gov.
