[John Falco]: The notice of a public hearing, 20-622 petition for grant of location, National Grid, gas main locations, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on November 17th, 2020.

[John Falco]: 2020, a link to be posted no later than Friday, November 13th, 2020 on a petition of Boston Gas DBA National Grid for permission to locate gas mains as herein after described for the transmission of gas in and under the following public streets, lanes, highways, and places of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Knight, to waive the reading to have a brief synopsis from a representative from National Grid.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: President Falco.

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: Ms.

[John Falco]: Cuddy, if you could please give us a brief synopsis of the project.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: This here has been approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the grant application be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant application is limited to approximately 532 feet of plastic gas main as described in the petition.

[John Falco]: To install and maintain approximately 532 feet of new four-inch plastic main extension from the existing two-inch plastic main in the Whitty Hill Road going on to Medford Street and extending to the service location at 87 Medford.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE.

[John Falco]: It shall obtain all applicable permits.

[John Falco]: from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances.

[John Falco]: are adversely impacted, National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration must be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[John Falco]: The concrete sidewalk must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints.

[John Falco]: The de minimis concrete pavement over the trench shall be milled and overlaid as described below.

[John Falco]: A Winter Hill Road includes approximately 130 feet of new gas main.

[John Falco]: This section of the street also includes trench patches associated with gas service work.

[John Falco]: Winter Hill Road should be restored with a mill and overlay that encompasses past national grid patches.

[John Falco]: B, the side of Medford Street with the proposed main includes multiple gas related trench patches that extend to the center seam of the roadway asphalt.

[John Falco]: It also includes trenches associated with other utility connections for 87 Medford Street.

[John Falco]: The Medford Street surface restoration should include mill and overlay from curb to central line seam.

[John Falco]: C, it is the understanding of the engineering division that the owner of the 87 Method Street project will provide the street restoration.

[John Falco]: The engineering division takes no exception to the owner providing this scope.

[John Falco]: However, National Grid remains responsible for confirming that the restoration is performed in accordance with this grant of location, the standards of the city of Medford, and the associated street opening permit.

[John Falco]: Number five, the new four inch gas main appears to be offset with the existing drain line by approximately three feet.

[John Falco]: This offset should be confirmed and maintained.

[John Falco]: Number six, the new four inch gas main appears to pass in between two drainage structures near 85 Medford Street.

[John Falco]: The condition of these structures in lateral must be verified before and after construction with the highway division.

[John Falco]: Number seven, pavement markings must be restored.

[John Falco]: Number eight, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Number nine, Medford Street is a highly traveled roadway for vehicles as well as pedestrians.

[John Falco]: A detailed traffic management plan must be submitted to the engineering division for review and approved prior to receiving

[John Falco]: a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: The TMP traffic management plan must include accommodations for pedestrians in addition to vehicles.

[John Falco]: Number 10, the plan submitted with the petition is not stamped by a professional engineer.

[John Falco]: National grid must, must submit a professional engineer stamp plan to the engineering division prior to release of a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: Number 11, only one service is shown 87 Medford street.

[John Falco]: This project is limited to that one service.

[John Falco]: If national grid,

[John Falco]: Plans to provide additional services, especially to the east side of Medford Street as part of this project, the engineering division must be notified and the surface restoration must be curb to curb.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodation.

[John Falco]: AIDS, TDD, 781-393-2516.

[John Falco]: For further information, contact the city clerk at 781-393-2425.

[John Falco]: The city of Medford is an EEO, AA 504 employer.

[John Falco]: By order of the city council, Adam L. Herdeby, city clerk.

[John Falco]: At this point, I would declare the public hearing open.

[John Falco]: Open to those in favor of the petition.

[John Falco]: Ms.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting maybe can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the

[John Falco]: The public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, in audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Whereas public safety concerns raised almost two years ago to city officials by residents living in the neighborhood of Fulton spring road, bells at Murray Hill road and fells out of terrorists have gone without any response or relief from the city.

[John Falco]: And whereas it's known

[John Falco]: known fact that many roads in North Medford are used as cut-through, and whereas the Medford City Council requested that a complete traffic study be done of the entire area to help alleviate concerns of area residents regarding speeding and cut-through traffic.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council hold an on-site committee of the whole meeting on either Saturday, November 21st or Saturday, November 28th, and invite area neighbors, police, Chief Buckley, City Engineer Tim McGibbon, Traffic Engineer Tom Blake, Mayor's Office, and DPW Commissioner Brian Kearns, Catholics.

[John Falco]: I can do that?

[John Falco]: And if I may, I want to thank Council Marks for bringing this forward as I very well know how painful the traffic is in this area.

[John Falco]: I live on Fulton Spring Road and I think I've told you before.

[John Falco]: I'm not getting out of the morning.

[John Falco]: That's how bad the traffic is.

[John Falco]: Even during the pandemic did a lot of for a while.

[John Falco]: But even during the pandemic, you know, it's it's an issue in the morning.

[John Falco]: And I even between the stop signs of and I can speak this person because I live there.

[John Falco]: The stop signs between Fulton Spring and Fulton Street in Fulton

[John Falco]: literally the traffic, it's like people race to get from one stop sign to the next.

[John Falco]: And it, it is, it is a safety hazard.

[John Falco]: And I've, I've talked to the, um, to, uh, Sergeant Hartman about this before in the past.

[John Falco]: Uh, so he's, I think everyone's well aware of it, but you're right.

[John Falco]: These things need to be addressed.

[John Falco]: And the last time I, because I would get a lot of calls with regard to, um,

[John Falco]: traffic in the morning because pre-pandemic the traffic literally used to go up Fells Ave and down the other side.

[John Falco]: It was like a parade of cars.

[John Falco]: And I think that what happened was at one point they were trying to go before the Malden traffic commission to see if they could shut down kind of the traffic coming in on the Malden side.

[John Falco]: But I think

[John Falco]: Malden said no to it, I think.

[John Falco]: But that's something we could discuss at the meeting.

[John Falco]: And I think that's why they couldn't alleviate some of the traffic.

[John Falco]: But we need to look at something.

[John Falco]: You are 100% correct.

[John Falco]: It needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: So if you don't mind me asking now, is everyone available on the 21st of November?

[John Falco]: Is that I can get on it right away?

[John Falco]: No.

[John Falco]: Okay, we have a no.

[John Falco]: Also, what time are we thinking?

[John Falco]: The 28th would be an issue.

[John Falco]: What time are we thinking?

[John Falco]: That also has an impact.

[John Falco]: I mean, I would say probably preferably in the morning.

[John Falco]: All seven members of the president at this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: Yes, one minute please.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Manfred City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen.

[John Falco]: or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email our city clerk, Adam Hurtubise at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: Next item.

[John Falco]: Key one nine dash six six zero motions under motions, orders and resolutions.

[John Falco]: This is the promote, prevent, support behavioral health commission being ordained by the city council of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Chapter X of the ordinances of the City of Medford, as most recently amended, is hereby further amended to insert the following after the present article, the following article.

[John Falco]: Promote, prevent, support Behavioral Health Commission.

[John Falco]: The purpose, to monitor, track, inform, and make recommendations to city officials and policy makers in the City of Medford about behavioral health data, issues, needs, and efforts within the city.

[John Falco]: The Medford promote, prevent, support Behavioral Health Commission shall,

[John Falco]: build community partnerships and collaboration amongst providers, social services organizations, and city government to identify and address the social determinants of health, social, environmental, and economic challenges that contribute to poor behavioral health, poor behavioral mental health and substance use outcomes.

[John Falco]: Serve as an advisory board to the city on all matters dealing with behavioral health and make recommendations to address needs such as evidence-based practices, programs, and systems.

[John Falco]: environmental or policy changes to prevent behavioral health disorders and promote behavioral health and wellness.

[John Falco]: Set overall community-wide goals and create a strategic plan for achieving mental and emotional well-being for all residents of Medford.

[John Falco]: Be the clearinghouse and repository for behavioral health programming and plans within the city to ensure efforts are purposeful and aligned with overall strategic planning goals.

[John Falco]: Behavioral health is a state of mental and emotional being and or choices in actions that affect wellness.

[John Falco]: Substance abuse and misuse are one set of behavioral health problems.

[John Falco]: Others include, but are not limited to, serious psychological distress, suicide, and mental illness, SAMHSA 2011.

[John Falco]: Specific goals may be approved by the commission as it seeks to fulfill.

[John Falco]: Okay, on the motion of Councilor Knight to waive the reading.

[John Falco]: Seconded by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Clerk, can I please call the roll?

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: 7 in the affirmative, 0 in the negative.

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: On the motion.

[John Falco]: On that motion by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Mr. President.

[John Falco]: See, Clerk Kurtabees, do we have a representative from National Grid with us?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: 2-0-6-0-0, petition for grant of location, National Grid Gas Main Locations, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's Office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing via Zoom on October 27, 2020.

[John Falco]: A link will be posted no later than Friday, October 23rd, 2020, on a petition for Boston Gas DBA National Grid for permission to locate.

[John Falco]: gas mains as here and described for the transmission of gas in and out of the following public streets, lanes, highways, and places of the city of Medford in of the pipes, valves, governors, manholes, and other structures, pictures, appearances designed or intended to protect or operate said mains and accomplish the objective objects of said company in the digging up and opening the ground to play or play sand.

[John Falco]: The,

[John Falco]: to install approximately 1,570 feet of eight-inch plastic gas main in approximately 170 feet of six-inch plastic gas main along Riverside Avenue, including all tie-ins and stubs on associated cross streets, as shown on the plans dated August 20th, 2020, and available for inspection in the city clerk's, in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 10385, George P. Hassett Drive,

[John Falco]: Massachusetts 02155.

[John Falco]: We afford a praise that after due notice and hearing as provided by law, it is granted a location for in permission to locate gas means as described above for the transmission of gas in and under the above.

[John Falco]: named streets, lanes, highways, and places of the city of Medford substantially as described in the petition date, August 20th, 2020, and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103, 85 George P. Assett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, and of the pipes, valves, governors, manholes, and other structures, fixtures, and appearances.

[John Falco]: designed or intended to protect or operate said mains and accomplish the objects of said company in the digging up in opening the ground to lay or play same and hereby consented to in approved.

[John Falco]: This was approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, these conditions include minor revisions to the proposed gas main routing.

[John Falco]: National grid must submit a final revised set to the engineering division prior to release of a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: This set of drawings must be stamped by a registered professional engineer.

[John Falco]: Number two, the grant of location, GOL, is limited to approximately 1,570 feet of 8-inch plastic gas main, 170 feet of 6-inch plastic gas main and associated

[John Falco]: Number three, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSIG and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 94-144 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: At a minimum, the street opening permit application must include a traffic management plan for review and approval.

[John Falco]: Number four, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Number five, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept safe of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Number six, Riverside Avenue is a highly traveled roadway for vehicles as well as pedestrians.

[John Falco]: A detailed traffic management plan must be submitted to the engineering division for review and approval prior to receiving a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: The traffic master management plan must include accommodations for pedestrians in addition to vehicles.

[John Falco]: Number seven, the proposed gas main crosses the stormwater drainage pipes in multiple locations along the route.

[John Falco]: The drainage pipe shall be video inspected, so the city may evaluate these pipes.

[John Falco]: Drain pipes that are in poor condition must be replaced by national grid.

[John Falco]: Number eight, there appears to be locations along the proposed route where the new gas main is laid too close to the...

[John Falco]: to the Medford 16-inch water main.

[John Falco]: The new gas main layout should be revised to maintain at least four feet offset from the Medford water main.

[John Falco]: Isolated locations of reduced encroachment may be allowed with approval by the Water and Sewer Division and Engineering Division.

[John Falco]: Number nine, the work located at the Locust Street intersection in the Spring Street intersection appears to disturb the traffic detection loops.

[John Falco]: If the traffic loops are disturbed, they must be replaced in kind and in condition with the superintendent of wires in the engineering division.

[John Falco]: Number 10, utility relocations that were performed by the MWRA as part of their section 57 project are shown on the plan and appear to be coordinated.

[John Falco]: National Grid shall confirm utility relocations with the MWRA and revise the plan as needed to eliminate potential conflicts and to provide sufficient offsets.

[John Falco]: Number 11, at the intersection with Locust Street, there appears to be a gas valve in conflict with the Medford 16-inch water main.

[John Falco]: The plan should be revised to remove the valve, to move the valve at least four feet from the water main.

[John Falco]: 12.

[John Falco]: The scope of the MWRA Section 57 project includes resurfacing and striping this portion of Riverside Avenue.

[John Falco]: The Engineering Division requests that National Grid contribute the cost of final restoration to other paving in the City.

[John Falco]: This can be coordinated with the Engineering Division.

[John Falco]: Number 13, the plan includes work in Linden Street.

[John Falco]: Linden Street was recently paved.

[John Falco]: The engineering divisions understood that National Grid completed Linden Street work prior to paving.

[John Falco]: If this is not the case, then Linden Street must be restored curb to curb for a length of at least 50 feet measured from the near curb line on Riverside Avenue or 10 feet beyond National Grid scope of work, whichever is greater.

[John Falco]: Number 14, MWR permits are required to perform this work.

[John Falco]: Copies of the MWRRA permits must be submitted to the engineering division with the street opening permit application.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodations.

[John Falco]: and or AIDS, TDD 781-393-2516.

[John Falco]: For further information, contact the city clerk at 781-393-2425.

[John Falco]: The city of Medford is an EEOAA 504 employer.

[John Falco]: By order of the city council, signed by Adam L. Hurtubise, city clerk.

[John Falco]: I declare this public hearing open, open to those in favor of the petition.

[John Falco]: Is there anyone, let's see, I believe is it Ms.

[John Falco]: Cuddy?

[John Falco]: Is there anyone else in favor that would like to speak?

[John Falco]: in favor of the petition.

[John Falco]: Anyone else here that would like to speak in favor of this petition?

[John Falco]: Okay, Clerk Kierkegaard, I don't see anyone else.

[John Falco]: Okay, hearing and seeing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition of the petition?

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Last month we approved a number of papers that came to us from the mayor to

[John Falco]: funding to fix various HVAC issues throughout the Medford Public Schools.

[John Falco]: I believe the total amount of the funding we approved was approximately about $800,000.

[John Falco]: The ongoing problems with the air quality throughout our district concerns me not only as a city councilor, but also as a parent.

[John Falco]: I have two students, two of my kids are in the Medford Public Schools, two are at Medford High School.

[John Falco]: And like many kids, many of their peers throughout the district are accessing the curriculum virtually five days a week because our buildings are not ready to handle the entire student body yet.

[John Falco]: For many students, the schools are a safe place.

[John Falco]: They get their food on a daily basis from the Metropolitan Public Schools.

[John Falco]: The emotional support, the health services that they might not actually have at home.

[John Falco]: And I know that the custodians and the buildings and grounds people at the schools have been working really hard.

[John Falco]: And I know the teachers have had the literally Herculean task of trying to teach virtually each day.

[John Falco]: And that's not easy, and they've had that task.

[John Falco]: We've appropriated the money.

[John Falco]: I think it's time that we get some sort of an update.

[John Falco]: It's been almost two months.

[John Falco]: And I know I did have an opportunity to review some of the air quality reports.

[John Falco]: And it looks like they've made some progress at, I believe, the elementary schools, which is promising.

[John Falco]: And to that I say thank you.

[John Falco]: But I know that there's, it seems to me when I did a quick analysis of the reports that there are, I know I have numerous questions regarding Medford High School and the vocational school.

[John Falco]: And I know David Murphy from the, I believe he's the new superintendent of finance on the school side, is actually on the call tonight.

[John Falco]: And I thank him for joining us.

[John Falco]: And I believe he's new, so I also welcome him to the Met with Public Schools.

[John Falco]: So if he could just give us an update with regards to what they're doing with regard to the funds that we sent.

[John Falco]: Give us a progress update as to what's happening.

[John Falco]: I have some further questions, but I'd love to hear an update from him.

[John Falco]: If you could please unmute him, that would be great.

[John Falco]: Yes, thank you.

[John Falco]: If I may continue.

[John Falco]: As far as the reports go, I've received many calls from parents

[John Falco]: basically asking where can they access the reports?

[John Falco]: Now you said they're online.

[John Falco]: Can you, I'm not sure if you're able to, and I don't mean to fine tune this to death, but I mean, as far as, are you able to share your screen and show us where these reports are?

[John Falco]: Because I've received numerous calls from parents and they can't find them.

[John Falco]: Um, so, okay.

[John Falco]: Because I've received numerous calls from, uh, from parents saying they can't find their reports.

[John Falco]: They want to see the reports and you know,

[John Falco]: To me, this process really, really needs to be transparent.

[John Falco]: And I know that word's used a lot, but this here needs to be transparent.

[John Falco]: I mean, we're talking about the health and the safety of our children, of our teachers, our students, our staff.

[John Falco]: I mean, we need to make sure that this stuff is out there so people can see it, and they can access it, and they can make their own decisions and ask educated questions.

[John Falco]: You know, because this is just important.

[John Falco]: I mean, this is important now more than ever.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: So I have some further questions.

[John Falco]: Sure.

[John Falco]: So when I look at the reports, and I did actually see some of the school committee meeting last night, I noticed I think one of your priorities, which I think is good, is that the vocational school goes back to school sooner than later, especially because the seniors are nearing the end of their, before they graduate, they need to make sure that they're ready to graduate and they're certified to do things they can do and whatnot.

[John Falco]: But when I look at the reports, it looks like the vocational school, if I'm reading this correctly,

[John Falco]: It looks like it hasn't been tested yet.

[John Falco]: Is that true?

[John Falco]: Thank you, I appreciate that.

[John Falco]: So when I look at the, so I know there were reports that came out previously.

[John Falco]: I believe it was maybe mid-September.

[John Falco]: And when I looked at the reports, I believe mid-September, I don't think at that time the vocational school was tested.

[John Falco]: I don't think that the Karen Theater was tested.

[John Falco]: And I don't think any of the three cafeterias at Medford High School were tested either.

[John Falco]: When I look at this report here, the most recent one, it looks like that the, like we said earlier, it didn't look like the vocational school was tested.

[John Falco]: It looks like the Caron Theater was tested, but it still doesn't look like any of the cafeterias were tested.

[John Falco]: Can you confirm that?

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Mr. Murphy, so I'm going to go back to the Caron Theater here.

[John Falco]: So when I look at my report, to me I'm looking at this and it says the required ACH is 4.0 for the Caron Theater and the actual ACH is 2.97.

[John Falco]: So therefore it fails.

[John Falco]: Now, I'm under the impression that that space is still being rented every Sunday.

[John Falco]: have the people that are renting that building have they been notified that they're in a building where the equality is not really up to par.

[John Falco]: When I look at my calendar, okay, it says that these reports were issued on the 20th of October.

[John Falco]: So if they were issued on the 20th of October, that means that last weekend, the district knew that the county theater failed, it's the equality, but yet there were still people in the building, utilizing the building, renting the building.

[John Falco]: I mean, is the city negligible for something like that?

[John Falco]: And to me, it doesn't seem we're putting health first.

[John Falco]: We're still allowing people to rent the building that maybe technically shouldn't be rented.

[John Falco]: So when you say there's additional, so you're saying that they added HEPA filters to the counter theaters?

[John Falco]: So now the HEPA filters that are there, has the data been tested since the HEPA filters have been added?

[John Falco]: So as far as the, I know it's the local church is actually renting the space.

[John Falco]: Have they been notified?

[John Falco]: Have they asked any questions as to whether or not the building is safe or ready to be used?

[John Falco]: So we have not reached out to them.

[John Falco]: The school system has not reached out to them at any point in time.

[John Falco]: And we haven't communicated with them anything from MPS?

[John Falco]: To me, I would think that the equality is something that should be communicated, but that's just me.

[John Falco]: Moving on to the cafeterias.

[John Falco]: The cafeterias haven't been tested.

[John Falco]: Where are students eating during the day?

[John Falco]: There are students in the building.

[John Falco]: Could you please comment on that?

[John Falco]: So I mean, as we move forward, it is New England, it's getting colder.

[John Falco]: So I would imagine even when it starts to rain or snow, eating outside is no longer going to be an option.

[John Falco]: So as far as eating in the cafeteria, we're putting in HEPA filters, which are great, and I'm sure that's going to improve the situation.

[John Falco]: But how do we know that if the cafeterias have not been tested yet, how do we know that we're putting enough HEPA filters in?

[John Falco]: I mean, to me as a parent, that's a concern.

[John Falco]: I feel like it's a gamble.

[John Falco]: Well, we'll throw three or four and hopefully it does the job.

[John Falco]: I mean, you know, parents deserve answers to these questions.

[John Falco]: And I feel like, you know, and I understand it and you're frustrated.

[John Falco]: I think everyone's frustrated with it, but you know, we deserve answers.

[John Falco]: And I feel like, you know what?

[John Falco]: So a lot of these questions really, I feel like we're guessing at, you know, with regard to the answers.

[John Falco]: And the cafeteria is going to be tested at some point?

[John Falco]: I mean, when I look at my report, unless I'm missing it, I don't think I see the cafeteria.

[John Falco]: So as far as, so as I moved to the report, I also noticed that,

[John Falco]: the nurse, the nurse's office, that from what I can tell, if I look at this report, it looks like it doesn't look like any of that space passed.

[John Falco]: Am I correct?

[John Falco]: You are correct.

[John Falco]: And have those rooms been retested with HEPA filters?

[John Falco]: Do you think we should be retesting the nurse's office?

[John Falco]: bathroom safe at the high school?

[John Falco]: Did you say many?

[John Falco]: Am I correct in saying that most of the space that's being utilized now by the students that are actually going to Medford High School are in the science wing?

[John Falco]: If I can ask you a question going back to the beginning, why were the buildings tested so late?

[John Falco]: The very beginning, we knew this was an airborne illness back in April, back in April of this year.

[John Falco]: And I don't think anyone came in to test anything until August.

[John Falco]: That's not a formula for success, that's just too late.

[John Falco]: I mean, there are other school districts throughout the commonwealth that are back to school and they might not have their buildings at full capacity, but they're able to utilize their buildings.

[John Falco]: I would think that if we're out front, we started testing in the springtime.

[John Falco]: You know, when a lot of these companies probably had more capacity to, you know, give us more resources, we probably wouldn't have the opportunity to maybe get in front of this and actually, you know, get our kids into school if their parents are okay with that.

[John Falco]: So can you tell us a little bit about why this started so late?

[John Falco]: And this might even, this might even, this I think actually predates you, but if you could please answer that question.

[John Falco]: If I may, does the, does the board of health have any type of input as to, you know, the cafeterias being tested or not being tested, the bathrooms, that type of thing?

[John Falco]: I mean, have they, have they given any input during this whole process?

[John Falco]: I still think at the end of the day, when you look at the cafeterias, I mean, I know you're talking about a formula, but I would think that these things need to be retested at some point in time.

[John Falco]: You know, as a parent, you want the, you know, the comfort of knowing, okay, you know what, they tested it, they retested it, it's finally up to the point where it passes.

[John Falco]: And I feel like, you know, I know you're saying, well, they have a formula and it shouldn't pass once we have these HEPA filters in, but I would think that, you know, I mean,

[John Falco]: You want to retest after the HEPA filters to get the comfort knowing, OK, you've got a good reading.

[John Falco]: We're ready to go.

[John Falco]: We can put our kids back in the classroom or back in the cafeteria or back in the Vogue, wherever it is.

[John Falco]: But I would think that there needs to be retesting at the end of the day.

[John Falco]: I mean, I just, I know at the end of the day, as a parent, I want to make sure that the buildings are safe for my kids to go to school and for everyone's kids to go to school.

[John Falco]: And I like to see numbers.

[John Falco]: I like to see metrics.

[John Falco]: I like to see that the testing is being done and that these areas are actually passing the test.

[John Falco]: That means a lot to me.

[John Falco]: I mean, I don't want to just assume that, you know what, they've worked a formula and it looks like you're going to be able to eat lunch today and be safe.

[John Falco]: And I don't think the option should be in February eating on a snowbank because you've got to eat outside.

[John Falco]: I mean, we need to make sure that these buildings are tested, the air quality's there, it's at where it should be.

[John Falco]: And that as parents and as residents and as taxpayers, people feel safe about the buildings.

[John Falco]: Okay so we'll say it's we'll say they're just not ready.

[John Falco]: As far as the HEPA filters go, do you have enough HEPA filters for the high school and all the other schools?

[John Falco]: I mean, I have a concern that we're going to be just rolling these things around in and out of rooms.

[John Falco]: Is the goal to basically have fresh air without opening a window?

[John Falco]: As far as the, can you say with any confidence that kids will be back

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Mrs. Reynolds, long time resident of Fulton Heights, passed away recently, 95 years old, and good friends with a number of her family.

[John Falco]: And just thoughts and prayers go to her family, so thank you.

[John Falco]: And I did actually drive by and take a look at this myself.

[John Falco]: This is, I guess, a storm drain that's been in disrepair for a number of years.

[John Falco]: And there's an orange cone there planted on top of it, but it really needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings of real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the city clerk, ahertubise, that will be A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E, at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: Let's see, motions, orders, and resolutions.

[John Falco]: So on the motion of Council of Bears to table this matter, seconded by.

[John Falco]: Does this motion have a second?

[John Falco]: Okay, seeing and hearing none.

[John Falco]: This does not have a second, so it cannot be tabled.

[John Falco]: Would anybody else like to speak on this matter?

[John Falco]: Okay, if I may, before we go any further, if my colleagues would not mind me speaking on this, I'd like to thank Councilor Marks for bringing this forward, especially in the interest of clarity and transparency.

[John Falco]: I'd just like to mention that the role of the Council President

[John Falco]: has taken on more responsibilities than ever before, especially over the past year during this pandemic.

[John Falco]: And while I have very much enjoyed my two terms as council president and take a great deal of pride in fulfilling this role, I have decided not to pursue the presidency for another term.

[John Falco]: I look forward to returning to the floor as an active participant, which will enable me to pursue the issues that mean a lot to our community,

[John Falco]: And I look forward to working with the next Council President, whoever he or she may be.

[John Falco]: So I just wanted to make that statement so everyone knows.

[John Falco]: And if they decide that they want to pursue the presidency, they absolutely can and should.

[John Falco]: So on the motion of Council of Marks, seconded by Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: 20606, October 8th, 2020, to Brianna Lugo, current mayor, from Kimberly M. Scanlon, city solicitor, regarding council paper 20-476.

[John Falco]: Dear Mayor Lungo-Koehn, on October 8th, 2020, the Medford City Council have made a request to include a 3% tax in the draft Cannabis Advisory Committee Ordinance.

[John Falco]: However, since General Law Chapter 64N, Section 3 is a local option statute, the preferred method is for the Council to accept the provisions of the statute pursuant to General Law Chapter 4, Section 4.

[John Falco]: For convenience purposes, I have included the following format below.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the City of Medford, through its City Council, accept the provisions of General Law, Chapter 64N, Section 3, and impose a local excise tax on the sale or transfer of marijuana products for adult use to anyone other than a marijuana establishment at a rate of 3%.

[John Falco]: Respectfully submitted, Kimberly M. Scanlon, City Solicitor.

[John Falco]: The 29th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Oh, actually, let me read the notice first.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted.

[John Falco]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email

[John Falco]: City Clerk, Adam Hertubise at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Scarpelli to suspend the rules, seconded by Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hertubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[John Falco]: The rules are suspended.

[John Falco]: Petitions, presentations, and similar papers.

[John Falco]: 20-598, petition for comment, vigil, and license by Clodian Quirazi, 94 Birch Street, Peabody, Massachusetts, 01960 for Helen's Roast Beef.

[John Falco]: and Pizzeria 321A, Boston Ave, Medford, Massachusetts 02155.

[John Falco]: On file is a business certificate number 175, building department, fire department, police traffic impact, health department, letter of compliance, state tax ID, workman's compensation, petition, and treasurer.

[John Falco]: At this point, I recognize the chairperson of licensing, Councilor Schakopiela.

[John Falco]: I believe he is, yes.

[John Falco]: Clodion, I'm going to unmute you.

[John Falco]: Clodion, if we could please have your name and address for the record.

[John Falco]: I'm trying to get him to turn it on.

[John Falco]: If I may for one minute, we're trying to work on some technical issues.

[John Falco]: So I'm going to try to see if we can get the volume turned up here in the chambers.

[John Falco]: So if you could please allow us just two quick minutes.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: He's present.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members of the President at this time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: If I may, I just have to read a quick note.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and general guidelines.

[John Falco]: For remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: And the motion of Vice President Caraviello to suspend the rule is seconded by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Seven to nothing, the rules are suspended.

[John Falco]: 20-587, October 1st, 2020, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding COVID-19 monthly update.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President, members of the City Council, in response to the Council's request for monthly COVID-19 updates from the administration, Medford Board of Health Director, Marian O'Connor, will be present at the regular City Council meeting scheduled for Tuesday, October 6th, 2020, to provide an update

[John Falco]: to provide an update on the city's response to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: The latest community data and other relevant data and information as available.

[John Falco]: The updates Mary Ann or designee will provide include but are not limited to.

[John Falco]: Latest positivity rate.

[John Falco]: Currently we are posting case numbers daily to www.medfordma.org slash coronavirus dash information, as well as state data on a weekly basis and full breakdowns of positivity and death rates by race and ethnicity on a monthly basis.

[John Falco]: We can answer additional questions regarding this data, our stage designated color code and what the data means for our reopening plans in Medford.

[John Falco]: Tufts University updates.

[John Falco]: We can break down the university's public dashboard with positivity rates, tests completed to date, and answer any questions regarding Tufts-specific COVID-19 plans.

[John Falco]: Reopening plans and related information.

[John Falco]: Of particular interest for October, the state has announced that cities and towns may proceed to phase three, step two, as of October 5th.

[John Falco]: as long as the community is not in the red category.

[John Falco]: We can provide information about Method Step 2 plans and protocols.

[John Falco]: Additional updates and information as necessary and available, we will provide updates on programs and resources like the city's RUOK program for seniors, upcoming flu vaccine clinics, and using these to prepare the potential future COVID-19 vaccine clinics, updates on nursing home data and schools and other information.

[John Falco]: Marianne or another member of my team will be available to the first city council meeting each month to provide these updates as requested, and we will answer any additional questions you may have.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[John Falco]: On the B paper offered by Vice President Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight, Clerk Urnavis, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Be it ordained by the Medford City Council that the revised ordinances of the city of Medford, as most recently amended, is hereby further amended by changing the language of chapter 74.

[John Falco]: Streets, sidewalks, and other public places, article three, sidewalks, section 74-114, entitled Removal of Snow and Ice.

[John Falco]: said section presently states section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[John Falco]: A, whenever the sidewalk or any part of the sidewalk adjoining any building or a lot of land of any street is encumbered with ice and snow, it shall be the duty of the tenant or occupant and in case there should be no tenant or occupant of the whole of such building a lot of land, it shall be the duty of the owner

[John Falco]: with a person having care of the sidewalk or to cause such sidewalk to have been made safe, convenient for public use or travel by removing the ice or snow or by covering the area with sand or some other suitable substance.

[John Falco]: In case such tenant, occupant, owner, or other person shall neglect to do so for the space of six hours during the daytime, he shall forfeit and pay the sum of $25 for the first events

[John Falco]: 50 for each successive date that the sidewalk shall continue to be encumbered.

[John Falco]: B, any person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[John Falco]: The fine for violation of this section shall be for the first offense $50, for the second offense and subsequent offenses $100.

[John Falco]: The language of said section 74-14 shall hereby be amended to read as follows.

[John Falco]: Section 74-114, removal of snow and ice.

[John Falco]: A, whenever snow or ice accumulates on a sidewalk, the owner of any land or building abutting a sidewalk or walking path shall remove the snow and ice to permit safe passage for pedestrians on the sidewalk abutting the owner's property and the entrance to the pedestrian crossing abutting the sidewalk.

[John Falco]: The owner shall also remove snow at a fire hydrant within or abutting the sidewalk that abuts the owner's property sufficient to

[John Falco]: allow fire department access to the hydrant.

[John Falco]: The owner shall remove the snow or ice or treat the sidewalk with sand or any other suitable material to permit safe passage to pedestrians.

[John Falco]: The owner shall remove snow and ice within six daylight hours after the snow stops falling and the city may extend the deadline set forth above in its discretion.

[John Falco]: The city's code enforcement officer or his designee or the police department shall notify the owner of the failure to comply and allow the owner 24 hours to comply.

[John Falco]: For residential properties, if the owner does not comply within 24 hours of receiving notice, the city may in its discretion remove.

[John Falco]: removal as a lien on the owner's property tax to fine the owner $50 per day until the owner complies.

[John Falco]: For such subsequent offense within 12 months, the fine or charge shall double.

[John Falco]: For commercial properties, if the owner does not comply within 24 hours of the receiving notice, the city may, in its discretion, remove the snow or ice and charge the owner for the removal as a lien on the owner's property tax bill

[John Falco]: will fine the owner $100 per day until the owner complies.

[John Falco]: For each subsequent offense within 12 months, the fine or charge shall double.

[John Falco]: B, a person shall not throw or put or cause to be thrown or put any snow or ice into any street in the city.

[John Falco]: The fine for violation of this section shall be, for residential property owners, $50 for the first offense, $100 for the second offense and subsequent offenses.

[John Falco]: The fine for commercial property owners, $100 for the first offense and $200 for the second offense and subsequent offenses.

[John Falco]: Okay, on the motion of Council, we ask to refer this to the Public Works Subcommittee, seconded by Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: So this is going to, was it Public Works?

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears?

[John Falco]: Public Works subcommittee, yep.

[John Falco]: I don't have my sheet in front of me yet.

[John Falco]: So that would be.

[John Falco]: Public Works, yes.

[John Falco]: Oh, yes.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information, and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom, please email the clerk, Adam Herdebes at A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E at MedfordMA.gov.

[John Falco]: That's Medford-MA.gov.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to the approximately 60 feet of gas main in one service located in Medford that is part of the larger project described in the GOL documents as follows.

[John Falco]: To install and maintain approximately 650 feet of a new 4-inch plastic main extension from the existing 4-inch plastic main in Williams Street going on to Broadway and to the service location in Medford Street.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DigSafe.

[John Falco]: It shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: Medford Street was rebuilt within the last five.

[John Falco]: years and is restricted from receiving a SOP without direct approval from the Commissioner of Public Works.

[John Falco]: At a minimum, the SOP application must include a street restoration plan for review and approval.

[John Falco]: At a minimum, the street restoration plan must include curb-to-curb paving.

[John Falco]: The SOP application must also include a traffic management plan.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: The National Grid shall ensure that all sewer water and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[John Falco]: There are multiple broken concrete panels clustered at the vicinity of the point of entry for the gas service.

[John Falco]: This cluster should be replaced as part of the project.

[John Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements of the approved street opening permit.

[John Falco]: Number five, pavement markings including the hatch pattern must be restored.

[John Falco]: Number six, the project site must be swept daily.

[John Falco]: It shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Okay, thank you.

[John Falco]: So this here project has been approved by our city engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: I'm just going to read the conditions, then I know a number of councilors have questions, and there are quite a few conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineer division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: These conditions include minor revisions to vault locations and conduit runs.

[John Falco]: Prior to issuance of a street opening permit, Comcast must submit a revised plan with the city clerk and engineering division for record.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to the conduit, vaults, handholds, and service conduit as described in the petition.

[John Falco]: High Street, starting at the existing conduit located in front of number 84 High Street, excavating to place two

[John Falco]: Let's see, four-inch PVC conduits, 1,094 plus or minus, and two three-by-three manholes in nine two-by-three vaults.

[John Falco]: Bradley Road, starting at the proposed manhole and the sidewalk, excavating place two.

[John Falco]: 4-inch PVC conduits, 170 foot plus or minus to utility pole number 5516-1.

[John Falco]: Main Street, starting at the proposed vault number 9.

[John Falco]: On High Street, excavating to place 2.

[John Falco]: 4-inch PVC conduits, 115 feet plus or minus to proposed vault number 10.

[John Falco]: Continuing.

[John Falco]: From vault number 10 excavating to place one four inch PVC conduit, 155 feet, to number 32 Main Street, Riverside Avenue.

[John Falco]: Starting at proposed vault number 10 on Main Street, excavating to place two four inch PVC conduits, 240 feet, plus or minus to number one, Salem Street.

[John Falco]: And proposing to place a two by three vault,

[John Falco]: over the existing conduit located in the sidewalk.

[John Falco]: Number two, the plan indicates that conflicts with other utilities may result in a change in location of conduits and structures.

[John Falco]: Changes in locations of conduit runs or structures by more than two feet requires the approval of a revised G.O.L.

[John Falco]: Changes to structure locations less than two feet must be approved by the city engineer.

[John Falco]: The note on the plan must be revised to indicate this information.

[John Falco]: Number three, before starting work, the contractor must notify dig safe and must obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: This project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: The SOP application must include a street restoration plan and traffic management plan for review and approval by the engineering division.

[John Falco]: Sea surface restoration requirements below the TMP must

[John Falco]: be prepared and stamped by a licensed professional engineer and must include accommodations for pedestrians, bicycles, and vehicles.

[John Falco]: Number four, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: Comcast must ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Number five, Comcast must submit a project

[John Falco]: schedule and sequence plan to the engineering division for review and approval.

[John Falco]: The project shall be limited to one crew.

[John Falco]: Number six, sections of work may be required to take place at night due to daytime traffic volumes.

[John Falco]: This must be coordinated with the Medford Police Department to minimize disruptions in traffic.

[John Falco]: in the interest of public safety.

[John Falco]: Number seven, Comcast must submit the communications and notification plan to the mayor's office for review and approval.

[John Falco]: It must include timely notifications to impacted business and residents.

[John Falco]: Number eight, the plan indicates a riverfront area jurisdictional line.

[John Falco]: Comcast must review this line in consultation with the Medford Conservation Commission.

[John Falco]: Riverfront areas are wetland resources and are under the jurisdiction of the Medford Conservation Commission.

[John Falco]: If an order of conditions is required, it must be issued prior to the release of ASOP.

[John Falco]: Nine, copies of the MWRA 8M permit must be submitted to the engineering division with the SOP application.

[John Falco]: Ten, Comcast may have abandoned utilities in Medford.

[John Falco]: A map showing the location of Comcast abandoned utilities in Medford must be submitted to the engineering division for record.

[John Falco]: Number 11, as part of the City of Medford COVID-19 emergency response, there are Jersey barriers set up on High Street and outdoor dining space.

[John Falco]: If any of these barriers must be temporarily removed, this work must be coordinated with the associated restaurants to take place at a time that minimizes impact to these restaurants.

[John Falco]: If this work must take place during business hours, there must be paid restitution.

[John Falco]: Number 12,

[John Falco]: The contractor must submit a COVID-19 work safety plan with the SOP application.

[John Falco]: The plan is subject to approval by the Board of Health and must be approved before the release of the permit.

[John Falco]: Number 13, the sidewalk and street restoration must be done in consultation with the engineering division in per the requirements of the approved SOP.

[John Falco]: Cement concrete sidewalks must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints to extend

[John Falco]: To extents described below, the bituminous concrete pavement over the trench must be milled and overlaid.

[John Falco]: In the extents described below and approved by the engineering division, the brick-stamped cement concrete edging shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: A, in general, sidewalk replacements must include panels from

[John Falco]: Curb to back of existing sidewalk or right of way line.

[John Falco]: Expansion joints must be placed at several intervals less than or equal to 30 feet.

[John Falco]: Less than or equal to 30 feet.

[John Falco]: Control joints must be placed to best meet and match existing conditions at the intervals no greater than six feet.

[John Falco]: Hybrids, utility poles, and driveway aprons must receive expansion joints to isolate.

[John Falco]: All joints must meet ADA requirements.

[John Falco]: B, Riverside Avenue must be resurfaced curb to curb to an offset of at least, to an offset at least 10 feet.

[John Falco]: to the eastern trench limits.

[John Falco]: C, there are at least two monitoring wells in the east gutter of Main Street near the intersection of Riverside Avenue.

[John Falco]: These wells are related to a remediation project and must be protected.

[John Falco]: The location in the gutter also conflicts with the granite curb concrete backing.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the run of conduit be placed in the sidewalk to avoid these wells and to avoid undermining the curbing.

[John Falco]: D, the trench surface restoration crossing Clippership Drive must be resurfaced at an offset of at least 10 feet from the trench limits.

[John Falco]: E, the conduit on the south side of Clippership Drive must be placed beneath the sidewalk.

[John Falco]: The landscaped area is reserved for tree growth.

[John Falco]: F, the trench surface restoration crossing Main Street must be resurfaced to an offset of at least 10 feet from the trench limits.

[John Falco]: G, the trench surface restoration on High Street and Bradley Road must be curb to curb.

[John Falco]: H, Vault 9 appears to be located in a sidewalk panel that includes a portion of a pedestrian ramp that is in poor condition.

[John Falco]: The restoration must include a new pedestrian ramp that meets ADA requirements.

[John Falco]: The vault cover must be located within the ramp wings and level landings.

[John Falco]: The vault must be located within the furniture zone if possible.

[John Falco]: The pedestrian ramps at the opposite sides of the crossing must also be replaced and meet ADA requirements.

[John Falco]: I, a sidewalk panel adjacent to vault 8 on the west side is cracked.

[John Falco]: It must be replaced.

[John Falco]: The asphalt patch adjacent to the cracked panel must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[John Falco]: J, vault 6 is located in an existing asphalt patch.

[John Falco]: The asphalt must be replaced with cement concrete.

[John Falco]: The cement concrete panels adjacent to the location are cracked and must be replaced.

[John Falco]: K, manhole 2, an associated excavation and conduit

[John Falco]: will disturb the existing pedestrian ramp on the west side of Bradley Road.

[John Falco]: The main old cover must not be located within a ramp, wings, or level landings.

[John Falco]: The new ramp placed as part of the restoration must be ADA compliant.

[John Falco]: The pedestrian ramp at the east side of the crossing must be replaced to meet ADA requirements.

[John Falco]: L, fault five is located adjacent to an asphalt patch that must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[John Falco]: The sidewalk panels adjacent to this fault are cracked and must be replaced.

[John Falco]: M, vault four is located adjacent to the building.

[John Falco]: The vault must be relocated to the furniture zone if feasible.

[John Falco]: The adjacent asphalt patch must be replaced with cement concrete sidewalk.

[John Falco]: And vault three appears to conflict with a city trash barrel.

[John Falco]: The vault must be removed or a new trash barrel location coordinated with the DPW.

[John Falco]: The adjacent sidewalk panel at the street light in the adjacent panel near the building are cracked.

[John Falco]: It must be replaced.

[John Falco]: Vault three must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[John Falco]: O, vault 2 must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[John Falco]: P, vault 1 must be located in the furniture zone if feasible.

[John Falco]: The adjacent panel in poor condition must be replaced.

[John Falco]: Q, the surface conduit for 81 High Street passes under damaged curb.

[John Falco]: The damaged curb must not be reused.

[John Falco]: A new or good condition used vertical granite curbing that matches the existing curbing must be used for restoration.

[John Falco]: The sidewalk panels adjacent to the conduit line are cracked, it's spalling, it must be replaced.

[John Falco]: R, all pavement markings must be restored.

[John Falco]: Number 14, the project must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Number 15,

[John Falco]: While we're under suspension, to take communications from the mayor.

[John Falco]: 20-541 communications from the mayor September 3rd 2020 the electronic delivery to the Honorable President members of the Medford City Council City of Medford Massachusetts 02155 regarding the proposed ordinance historic district dear Mr. President and members of the City Council I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approved the following amendments to the City of Medford revised ordinances

[John Falco]: ordinances entitled Historic District Commission, Article 3, Section 48 through 51 as described below.

[John Falco]: The amendments clarify the ordinance to delineate the previously approved districts and at the request of the Methodist Historical District Commission, create a new single parcel historic district.

[John Falco]: at 16 Foster Court.

[John Falco]: By way of background, Section 48 through 51 presently states under the authority of Master M.G.L.A.

[John Falco]: Chapter 40, Section 3, there is hereby established a Hillside Avenue Historic District and Moms Simmons Historic District bounded as respectively shown on the map entitled Historic Avenue Historic District.

[John Falco]: and Monson's Historic District, which are on file in the city clerk's office and made part of this article by reference.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 40C, Section 3, the attached report and request has been transmitted to the Community Development Board for the concurrent review.

[John Falco]: The matter is scheduled to be taken up at the Community Development Board on September 16th, 2020.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[John Falco]: By being ordained by the City Council of the City of Medford as follows, Amendment 1, Section 48 through 51A of the Revised Ordinance, City of Medford, Massachusetts, is hereby amended to read as follows.

[John Falco]: Under the authority of MGLA Chapter 40, Section 3, the following historic districts bound respectively

[John Falco]: and which are on file in the city clerk's office and made a part of the article by reference are hereby established.

[John Falco]: Number one, Hillside Avenue Historic District.

[John Falco]: Number two, Marm Simmons Historic District Amendment.

[John Falco]: Two, section 48-51A of the revised ordinances, City of Manfred, Massachusetts, as amended in section one, is hereby further amended to read as follows.

[John Falco]: Under the authority of MGLA,

[John Falco]: Chapter 40C, Section 3, the following historic districts, bounded respectfully, and which are on file in the City Clerk's Office and made a part of this article of reference are hereby established.

[John Falco]: Number one, Hillside Avenue Historic District.

[John Falco]: Two, Marm Simmons Historic District.

[John Falco]: Three, 16 Foster Court Historic District.

[John Falco]: Method Historic District Commission and Method Historical Commission report on 16 Foster Court.

[John Falco]: We also received the communication from the, let's see, from the CD board to John C. Falco, Jr., President, Method City Council, Adam Herdeby, City Clerk, from Andre LaRue, Chairman.

[John Falco]: It's dated September 18th, 2020.

[John Falco]: regarding the proposed local historic district at the Haskell-Cutter House 16 Foster Court, Medford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: At its meeting on September 16, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to make no recommendation on the proposed local historic district at the Haskell-Cutter House 16 Foster Court, Medford.

[John Falco]: but encourages the parties involved to pursue preservation of the historic structure either on this site or another site.

[John Falco]: During the robust discussion, board members expressed their desire to work with the Historic District Commission to prioritize conservation properties for future districts, find additional ways of celebrating Medford shipbuilding history, and support a citywide evaluation of the city's historic assets.

[John Falco]: Thank you for the opportunity to review this matter.

[John Falco]: Andrew LaRue, Chairman, and the CC was to Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor, and Kimberly Scanley, the acting city solicitor.

[John Falco]: Council appears.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you console beers.

[John Falco]: Okay, so make sure Let's see there is there any any other consoles that like to speak on this matter?

[John Falco]: And this is 20-566.

[John Falco]: September 17, 2020, the electronic delivery to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding Home Rule Petition Charter Commission.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following Home Rule Petition and transmit to the General Court for their consideration.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[John Falco]: An act authorizing the election of a charter commission in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives and General Court assembled and by the authority of the same as follows.

[John Falco]: Section one, notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws of the provisions of any general law, special law or regulation to the contrary, the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: The city the city of Medford City Council shall at the first regular city regular city election or a fogging up City election or early occurring special election held

[John Falco]: On or after the 60th day following the effective date of this act, by order, provide for submission to the voters of the city the question of adopting or revising a charter and for the election of a nine member charter commission.

[John Falco]: Section two, other than as set forth herein, the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws shall be applicable to the nomination and election of charter commissioners and to the duties and responsibilities of the city and the charter commission elected here under.

[John Falco]: Section three, this act shall take effect upon its passage.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Okay, thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Notice of a public hearing, 19-481.

[John Falco]: Public hearing notice, amendment to chapter 94, zoning.

[John Falco]: Revised ordinances of the City of Medford, Medford City Council, September 22nd, 2020.

[John Falco]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on Tuesday, September 22, 2020 at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to a petition on Council Paper 19-481, Chapter 94, Zoning, Section 94-2, Definitions.

[John Falco]: Definitions is proposed to be amended to add definitions for brewery, tasting room, tap room, barrel, and brew pub.

[John Falco]: Section 94-148, table of use regulations is proposed to be amended by adding use 35B, brewery, which will be allowable by right in C2IOA.

[John Falco]: In the C1 district, breweries operating with seven barrels or under will be allowable by right.

[John Falco]: If breweries operating with more than seven barrels will be allowable by special permit board of appeals.

[John Falco]: The full text of the amendment may be viewed in the office of the city clerk, city hall, room 103, or on the city's website at http://www.methodma.org, departments, community development, by clicking on the current CD board filings.

[John Falco]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be posted no later than Friday, September 18th, 2020.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: So we did receive a paper here from the CD board.

[John Falco]: And I'm just going to read it quick so everybody can.

[John Falco]: Listen, it's from the Community Development Board to John C. Falco, Jr., President, Medford City Council, and to Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk, from Andre LaRue, Chairman, dated September 8, 2020, regarding Council Paper 20-481, proposed amendment to Chapter 94, zoning to add definitions and an additional line brewery to the table of use regulations.

[John Falco]: Following a duly advertised public hearing conducted on September 16, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to recommend that the Medford City Council adopt the proposed amendment to Chapter 94 zoning, as well as in Council Paper 20-481.

[John Falco]: Board members strongly supported the proposal to allow breweries and brew pubs to operate in the city.

[John Falco]: Furthermore, given the fact that some other breweries in the region have become social gathering spots, the board respectfully suggests including the following language to provide additional flexibility to their operations.

[John Falco]: Add the following after the last line in the definition for brewery.

[John Falco]: The facility may also provide food that is produced on site,

[John Falco]: produced off-site or produced with food trucks that are located on-site.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your consideration of this recommendation.

[John Falco]: Andrea LaRue, Chairman, and that was CC to Brianna Lungo, current Mayor, and to Kimberly Scanlon, City Solicitor, and to Paul Moki, the Building Commissioner.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made possible to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Mefford or Mefford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of Zoom,

[John Falco]: Please email ahertubise, that's A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E, at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: I've been a passenger on that 325 and the 326 for probably

[John Falco]: Probably just about 20 years now, and like Consular Marks mentioned, these bus routes have become more and more popular pre-pandemic than I've ever seen since I've been taking them.

[John Falco]: And one of my biggest concerns is when they said they were going to temporarily suspend service, that they would never bring service back.

[John Falco]: That seems to come to fruition now, and I did give Representative Donato a call today to talk specifically about this.

[John Falco]: And he basically told me the same thing he told Councilor Scarpelli, and that is that the MBTA lied to him and to the whole entire state delegation.
