[John Falco]: And that's a piece I think that's going to be.

[John Falco]: Probably we had to prove because right now ridership is low due to the pandemic.

[John Falco]: So Councilor Scarpelli, I like the idea of scheduling a subcommittee to look at this and bring in the state delegation and bring in the MBTA and ask really good solid questions.

[John Falco]: And really getting them to commit to a timetable as to when they're going to bring things back or when they're going to reevaluate.

[John Falco]: But this needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: And it needs to be addressed sooner than later.

[John Falco]: But to tell you the truth, there are some cities and towns that are meeting, actually, and having the public here as well.

[John Falco]: Now, I've been told by our city solicitor that we can't do that.

[John Falco]: Okay, the room.

[John Falco]: I do have that, and I can send that to you.

[John Falco]: But with that being said, the opinion was that the room's got 25 people in it.

[John Falco]: If 30 people show up to the meeting, we can't kick people out of the room.

[John Falco]: And therefore, we would be limiting speech and be limiting participation.

[John Falco]: So it would be a violation of the open meeting law.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: 20-537 offered by Council of Mayors, whereas residents of Medford requested that the city of Medford hang a banner stating Black Lives Matter at Medford City Hall as a statement of solidarity and support to begin to address the history of racism and discrimination in our community.

[John Falco]: And whereas the Supreme Court of the United States and Rosenberger versus Rectors and Visitors of University of Virginia established

[John Falco]: The government speech doctrine recognizing that a government entity is entitled to say what it wishes and select views it wants to express.

[John Falco]: And whereas the government speech doctrine has been affirmed and reinforced by Supreme Court decisions including but not limited to Russ versus Sullivan, Johans versus Livestock.

[John Falco]: Marketing Association, Pleasant Grove City v. Summum, Walker v. Texas Division, Sons of Confederate Veterans and Matal v. TAM, and whereas placing a banner on Medford City Hall meets the multi-factor test defined in Summum and Walker of, number one, historic use of building

[John Falco]: including banners to convey government messages, two, the public's close identification of messages and signage placed on Medford City Hall with the city government, and three, the city of Medford's maintenance of effective control over the messages conveyed, and whereas in 2018 the U.S.

[John Falco]: District Court for the District of Massachusetts in Shirtland versus the City of Boston denied the request for injunction

[John Falco]: of a plaintiff requesting the flying of a specific flag on Boston City Hall using the government speech doctrine and multi-factor test defined in Summum and Walker.

[John Falco]: And whereas in 2019, the U.S.

[John Falco]: Court of Appeals for the First Circuit affirmed the decision of District Court of Shurtleff with a three-judge panel deciding unanimously to reject the plaintiff's appeal.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore,

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council, that the city administration provide a summary explanation of the opinion regarding banners on Medford City Hall and how it is possible that such an opinion can ignore the U.S.

[John Falco]: Constitution's government speech doctrine as decided and affirmed by decades of precedent of the Supreme Court of the United States.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: So this same resolution has been offered two weeks in a row.

[John Falco]: So when the council rules, I have to rule this out of order because it has been two weeks in a row.

[John Falco]: This is verbatim, the same exact resolution as a prior meeting.

[John Falco]: Now, so with that being said, the matter basically has already been disposed of because I was ruled out of order in the previous week.

[John Falco]: There was a doubting of the chair.

[John Falco]: But with that being said, what I did do today is I made a phone call to Chief of Staff Rodriguez.

[John Falco]: And he was busy all day meeting, so I did have a conversation with the mayor regarding this very issue.

[John Falco]: So what I wanted to let you know is during our conversation, what she said is the response is on the way, and that the council should receive it within the next few days.

[John Falco]: She also went out to say that the administration is also working on a policy with regard to banners.

[John Falco]: There's no timeline on that, but there is a policy that they are working on.

[John Falco]: But she said that we will be getting a response, because we haven't received an official response.

[John Falco]: But we will be getting that in the next few days, okay?

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: 20-53, an offer by Councilor- Can I ask why it's taking a month?

[John Falco]: Yeah.

[John Falco]: Yeah, the paper's out of order.

[John Falco]: I do not know why the administration's taking as long as it's taking, but that is what I was told and I wanted to pass that information on to my colleagues.

[John Falco]: I would agree, but you know.

[John Falco]: The electronic delivery to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding the proposed ordinance historic district.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President.

[John Falco]: and members of the city council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following amendments to the city of Medford revised ordinances entitled historic district commission, article three, section 48 through 51 as described below.

[John Falco]: The amendments clarify the ordinance to delineate the previously approved districts and at the request of the method historic district commission create new single parcel district at 16 Foster court.

[John Falco]: By way of background, section 48-51A presently states, under the authority of Mass General MGLA C40 section 3, there is a hereby established Hillside Avenue Historic District and Marm Simmons Historic District.

[John Falco]: bounded as respectively shown on the map entitled Historic Avenue Historic District in Marm-Simons Historic District, which are on file in the city clerk's office and made part of this article by reference.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 40C, Section 3, the attached report and request has been transmitted to the Community Development Board for their concurrent review.

[John Falco]: The matter is scheduled to be taken up by the Community Development Board on September 16th, 2020.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Okay, I just wanted to,

[John Falco]: just make a quick statement regarding these meetings here.

[John Falco]: So last week we had a Committee of the Whole meeting at City Council Chambers, and the public was able to access the meeting via Zoom.

[John Falco]: Tonight, the council members are back home, accessing the meeting via Zoom.

[John Falco]: The reason why we are doing this from home tonight is we have early voting this week in City Hall, and I know Clerk Hurtubise has been working hard at that since Saturday.

[John Falco]: I know that's been taking up most of his time.

[John Falco]: They have the tabulation machines behind the rails and they would have to move everything.

[John Falco]: So this should be, uh, hopefully the last time that the council has to log in from their homes and we can do it, uh, in council chambers.

[John Falco]: The council can meet in council chambers going forward.

[John Falco]: Uh, and so that is the plan, but I just wanted to explain that before we get started.

[John Falco]: 20-507 offered by Councilor Bears, whereas residents of Medford requested that the

[John Falco]: City of Medford hang a banner stating Black Lives Matter at Medford City Hall as a statement of solidarity and support to begin to address the history of racism and discrimination in our community.

[John Falco]: Point of information, Mr. President?

[John Falco]: Point of information, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: So rule 21 would be that it doesn't come up for another 90 days, I believe?

[John Falco]: If I may, I'm going to read the rest of this, okay?

[John Falco]: And then we'll go from there, okay?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: And I do not think it is out of order because I think this is different from the original resolution was asking for a banner.

[John Falco]: This is asking for an opinion.

[John Falco]: The policy was asked what the policy was.

[John Falco]: This here is asking for an opinion.

[John Falco]: So that's why I don't think that this is, to me, this is not a, doesn't come out of rule 21.

[John Falco]: That's my, that's how I feel as the chair.

[John Falco]: I was going to, well, I told you how I feel.

[John Falco]: I was going to read it in.

[John Falco]: I have questions myself, to be honest with you, but I was going to read it in and take it from there.

[John Falco]: Yes, that's that's fine.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Whereas the Supreme Court of the United States in Rosenberger versus rectors and visitors of University of Virginia established the government speech doctor recognizing that a government entity is entitled to say what it wishes and select views it wants to express and whereas the government

[John Falco]: speech doctrine has been affirmed and reinforced by Supreme Court decisions including but not limited to Russ v. Sullivan, Johans v. Livestock Marketing Association, Pleasant Grove City v. Summum Walker v. Texas, Division Sons of Confederate Veterans, and

[John Falco]: Mattel versus Tan, and whereas placing a banner on Medford City Hall meets the multi-factor test defined in Summum and Walker of historic use of the building, including banners to convey government messages to the public's, number two, the public's close identification of messages and signage placed on Medford City Hall with the city government and

[John Falco]: Number three, the City of Medford's maintenance of effective control over the messages conveyed, and whereas in 2018 the U.S.

[John Falco]: District Court for the District of Massachusetts in Shurtleff versus City of Boston denied the request for injunction of a plaintiff requesting the flag of a specific flag

[John Falco]: at Boston City Hall using the government speech doctrine in multi-factor test defined in Summum and Walker, and whereas in 2019, the US Court of Appeals for the First Circuit affirmed the decision of the District Court in Shurtleff with a three-judge panel deciding unanimously to reject the plaintiff's appeal.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the city administration provide a summary explanation of the opinion

[John Falco]: regarding banners on Method City Hall and how it is possible that such an opinion can ignore the U.S.

[John Falco]: Constitution's government speech doctrine as deemed and affirmed by decades of precedent of the Supreme Court of the United States.

[John Falco]: So with that being said, Councilor Bears, if I may, when I read this, the last sentence, be it resolved that the Method City Council, that the city administration provide a summary explanation of the opinion

[John Falco]: I incorrectly if I'm wrong, I checked with the clerk.

[John Falco]: Do we receive an opinion back from the administration on this?

[John Falco]: 2-0-5-2-0, offered by Council of Mayors, whereas the U.S.

[John Falco]: Census Bureau is required by the U.S.

[John Falco]: Constitution to conduct a count of the population every 10 years, and this count provides a historic opportunity to help shape the foundation of our society and play an active role in American democracy.

[John Falco]: And whereas, Medford is committed to ensuring every resident is counted and

[John Falco]: Whereas method includes many hard-to-count communities, which are those that face barriers to full and equitable representation in the data collection process, and that traditionally we have undercounted, and whereas the Trump administration recently decreased the time to respond to the census, it instituted a new deadline of September 30th, 2020, endangering a complete count, and whereas census data plays an important role in the allocation of federal and state funding,

[John Falco]: the determination of representation and redistricting in a full capacity for economic and social science research, and whereas the information collected by the census is confidential and protected by law, now therefore be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the city is committed to partnering with the US Census Bureau and Commonwealth of Massachusetts to achieve a complete and accurate count of all persons within our borders.

[John Falco]: Be it further resolved that the Medford City Council supports the goals and ideals for the 2020 census and will disseminate 2020 census information, encourages all residents to fill out the 2020 census before September 30, 2020, encourages all residents to participate in events and initiatives that will raise the overall awareness of the 2020 census and increase participation and support partnership specialists, census takers,

[John Falco]: and other U.S.

[John Falco]: Census Bureau staff as they help our community complete and accurate counts.

[John Falco]: The 24th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: I am present.

[John Falco]: All seven members are present.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: This is being broadcast live on channel 22 for Comcast and channel 43 on Verizon.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18 and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing

[John Falco]: strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: I want to thank everyone for attending tonight.

[John Falco]: We have a number of hearings tonight.

[John Falco]: Hearings 20-381.

[John Falco]: This is a notice of a public hearing, legal notice, City of Medford, Massachusetts, Medford City Council Chapter 94 zoning.

[John Falco]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on Tuesday, July 28, 2020 at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: via Zoom remote videoconferencing relative to the petition by Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn to amend Chapter 94 Zoning, Chapter 94-148D, Table of Use Regulation for Use 18, multiple dwelling not over three stories in height, in Use 19, multiple dwelling not over 75 feet or six stories in height.

[John Falco]: Will use 18 or 19 is presently allowed by right, yes.

[John Falco]: The proposed amendment would require a special permit from the city council, SPC, requiring that at least 25% of the total gross floor area of the development contain non-residential uses permitted by right, of which are authorized pursuant to a special permit in the underlying zoning district where relevant overlying zoning

[John Falco]: where relevant overlying zoning districts.

[John Falco]: As drafted, the amendment would take effect in the APT-1, APT-2, APT-3, and C-1 in MUZ zoning districts.

[John Falco]: The full text of the amendment may be viewed in the office of the city clerk at Medford City Hall, room 103, or the city's website at http://www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: slash community development by clicking on the current CD board filings.

[John Falco]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be posted no later than July 24, 2020.

[John Falco]: So at this point in time, I would declare the, actually, if I may, this paper did go to the, actually,

[John Falco]: Let me just read the rest of this, if you could give me a second.

[John Falco]: To participate remotely outside of the virtual platform, questions and comments may be submitted via email to ahertubise, that's A-H-U-R-T-U-B-I-S-E, at medford-ma.gov.

[John Falco]: For accommodations, call 781-393-2425.

[John Falco]: TTY 7813932516 pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18 and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place

[John Falco]: This hearing of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained

[John Falco]: contained to be posted not later than July 24, 2020, no in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Meeting website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: By order of the Medford City Council, Adam L. Hurtubise, City Clerk, this was advertised in the Boston Globe July 13th and July 20th, 2020.

[John Falco]: We also have received correspondence from Andre LaRue, who's the chair of the CD board.

[John Falco]: That's dated July 20th, 2020.

[John Falco]: And I'm going to read that now, that's regarding Council Resolution 20-381, Proposed Amendment to Chapter 94 Zoning, Section 94-148D, Table of Use Regulations for Use 18, multiple dwelling not over three stories in height and

[John Falco]: Use 19 multiple dwelling not over 75 feet or six stories in height to require at least 25% non-residential uses.

[John Falco]: Following the duly advertised public hearing conducted on June 18, 2020, in July 16, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to recommend that the Medford City Council adopt the proposed amendment

[John Falco]: In the commercial 1, C1 in mixed-use zones, MUZ zoning districts, with the following changes.

[John Falco]: For the proposed footnote to use 18 and use 19, number 3, remove the words 25% of the total floor area and replace with the first floor.

[John Falco]: Two, for the proposed footnote

[John Falco]: to use 18 and use 19.

[John Falco]: Number three, add the following language after the words overlying zoning district or business or professional office retail sales.

[John Falco]: Consumer service business or eating place as defined in section 94-2 definitions.

[John Falco]: Following considerable discussion, the Community Development Board made no recommendation on the proposed amendment to the APT

[John Falco]: apartment one in APT, apartment two zoning districts.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your consideration of these recommendations.

[John Falco]: Audrey LaRue, chair.

[John Falco]: At this point, I declare this public hearing open.

[John Falco]: Would anybody like to speak in favor?

[John Falco]: Anyone like to speak in favor of the petition?

[John Falco]: Notice of a public hearing, 20-042 legal notice, City of Medford, Massachusetts, Medford City Council, chapter 94, zoning.

[John Falco]: The Medford City Council will conduct a public hearing on Tuesday, July 28, 2020, at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: via Zoom remote video conferencing relative to a petition by the Medford City Council to amend chapter 94 zoning revised ordinances of the City of Medford to allow

[John Falco]: to allow for and regulate adult-use marijuana establishments in the city of Medford with an aim to minimize any adverse impacts that marijuana establishments may have on adjacent or nearby properties and to provide standards for placement, design, siting, safety, security, modification, and discontinuance of central establishments subject to reasonable conditions that protect public health.

[John Falco]: safety, and welfare.

[John Falco]: 20-478, notice of a public hearing.

[John Falco]: Petition for grant of location, Tufts University, Medford, Massachusetts, electrical transmission line.

[John Falco]: Medford, Massachusetts City Clerk's Office, you are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, a public hearing will be given via Zoom at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: on Tuesday, July 28th on a petition of Tufts University for permission to install an electrical transmission line beneath Boston Avenue near the intersection of College Avenue and to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across the public way herein named

[John Falco]: said poll locations to be located substantially in accordance with the revised plan marked Boston Avenue.

[John Falco]: Menford, Massachusetts will be filed in the Office of the City Clerk on June 4, 2020.

[John Falco]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be provided no later than Friday, July 24, 2020.

[John Falco]: Wherefore, it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires, together with such as standing and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary, said electrical transmission line be erected substantially in accordance with the revised plan marked Boston Ave, Medford, Massachusetts, and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 103,

[John Falco]: 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: Also, for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals, cables, and wires in the above or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles in buildings as each of said petitioners may desire for distributing purposes.

[John Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[John Falco]: Boston Avenue in the vicinity of the new power plant building

[John Falco]: near the intersection of College Avenue.

[John Falco]: Location approximately as shown on plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: This was approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineer division recommends that the grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: One, the grant of location, GOL, is limited to approximately 60 feet of electrical transmission main described in the GOL document as follows.

[John Falco]: Number two, excavation of Boston Avenue is an installation and maintenance of eight by six underground electrical conduits and wires together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as may be necessary for the transmission of electricity under and across Boston Avenue, a public way approximately 500 feet north of the center line of the intersection of Boston Avenue and College Avenue, said location request.

[John Falco]: touched athletic utility district, Medford, Massachusetts, and filled, filed in the office of the city clerk the plan.

[John Falco]: The work consists of installing approximately 55 linear feet of electrical duct bank to an electric manhole as

[John Falco]: shown on the plan and to connect to conduits of petitioner's property and property of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation.

[John Falco]: Number three, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: The SOP application must include a proposal for temporary and permanent street restoration to be considered as a condition.

[John Falco]: Please see additional comments below on street restoration.

[John Falco]: The SOP application must also include a traffic management plan.

[John Falco]: Number four, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: Tufts shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[John Falco]: Five, the sidewalk and street temporary and permit restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division and per the requirements.

[John Falco]: of an approved street opening permit.

[John Falco]: The recent resurfacing of Boston Avenue stopped short of this location due to the anticipated and ongoing construction related to both Tufts University projects and the Green Line Extension project.

[John Falco]: Also, the City of Medford intends to add a pedestrian crossing in this vicinity using funds obtained from the MBTA related to mitigation for the GLX project.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that in lieu of performing final street restoration, a contribution be negotiated and agreed upon with the city engineer that approximates the construction cost value of finished street restoration.

[John Falco]: The cost should take into consideration.

[John Falco]: in consideration roadway mill and overlay restoration with a curb-to-curb offset of 25 feet, including setting curb stones and sidewalk restoration and mill and overlay restoration encompassing Tufts University utility patches from the intersection of College Avenue to the limits of Dolan Hall.

[John Falco]: This contribution will go towards final resurfacing of this section of Boston Avenue.

[John Falco]: This will provide a consistent final pavement surface along this section of Boston Avenue.

[John Falco]: Number six, pavement markings must be restored.

[John Falco]: Number seven, the project site must be swept daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Number eight, a copy of the MWRA permit and associated plans must be submitted to the engineering division prior to releasing a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: Number nine, the plan indicates open trench construction

[John Falco]: There is existing concrete barrier structure and cable guardrail that must be removed for the installation of the transmission line.

[John Falco]: These two elements should not be replaced.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the petitioner coordinates sidewalk surface restoration with the Greenline Extension Project as there is sidewalk scope for that project on the east side of Boston Avenue.

[John Falco]: Any temporary restoration must meet accessibility standards.

[John Falco]: The sidewalk on the west side is likely to remain

[John Falco]: and should be permanently restored to concrete upon completion of the crossing.

[John Falco]: Approved by the Superintendent of Wires, call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations and or aids.

[John Falco]: Plans can be reviewed at the City Clerk's Office, 781-393-2425, Adam L. Hurtubise's City Clerk.

[John Falco]: The bollards shall remain in place.

[John Falco]: Number seven,

[John Falco]: There are multiple trees that have canopy that will be impacted by the relocation of the associated overhead wires.

[John Falco]: Protection measures for the tree roots must be coordinated with the Method DPW tree warden.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears, clerk, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes, 70 affirmative, 0 in the negative.

[John Falco]: Motion passes.

[John Falco]: The rules are suspended.

[John Falco]: And we will now take, I believe it's 20481.

[John Falco]: Am I correct, Clerk Hurtubise?

[John Falco]: Okay, so let me, this one here, I did not, I'm gonna read that now.

[John Falco]: So, notice of a public hearing, legal notice 20-481, petition for grant of location, Comcast Cable Communications Management, LLC, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's Office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, public hearing will be given via Zoom at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: on Tuesday, July 28, 2020, on a petition of Comcast Cable Communications, LLC.

[John Falco]: Yes, if you could.

[John Falco]: Is this Mr. Flewelling?

[John Falco]: If you could please give us a brief synopsis.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: So at this point, I would declare the public hearing open.

[John Falco]: Actually, before I move any further, I just wanted to note that this year has been approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that this grain of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grain of location is limited to approximately 52 feet of conduit.

[John Falco]: Proposed vault and service conduit as described in the petition.

[John Falco]: Starting at the existing Comcast vault excavating to place two four-inch PVC conduits

[John Falco]: 52 plus or minus to a proposed two-by-three vault in the sidewalk.

[John Falco]: From the newly placed vault excavating to a place one four-inch PVC conduit, three plus or minus and continue on to private property.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a

[John Falco]: Street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: At a minimum, the street opening permit application must include a street restoration plan and traffic management plan for review and approval.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: Comcast shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division in further requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[John Falco]: This must include a site inspection with the permit officer to determine the extent of pavement restoration.

[John Falco]: The concrete sidewalk must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints.

[John Falco]: The bituminous concrete pavement over the trench shall be milled and overlaid to an offset approved by the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The brick-stamped concrete edging shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Number five, pavement markings- President, if I could stop you on that point for a moment?

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Mr. Flewellen, could you comment on that, please?

[John Falco]: Number five, pavement markings must be restored.

[John Falco]: Number six, the project site must be scrubbed daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[John Falco]: Number seven, Riverside Avenue is a highly traveled roadway for vehicles as well as pedestrians.

[John Falco]: A detailed TMP must be submitted to the engineering division for review and approved prior to receiving a street opening permit.

[John Falco]: The TMP must include accommodations for pedestrians

[John Falco]: in addition to vehicles.

[John Falco]: Number eight, the plan does not indicate drain lines or laterals.

[John Falco]: Drainage pipes beneath the conduit must be replaced.

[John Falco]: Number nine, the conduit must cross MWRA infrastructure.

[John Falco]: Copies of the MWRA permit must be submitted to the engineering division prior to releasing a street opening permit approved by the superintendent of wires.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations and or aids.

[John Falco]: Adam L. Herneby, City Clerk.

[John Falco]: These plans can be viewed in the City Clerk's office at 781-393-2425.

[John Falco]: At this point, I would declare the public hearing open, open to anyone in favor of this project.

[John Falco]: Mr. Flewelling, I would assume you're in favor?

[John Falco]: Okay, thank you.

[John Falco]: Is there anyone else that would like to speak that is in favor of the project?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: OK, thank you.

[John Falco]: The first being offered by Council of Peers.

[John Falco]: If I may, I know as the president, I don't comment on too much and I pretty much preside over the meetings, but I just want to say that I believe emphatically that black lives matter.

[John Falco]: However, I do have some serious concerns about the council's authority to approve or disapprove putting a flag or banner on city hall property.

[John Falco]: There are no guidelines in place regarding which flags or banners are permitted.

[John Falco]: And I do need that this I do believe that this needs to be established outside City Hall is a pride flag that went up.

[John Falco]: I don't think it went up with a council vote.

[John Falco]: But I want to support that flag too.

[John Falco]: And I personally understand its significance to the LGBTQ community.

[John Falco]: as a father of a gay child.

[John Falco]: But what happens next week if a petition is made to fly a straight pride flag?

[John Falco]: Because yes, they do really exist.

[John Falco]: I don't believe it's within the council's purviews to choose which flags are raised without pre-existing guidelines.

[John Falco]: The city council has no jurisdiction whatsoever over City Hall.

[John Falco]: We have no jurisdiction, absolutely none.

[John Falco]: As a city council, we don't even have control over the thermostat in city council chambers.

[John Falco]: And that's a serious statement.

[John Falco]: So we have no control over the building.

[John Falco]: 19-481, July 23rd, 2022, Brianna Lugo, current mayor.

[John Falco]: uh, from Kimberly M. Scalen, acting city solicitor regarding council paper 19-481.

[John Falco]: On June 9, 2020, the Medford City Council requested that the proposed brewery ordinance have the following amendments made there too.

[John Falco]: At the consultation with the building commissioner, Paul Mokey, I have drafted the amendments.

[John Falco]: I respectfully request that this paper is sent to the Medford City Council.

[John Falco]: respectfully submitted Kimberley M. Scanlon.

[John Falco]: An ordinance amending Article 1, Chapter 94 of the revised ordinances of the City of Medford.

[John Falco]: Be it ordained by the City Council of the City of Medford that Article 1, Chapter 94 of the revised of the revised ordinance of the City of Medford as most recently amended is hereby further amended by the addition of two new definitions in Section 94-2 and

[John Falco]: adding an additional line called brewery to the principal uses set forth in the table of use regulations in section 94-148.

[John Falco]: The following two definitions are hereby added to section 94-2 entitled definitions.

[John Falco]: Brewery means an establishment primarily engaged in the production and distribution of beer, ale, and other malt beverages, which may include accessory uses such as tours of the brewery, retail sales, and or on-site consumption of the products

[John Falco]: For example, a tap room or tasting room.

[John Falco]: The facility shall hold the appropriate Commonwealth of Massachusetts brewery license, as well as any required pouring license approved by the local licensing authority.

[John Falco]: This facility may host marketing events, special events, and brewery tours.

[John Falco]: The facility may only sell beverages produced by and commercial goods branded by the brewery.

[John Falco]: Tasting room tap room means a room attached to a brewery that allows patrons to sample or consume bear, ale, or other malt beverages that are produced on site in accordance with general law chapter 138.

[John Falco]: Barrel means a container, usually cylindrical in nature, used for the storage of a malt beverage with a capacity of not more than 31 gallons.

[John Falco]: A line number 35B entitled brewery is hereby added to the principal uses set

[John Falco]: fourth in the table of use regulations in section 94-148 as follows.

[John Falco]: Table of use regulations in off-street parking and loading requirements.

[John Falco]: Let's see, so use brewery.

[John Falco]: This is communications from city officers and employees.

[John Falco]: Actually, yeah, so I'm sorry.

[John Falco]: So it's not allowed in SF1, SF2, GR&O, Apartment 1, Apartment 2, Apartment 3.

[John Falco]: C1, yes for breweries operating with seven barrels or under.

[John Falco]: SPA, for breweries operating with more than seven barrels.

[John Falco]: C2, it's allowable.

[John Falco]: I, industrial, it is allowable.

[John Falco]: O, yes.

[John Falco]: MUZ, yes.

[John Falco]: Parking 350.

[John Falco]: 20-472 Memorandum to President John Falco and members of the Medford City Council.

[John Falco]: CC registrar vote is from Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk, regarding Ward 3, Precinct 1 polling location, July 23, 2020.

[John Falco]: This is a follow-up paper to 20-472 from last month, as I reported in June.

[John Falco]: The former Lawrence Memorial Hospital site will not be available as a polling location for the September-November elections because of the ongoing construction and because of COVID-19 concerns.

[John Falco]: When I became aware that the LMH campus would not be available as a polling location, I began working identifying a new potential polling location for Ward 3, Precinct 1.

[John Falco]: I sought guidance from the Election Division of the Office of Secretary of the Commonwealth on designation of a new polling place.

[John Falco]: I reached out to the Commander Richard Martin of the American Legion post at 321 Winthrop Street.

[John Falco]: Commander Martin graciously volunteered the Legion Post as a polling place for both- Mr. President, move for the Reader's Digest version.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020, order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020, order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted.

[John Falco]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts 02155.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the appropriation of retained earnings in the amount of $1,500,000.00.

[John Falco]: This amount is being requested to subsidize the fiscal 2021 Water and Sewer Enterprise Fund budget due to the health pandemic and current economic conditions.

[John Falco]: retained earnings and reserves of the Water and Sewer Fund.

[John Falco]: Reserves can be used for any lawful purpose, but serve primarily to provide financial security in cases of unforeseen events such as COVID-19 or capital replacement.

[John Falco]: The balance of retained earnings before this vote is $6,433,552.

[John Falco]: The 21st regular meeting of the Bedford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members are present.

[John Falco]: This time I ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law, chapter 30A, section 18, and the governor's March 15, 2020 order, imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and your parties with the right

[John Falco]: The indoor requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: 20-420, offered by Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Whereas the City of Medford is in a fiscal budget emergency,

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the mayor be requested to appropriate with the city council approval the necessary amount of free cash to address the municipal in-school budget deficits.

[John Falco]: Be it further that the mayor be requested to replenish this account with any budget aid that it receives from the federal government or the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Be it further resolved that the mayor respond to this request by next Tuesday's city council meeting.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: We have Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Morell, Councilor Bears, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Vice President Carvill.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: We have Councilor Morell and then Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Anybody else like to speak on this issue?

[John Falco]: Any other comments from the public?

[John Falco]: Oh, okay.

[John Falco]: I'm sorry, Councilor Knight?

[John Falco]: I'm trying my best.

[John Falco]: So hopefully we'll have an update for you tomorrow.

[John Falco]: OK, on the motion of Vice President Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Oh, okay, I'm sorry.

[John Falco]: Seconded by... Does this resolution have a second?

[John Falco]: Well, I think what Councilor Mark said, I mean, to me, the responsibility is of the mayor to come to us.

[John Falco]: I understand that.

[John Falco]: I understand that.

[John Falco]: I understand what you're trying to do.

[John Falco]: You're trying to reach out.

[John Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli would like to make a comment.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: So I did hear back from the chief of staff today.

[John Falco]: So I believe what we're going to do is meet on Saturday with, I think it's going to be police, fire, DPW, and then

[John Falco]: The next meeting will probably be probably next Monday and probably do committee on Tuesday and maybe next Wednesday.

[John Falco]: I haven't kind of got that far yet as far as the scheduling piece goes.

[John Falco]: As far as getting it to City Hall, I'm working on that as well.

[John Falco]: And as far as budget books, I've been told we should receive a budget book Thursday afternoon.

[John Falco]: One of my concerns is if we don't get a budget book,

[John Falco]: until Thursday night, is that going to give the council enough time to review to take up police fire in DPW, which is kind of like the big three on Saturday.

[John Falco]: So that's my concern.

[John Falco]: I'm kind of wrestling with whether or not, you know, if we don't get that budget book, I mean, I want to make sure to me, the way I look at it is this, especially if we're going to be looking at a budget, we want to make sure that the council has enough time

[John Falco]: to look at the budget for those departments that we're going to meet with on Saturday to process the information and ask, you know, good questions and have a good, you know, truthful discussion.

[John Falco]: You know, if we get the budget book, you know, late, that's not going to be beneficial to anyone that's involved in this process.

[John Falco]: Point of information.

[John Falco]: And that's my concern.

[John Falco]: So I, to be, to be honest with you, I apologize for interrupting.

[John Falco]: I don't know yet if that Saturday is going to be police fire and DPW that I think needs to probably be juggled around because of the, uh, the timing of the book.

[John Falco]: It doesn't really make sense to have three big departments, you know, and we have minimal time to review.

[John Falco]: So, so I completely hear what you're saying.

[John Falco]: The regular meeting of June 9th.

[John Falco]: This is the 20th regular meeting of the Bedford City Council.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: President, all seven members are present.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise and salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: At this point, I want to recognize Vice President Caraviello, who would like to make a statement.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much for your comments.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight to revert to the regular order of business.

[John Falco]: Please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: The motion passes hearings.

[John Falco]: This is a notice of a public hearing.

[John Falco]: Legal Notice 20-389, petition for grant of location, National Grid, North Andover, Massachusetts, joint or identical poll locations, Medford, Massachusetts, City Clerk's Office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, public hearing will be given via Zoom at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: on Tuesday, June 9th, 2020, on a petition of National Grid for permission to locate polls, wires, and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining

[John Falco]: in protecting fixtures along and across the public way herein named said poll locations to be located substantially in accordance with the plan marked Woodruff Ave, Medford, Massachusetts and filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: Whoever prays that after due notice in hearing,

[John Falco]: as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may be necessary said, poles be erected substantially in accordance with the plan marked Woodruff Ave.

[John Falco]: Medford, Massachusetts and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 10385, George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: also for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals, cables, and wires in the above or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles in buildings as each of said petitioners may desire.

[John Falco]: Yes, on the motion of Councilor Marks to get approved, seconded by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Do we have a representative on the line?

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Marks, seconded by Councilor Bears, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes, 70 affirmative, zero in the negative.

[John Falco]: Do we have a representative from National Grid?

[John Falco]: Oh, he is, I see him right here, okay.

[John Falco]: So

[John Falco]: If I may go on further, this has been approved by the chief engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to this one JO poll described in the GOL document as follows.

[John Falco]: National Grid will install one JO poll

[John Falco]: on Woodruff Ave beginning at a point approximately 200 feet east of the center line of the intersection of Bradbury Avenue and Woodruff Avenue.

[John Falco]: Two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141A.

[John Falco]: of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[John Falco]: Number four, the new pole location is located adjacent to granite curbing.

[John Falco]: Any disturbance of the curb or curb concrete backing must be repaired to the satisfaction of the city engineer.

[John Falco]: Number five, the new pole location is in a landscaped area with trees.

[John Falco]: The city of Medford tree warden should inspect the trees before and after construction.

[John Falco]: Tree protection should be required and coordinated with the Medford tree warden.

[John Falco]: That's approved by the superintendent of wire.

[John Falco]: So at this point, I'll declare the public hearing open, open to those in favor of the petition.

[John Falco]: Socrates, you're in favor, I assume?

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Is there anyone else here in favor of the petition that would like to speak in favor of this petition?

[John Falco]: Seeing and hearing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[John Falco]: Anyone here in opposition of the petition?

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition?

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition?

[John Falco]: Clerk Cardavis, you see anybody in opposition?

[John Falco]: Hearing and seeing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Is there any questions for Socrates on this matter?

[John Falco]: 2-0-399 offered by Councilor Knight, whereas the Office of Diversity is established to provide oversight of laws and regulations relating to affirmative action, contract compliance, fair housing, disability, human rights, discrimination, hate-related incidents, and or crimes.

[John Falco]: We focus on outreach, inclusion, and education.

[John Falco]: We interact with other city departments as well as other cities in local, state, and federal organizations and agencies to ensure fair and equitable opportunity and access for all persons.

[John Falco]: And whereas the Office of Diversity is established to provide persons with disabilities equal opportunity to access to as well as participation in education, employment,

[John Falco]: the public and private services in the city of Medford through advocacy, awareness, and enforcement.

[John Falco]: And whereas the office of personnel is established to help city departments attract, motivate, retain, manage, and develop qualified and productive employees.

[John Falco]: And whereas the functions of the office of the disability and office of diversity have been consolidated under the director of personnel.

[John Falco]: And whereas the consolidation

[John Falco]: as a result in the elimination of the independent disinterested check and balance on personal matters once provided through the Office of Disability and Diversity.
