[John Falco]: 20-042 in the ordinance amending the revised ordinances of the city of Medford zoning relative to adult use marijuana.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved by the city council of the city of Medford as follows.

[John Falco]: The revised ordinances of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: So when I say X, that means it hasn't really been slotted into a position yet.

[John Falco]: So that'll be renumbered once it goes to, once it gets passed.

[John Falco]: City Method X, B, and R hereby amended by inserting the following to section X at the end of article X as follows.

[John Falco]: Whereas by vote of the state election on November 8, 2016, the voters of the Commonwealth approved legislation regulating commerce in marijuana.

[John Falco]: marijuana accessories and marijuana products, and for the taxation of proceeds from sales of such products.

[John Falco]: It was authorized cities and towns to adopt reasonable restrictions on the time, place, and manner of operating marijuana business, and whereas currently the City of Manfred Code of Ordinance does not

[John Falco]: specify the license requirements for persons or entities seeking to operate adult-use marijuana establishments in the city and whereas the legislature, the commonwealth has determined that cities and towns in Massachusetts

[John Falco]: should not be permitted to outright prohibit adult-use marijuana facilities without a citywide referendum vote.

[John Falco]: Whereas the licensing commission of the city of Manford may grant local licenses for adult-use marijuana establishments regulated under Section 3 of Chapter 94G of the General Laws in 935 CMR 500.

[John Falco]: Therefore, be it adopted by the Medford City Council in session assembled that the below listed sections of the Medford Code of Ordinances are hereby amended and created as identified.

[John Falco]: Section XX, purpose and intent applicability.

[John Falco]: A, purpose, intent,

[John Falco]: purpose and intent and applicability.

[John Falco]: Number one, purpose and intent.

[John Falco]: The purpose and intent of this ordinance is to provide for adult use of marijuana establishments in the city of Medford in accordance with general law chapter 94 G and its implementing regulations at 930.

[John Falco]: 935 CMR 500.

[John Falco]: It is the aim of this ordinance to minimize any adverse impacts that marijuana establishments may have on adjacent or nearby properties and to provide standards for the placement, design, siting, safety, security, monitoring, modification and

[John Falco]: discontinuance of marijuana establishment subject to reasonable conditions aimed to protect public health, safety and welfare.

[John Falco]: This ordinance is intended to be used in conjunction with other applicable ordinances of the city of Medford that are designed to encourage appropriate land use and impose reasonable safeguards to govern the time, place and manner of marijuana establishment operations.

[John Falco]: and any business dealings in marijuana accessories in such as fashion to protect public health, safety, well-being, and minimize undue impacts of the natural environment.

[John Falco]: Two, applicability.

[John Falco]: The ordinance applies to all marijuana establishments, including marijuana cultivators, craft marijuana cooperatives, marijuana product manufacturers, marijuana microbusinesses, independent testing laboratories, marijuana retailers, marijuana transporters, marijuana research facilities, delivery only licenses, and medical marijuana treatment centers licensed by

[John Falco]: The commonwealth pursuant to general laws chapter 94G and chapter 941.

[John Falco]: Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed to supersede federal and state laws or regulations governing the sale and distribution of marijuana.

[John Falco]: Section XX definitions, A definitions.

[John Falco]: The following definitions consistent with general law chapter 94G, the general law chapter 941,

[John Falco]: and the Cannabis Control Commission implementing regulations 935 CMR 500.002 and 935 CMR 501.002 shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section.

[John Falco]: Number one, Cannabis Control Commission.

[John Falco]: The Massachusetts Cannabis Control Commission established by general law chapter 10, section 76 orders representatives with authority to implement the state marijuana laws.

[John Falco]: Two, Kraft Marijuana Cooperative.

[John Falco]: A marijuana cultivator comprised of residents of the Commonwealth and organized as a limited liability company, limited liability partnership, or cooperative corporation under the laws of the Commonwealth.

[John Falco]: A cooperative license to cultivate, obtain, manufacture, process, package, and brand cannabis or marijuana products to transport marijuana to marijuana establishments, but not to consumers.

[John Falco]: A craft marijuana cooperative is a type of marijuana cultivator.

[John Falco]: Three, delivery only licensee, an entity that is authorized to deliver directly to consumers from a marijuana retailer or registered qualifying patients or caregivers from a medical marijuana treatment center, MTC, and that does not provide a retail location accessible to the public.

[John Falco]: Four, independent testing laboratory, a laboratory that is licensed or registered by the Cannabis Control Commission and is a currently in

[John Falco]: validly licensed under 935 CMR 500.001.

[John Falco]: Application requirements were formally validly registered by the Commission B, accredited to the most current international organization for standardization 17025 by a third party accrediting body that is a signatory to the International Laboratory Accreditation Corporation Mutual

[John Falco]: recognition arrangement or that is otherwise approved by the commission.

[John Falco]: C, independent financially from any medical marijuana treatment center or any licensee or marijuana establishment for which it conducts a test.

[John Falco]: And D, qualified to test marijuana in compliance with regulations promulgated by the commission.

[John Falco]: Excuse me.

[John Falco]: Marijuana, all parts or any plants of the genus cannabis not expected below in whether growing or not, the seeds thereof in resident extracted from any part of the plant in every compound manufactured, solid derivative mixture or preparation of the plant, its seeds or resident including tetrahydrocannabal is defined in general law chapter 94 C section one provided however that marijuana shall not include.

[John Falco]: I the mature stocks of the plant fiber produced from the stocks oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant Any other compound manufacture salt derivative?

[John Falco]: mixture or preparation of the mature stocks fiber oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant or sterilized seed of the plant that is incapable of germination

[John Falco]: Two, hemp, or three, the weight of any other ingredient combined with marijuana to prepare topical or oral administrations, food, drink, or other products.

[John Falco]: Six, marijuana cultivator, an entity licensed to cultivate, process, and package marijuana and to transfer marijuana to other marijuana establishments, but not to customers.

[John Falco]: Seven, marijuana establishment and marijuana cultivated, craft marijuana, cooperative marijuana, product manufacturer, marijuana micro-business, independent testing laboratory, marijuana retailers, marijuana transporter, delivery only licensing, marijuana research facility, or any other type of licensed marijuana related business, including a medical marijuana treatment center, MTC.

[John Falco]: Eight, marijuana product manufacturer.

[John Falco]: An entity licensed to obtain, manufacture, process and package marijuana and marijuana products to deliver marijuana and marijuana products to marijuana establishments and to transfer marijuana and marijuana products to other marijuana establishments but not to customers.

[John Falco]: Marijuana Retailer.

[John Falco]: An entity licensed to purchase and transport marijuana and marijuana products from marijuana establishments and to transfer a sale, otherwise transfer this product to marijuana establishments and to sell to consumers.

[John Falco]: Marijuana retailers are prohibited from offering marijuana or marijuana products from the purpose of onsite social consumption on the premises of a marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: 10, marijuana transporter, an entity not otherwise licensed by the Cannabis Control Commission that is licensed to purchase, obtain, and possess marijuana and marijuana products solely for the purpose of transporting temporary storage, sale, and distribution to marijuana establishments, but not for sale to consumers.

[John Falco]: 11, marijuana research facility, an entity licensed to engage in research projects by the Cannabis Control Commission.

[John Falco]: 12, microbusiness, a collected marijuana operation that can be either a tier one marijuana cultivator or marijuana product manufacturer or both in compliance with 935 CMR 500.000 operating procedures for each license and in a receipt of a delivery endorsement issued by the Cannabis Control Commission may deliver marijuana or marijuana products

[John Falco]: produced at the licensed location directly to consumers in compliance with the established regulatory requirements for retail sale as relates to delivery.

[John Falco]: A microbusiness that is a product manufacturer may purchase no more than 2,000 pounds of marijuana per year from other marijuana establishments for the purpose of marijuana product manufacturing.

[John Falco]: 13, special permit.

[John Falco]: A special permit issued by the special permit granting authority to a marijuana establishment in accordance with the standards set forth in this ordinance and the general criteria for granting a special permit contained in section XX of the revised zoning ordinance of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: A special permit issued under this ordinance shall be for a term of five years from the date of the marijuana establishment commences operations unless sooner revoked or forfeited.

[John Falco]: At the expiration of the term of the holder term a holder may apply for renewal according to the process established by the special permit granting authority.

[John Falco]: 14 special permit holder the person persons or entity who desires to operate a marijuana establishment in the city of Medford and who is who has received a special permit issued by the special permit granting authority

[John Falco]: to operate a marijuana establishment in accordance with the standards set forth in this ordinance and the general criteria for granting a special permit contained in section XX of the revised zoning ordinance of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: 15, special permit granting authority, the zoning board of appeals of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: 16, host community agreement, an agreement negotiated and executed between an applicant who proposes to locate

[John Falco]: in marijuana establishment in the City of Method and the City in accordance with General Laws, Chapter 94G, Section 3D.

[John Falco]: Section XX, Special Permit Granting Authority, Special Permit Requirements, Special Permit Granting Authority.

[John Falco]: A, the Zoning Board of Appeals shall be the Special Permit Granting Authority in the City of Method and may grant a special permit for marijuana

[John Falco]: establishments in accordance with the standard set forth in the ordinance in the general criteria for breaking a special permit contained in section XX of the revised zoning ordinance of the city of Metro.

[John Falco]: The B requirement to apply for a special permit shall be set by the building commissioner.

[John Falco]: B requirements.

[John Falco]: Number one, it shall be unlawful for any person or entity to operate a marijuana establishment without obtaining a special permit

[John Falco]: from the special permit granting authority to operate pursuant to the requirements of this ordinance.

[John Falco]: Two, a separate special permit is required for each different marijuana establishment defined in section XX above.

[John Falco]: In the case that one or more different types of marijuana establishments are proposed, each establishment type shall require a special permit as defined in the ordinance.

[John Falco]: Three, an applicant shall be eligible to apply for a special permit

[John Falco]: upon receipt of the recommendation from the Cannabis Advisory Committee in accordance with Section XX of the General Ordinance.

[John Falco]: No special permit shall be issued until an applicant has successfully negotiated a host community agreement with the city.

[John Falco]: Four, the special permit requirements set forth in this ordinance shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other licensing and permitting requirements imposed by any other federal, state, or local law or required by the special permit granting authority.

[John Falco]: Five, the issuance of a special permit pursuant this ordinance does not create an exception, defense, or immunity to any person or entity in regard to any potential criminal liability

[John Falco]: the personal entity may have for the production, distribution, or possession of marijuana.

[John Falco]: Six, a special permit issued for a marijuana establishment is not transferable nor assignable to a different location or to a different type of marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: Section XX, General and Operational Provisions,

[John Falco]: A, general provisions.

[John Falco]: One, the following provisions apply to all marijuana establishments as defined above in general law chapter 94G, GLC941 in subsection XX of this ordinance.

[John Falco]: including marijuana cultivators, crack marijuana cooperatives, marijuana product manufacturers, marijuana micro-businesses, independent testing laboratories, marijuana retailers, marijuana transporters, marijuana research facilities, delivery-only licenses, and medical marijuana treatment centers.

[John Falco]: Two, marijuana establishments shall comply with applicable state and local laws, regulations, ordinances, codes, conditions, and agreements with the city, including but not limited to

[John Falco]: general law chapter 94G, general law chapter 94I, 935 CMR 500.000, 935 CMR 501.000, the revised ordinances of the city of Medford, the city of Medford zoning ordinance, all applicable city building fire prevention, police and health codes, regulations and standards.

[John Falco]: Any conditions imposed,

[John Falco]: on licenses and permits held by the marijuana establishment, including but not limited to those imposed by the Special Permit Granting Authority in agreements between the marijuana establishment and the City of Medford, including host community agreements.

[John Falco]: Excuse me.

[John Falco]: Number three, marijuana establishments shall maintain all permits and licenses required by state and local laws.

[John Falco]: Any actions avoiding the Cannabis Control Commission's license by operation of law, including

[John Falco]: including due to cessation of operations, failure to become operational within the permanent time or relocation without Cannabis Control Commission approval and any revocation or suspension of the marijuana establishment's Cannabis Control Commission license shall result in a suspension of the special permit pending hearing or the opportunity therefore afforded to the marijuana establishment and pending further determination by the Zoning Board of Appeals of

[John Falco]: by the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Four, all taxes and charges owed to the city must be paid on a current basis.

[John Falco]: The city must place a lien, and may place a lien, on the property or any person or entity who has an outstanding balance due.

[John Falco]: The city, for any fee, charge, or tax, which balance is at least three months past due, the city has adopted the provisions of general law chapter 40, section 57.

[John Falco]: B, operational provisions.

[John Falco]: One, security plan operations and management plan and emergency response plan, disposal of odor, disposal and odor control plan.

[John Falco]: A, security plan.

[John Falco]: I, an applicant for a special permit pursuant to this ordinance shall at least 30 days prior to the public hearing on the application submit a security plan to the chief of police of the city of Medford describing

[John Falco]: adequate and proper security at the premises so as to avoid, deter and prevent illegal activities from taking place upon or about the applicant's premises, and to demonstrate that there is limited undue burden on city public safety resources as a result of the proposed business prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, and two,

[John Falco]: The security plan shall include the details at all security measures for the site and transportation of marijuana and marijuana products to and from on-site premises to ensure the safety of employees and the public and to protect the premises property from theft or other criminal activity.

[John Falco]: The applicant shall meet with the chief of police or his designee regarding the applicant's security plan prior to the issuance of a special permit.

[John Falco]: B, operation of management plan.

[John Falco]: An applicant for a special permit pursuant to this ordinance shall submit an operation and management plan to the special permit governing authority, which shall include but not be limited to the following elements.

[John Falco]: Organizational structure, location, property, description, hours of operation and staffing, description and proposed operations, distribution practices, employee safety, general compliance,

[John Falco]: fire prevention, sanitation requirements, electrical system overview, proposed energy demand, and proposed electrical demand offsets.

[John Falco]: Ventilation system and air quality, proposed water system and utility demand prior to the issuance of a building permit, and proposed traffic mitigation and parking plans.

[John Falco]: The applicant shall additionally provide the building commissioner and the director of the City of Medford Health Department copies of all documents submitted under this section for review and comment.

[John Falco]: The emergency response plan.

[John Falco]: An applicant for a special permit pursuant to the ordinance shall submit proposed emergency response plan to the special permit granting authority.

[John Falco]: It shall meet with the fire chief of the city of Medford and the police chief of the city of Medford prior to the public hearing to discuss and identify emergency plans.

[John Falco]: contingency plans for the site prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy.

[John Falco]: The emergency response plan shall include, but not be limited to, a description of the work tasks and activities to take place on the premises and its plan.

[John Falco]: to implement proper protocols and to take proper steps so as to prevent hazardous activities from taking place upon or about the premises.

[John Falco]: A written emergency response plan shall be filed with the Medford Fire Department and Medford Police Department pursuant to Mass General Law AC94G section 12.

[John Falco]: Marijuana establishments shall comply with 527 CMR 1.00

[John Falco]: It was Chapter 38 of NFPA Number 1, 2018, as they may be amended and as applicable.

[John Falco]: D, disposal and odor control plans.

[John Falco]: An applicant for a special permit pursuant to this ordinance shall submit plans for waste disposal, trash pickup, and rubbish removal that serve the metal water establishment.

[John Falco]: All trash pickup and rubbish removal shall be provided by a private rubbish removal service and the city of Medford shall not be required to provide any trash pickup or rubbish removal for the marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: The marijuana establishment shall comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws, regulations, rules and ordinances pertaining to the disposal of trash or refuse.

[John Falco]: from the marijuana establishment and any other conditions required by the director of the City of Medford Health Department.

[John Falco]: This shall include, but not be limited to, Massachusetts waste disposal regulations set forth in 310 CMR 19.017.

[John Falco]: An applicant for a special permit to engage in cultivation or product manufacturing pursuant to this ordinance shall submit an odor control plan

[John Falco]: that provides for proper and adequate ventilation at such facilities in such a manner as so to prevent pesticides, insecticides, or other chemicals used in the cultivation or processing of marijuana or marijuana-related products from being dispersed or released outside the facilities, all resulting in odors, smoke, vapors, fumes, gases, and particulate matter from marijuana

[John Falco]: or its processing or cultivation shall be effectively confined to the premises or so disposed of so as to avoid any air pollution and so that no odor or marijuana or its processing can be detected by a person with an unimpaired and otherwise normal sense of smell at the exterior of the facility or at any adjoining

[John Falco]: adjoining use of property, and to minimize any adverse impacts on human beings, the environment, and abutting properties from odor-emitting activities to be conducted on site.

[John Falco]: The applicant shall additionally provide the Director of the City of Medford Health Department copies of all documents submitted under this section of for review and comment.

[John Falco]: environmental impact plan.

[John Falco]: An impact for a special permit pursuant to this ordinance shall submit a plan to reduce the impact of its intended activity on the environment.

[John Falco]: The applicant shall additionally provide the director of the energy and environment of the city of Medford copies of all documents submitted under this section for review in comment.

[John Falco]: to retail marijuana establishments shall not be managed by any person other than the licensee or their assigned.

[John Falco]: Such licensee or assigned shall be on the premises during regular hours of operation and responsible for all activities within the licensed business and shall provide up-to-date emergency contact information for the city or a city of Medford police fire and building department to have on file.

[John Falco]: Three, on-site social consumption of marijuana is prohibited at all marijuana establishments as are vending machines and other self-service devices.

[John Falco]: Four, pursuant to General Law 94G, Section 5B.3, a marijuana establishment shall not be located within 500 feet of a pre-existing public or private school providing education in kindergarten,

[John Falco]: or any grades one through 12.

[John Falco]: The 500 foot distance shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest point of the property line in question to the nearest point of the property line where the marijuana establishment is or will be located.

[John Falco]: Five, all marijuana establishments license operations shall be conducted within a building at a fixed location.

[John Falco]: A marijuana establishment shall not be located in a trailer, storage free container.

[John Falco]: motor vehicle or other similar movable enclosure.

[John Falco]: Six, the marijuana establishment may only be involved in the use permitted by its definition.

[John Falco]: Retail marijuana establishments may only be located in buildings with other uses, including other types of marijuana establishments, if the marijuana establishment is separated by four walls from other use.

[John Falco]: 7.

[John Falco]: All aspects of marijuana establishment relative to the cultivation, possession, processing, manufacture, sale, distribution, dispensing, or administration of marijuana, marijuana products, or related supplies must take place at a fixed location within a fully enclosed building and shall not be visible from the exterior of the building.

[John Falco]: 8.

[John Falco]: Marijuana establishments may cultivate, process, test, store, and manufacture marijuana or marijuana products only within an area that is enclosed and secured in a manner that prevents access by persons not permitted by the marijuana establishment to access the area.

[John Falco]: The hours of operation of the marijuana establishments in all standards or requirements relating to exterior signs and advertisements shall be those that are set by the marijuana's establishment's host community agreement with the city.

[John Falco]: 10.

[John Falco]: Marijuana establishments shall ensure that their hours in methods of transportation or products shall not be a detriment

[John Falco]: or be a nuisance to the surrounding area in nearby uses.

[John Falco]: 11, marijuana establishments shall not permit any disorder, disturbance, nuisance, or illegality under state or local law of any kind on the premises.

[John Falco]: 12, marijuana establishment operations shall not result in illegal distribution under state or local law of marijuana obtained

[John Falco]: from the marijuana establishment or in use of marijuana in any manner that violates state or local law.

[John Falco]: 13, marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: operations shall not create nuisance conditions in parking areas, sidewalks, streets, in areas surrounding the premises and adjacent properties.

[John Falco]: Nuisance includes but is not limited to disturbances of the peace, open public consumption of marijuana, excessive pedestrian or vehicular traffic,

[John Falco]: odors emanating from the marijuana's establishment's premises, electrical lighting, illegal drug activity in the state or local law, harassment of passerby, excessive littering, excessive loitering, illegal parking, excessive loud noises, excessive citation for violations of state traffic laws and regulations, and or transportation division rules and regulations, queuing of patrons, vehicular or pedestrian

[John Falco]: in or other obstructions of the public way, sidewalks and streets, collisions between vehicles, bicyclists and pedestrians, lewd conduct or police detentions and arrests.

[John Falco]: Fourteen, marijuana establishments may be subject to and announce unscheduled periodic inspections of its premises by the building commissioner or designee.

[John Falco]: including an agent from the building health police and fire departments, which when conducted by the police department shall be by a sworn police officer holding the rank of sergeant or higher at any time during the normal business hours to determine the marijuana establishment's compliance with the requirements of applicable state and local laws, regulations, and codes.

[John Falco]: 15, marijuana establishments are prohibited from use of the onsite self-service displays.

[John Falco]: Self-service displays are defined to mean displays from which customers may select marijuana or marijuana products without assistance from an employee or store personnel, including vending machines.

[John Falco]: 16, all business signage shall be subject to the requirements to be

[John Falco]: promulgated by the Cannabis Control Commission, the signed ordinance set forth by the revised ordinance of the City of Medford, and is set forth by the host community agreement.

[John Falco]: 17, no drive-thru service shall be permitted at a marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: 18, no outside storage of marijuana and marijuana products or related suppliers is permitted.

[John Falco]: 18, no outside storage of marijuana products or related supplies is permitted.

[John Falco]: 19, the consumption of marijuana in the interior or exterior of the premises is not permitted.

[John Falco]: No marijuana or marijuana products shall be smoked, eaten, or otherwise consumed or ingested on the premises where sold.

[John Falco]: All marijuana establishments permitted in the city of Medford shall comply with all state and local laws, rules, and regulations governing the smoking of tobacco. 20,

[John Falco]: A marijuana establishment and the owners of the premises where the marijuana establishment is located shall comply with the provisions of General Law Chapter 40, Section 57.

[John Falco]: 21, a marijuana establishment shall be required to remove all marijuana and marijuana products by the earlier of A, prior to surrendering its state-issued license or B, within one month of ceasing operations.

[John Falco]: Section XX, Application Procedure and Submission Requirements.

[John Falco]: A, Application Procedure and Submission Requirements.

[John Falco]: An applicant for a special permit shall submit a standard application will form along with all materials as required by the Special Permit Renting Authority.

[John Falco]: In addition, each applicant shall submit the following materials.

[John Falco]: One, payment for publication and mailing

[John Falco]: of notice of the date, time, and place of the hearing of the petition for a special permit before a special permit granting authority to the owners of all property within 750 feet of the property line.

[John Falco]: of the location of the marijuana establishment as it appears on the most recent tax list maintained by the assessor's office of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: The city shall also provide notice generally to the residents of the city of Medford by way of telephone call or text message that uses a computerized auto dialer to deliver a prerecorded message of its equivalent no less than 14 days prior to the hearing

[John Falco]: on a petition for a special permit setting forth the date, time, and place of the hearing.

[John Falco]: The applicant shall be responsible for any costs associated with such notice.

[John Falco]: to the applicant shall submit proof of site control in right to use the premises proposed for the marijuana establishment in making included deed notarized statement from the property owner in a copy of the lease agreement or a real estate contract contingent upon successful licensing

[John Falco]: or a letter of intent by the owner of the premises indicating intent to lease the premises to the applicant contingent upon successful permitting.

[John Falco]: Three, in addition to complying with any other state or city requirement related to good character and criminal background, any person or entity

[John Falco]: proposed to have interest in a license to operate a marijuana establishment shall not have committed any marijuana licensing violation affecting public safety or receiving any suspension or revocation of any other state or local marijuana business licenses.

[John Falco]: Four, a statement signed by the applicant's chief executive officer disclosing all of its designated owners, including officers, directors, partners, managers, or other similarly situated individuals.

[John Falco]: If any of the above are entities rather than persons, the applicant must disclose the identity and current contact information for all responsible individuals.

[John Falco]: Five, a detailed description of the proposed activities to occur on site in relation to the standard special permit criteria set out in section XX of the zoning ordinance of the city of Medford and specific requirements set forth in this chapter.

[John Falco]: Six, the applicant shall submit a security plan to the Medford police chief to demonstrate that there is limited undue burden on the city's public safety officials as a result of the proposed business prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy.

[John Falco]: excuse me, seven, the applicant shall submit an operation and management plan with an additional copy to the building commissioner and the director of, director of the board of health.

[John Falco]: Eight, the applicant shall submit a copy of an emergency response plan with an additional copy to the police chief and the fire chief of the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Nine, the applicant shall submit a copy of the disposal in odor control plan with an additional copy to the director of health of the health department.

[John Falco]: Section XX, the special permit findings and specific requirements for various facilities.

[John Falco]: A, special permit findings.

[John Falco]: In addition to the findings of the special permit in section XX of the zoning ordinance, the special permit granting authority must also make the following findings.

[John Falco]: One, the applicant demonstrates that the marijuana establishment will meet all of the permitting requirements of the applicable agencies within the commonwealth.

[John Falco]: It will be in compliance with all applicable state laws and regulations including but not limited to MGLAC 94G section 12 general marijuana establishment operation.

[John Falco]: Two, the applicant has satisfied all of the conditions and requirements of this section

[John Falco]: and other applicable sections of the zoning ordinance in any applicable city ordinances.

[John Falco]: Three, the facility provides adequate security measures to ensure that there are not direct threats to the health or safety of employees, staff or members of the public in that storage and location of confirmation is adequately secured.

[John Falco]: Four, the marijuana establishment does not derogate from the purposes and intent of this section in the zoning ordinance.

[John Falco]: Five, the application information submitted is adequate to the special permit granting authority to consider approving the special permit request.

[John Falco]: Six, the proposed establishment is designed to minimize any adverse impacts on human beings, the environment and abutting properties.

[John Falco]: Seven, the security plan provides sufficient assurance

[John Falco]: that adequate security controls have been implemented to ensure the protection of the public health and safety during hours of operation and that any marijuana or marijuana related products are adequately secured on site or via delivery.

[John Falco]: Eight, the operation and management plan includes all required components and can be implemented to meet

[John Falco]: the requirements of this section.

[John Falco]: Nine, the emergency response plan includes all required components and can be implemented to meet the requirements of this section.

[John Falco]: 10, disposal in order control plans includes all required components and can be implemented to meet the requirements of this section.

[John Falco]: 11, the special permit granting authority may require a marijuana establishment to post a bond or other resources held in an escrow account

[John Falco]: an amount sufficient to adequately support the dismantling and winding down of the marijuana establishment.

[John Falco]: 12, no special permit shall be issued by the special permit granting authority zoning until an applicant has submitted proof of an executed host community agreement with the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: B, requirements specific to marijuana cultivation facility.

[John Falco]: As the cultivation and processing of marijuana is not considered agricultural under General Law, Chapter 128, Section 1A, and is subject to General Law, Chapter 94G, Section 12, the following restrictions to ensure the health, safety, well-being of the public and to limit undue impacts on the natural environment as it relates to cultivation shall apply.

[John Falco]: One, all marijuana cultivators shall use high-efficiency lights and equipment to limit energy and water usage demand.

[John Falco]: Two, all marijuana cultivators shall use LEDs for all fixtures except for those that are used in flowering rooms.

[John Falco]: High pressure sodium grow lights may be used for no more than 50% of the total square footage of the cultivation area to maximize flowering conditions and limit electricity demand.

[John Falco]: Three, no pesticides, insecticides, or other chemicals shall be used in the cultivation of marijuana.

[John Falco]: Marijuana cultivators shall be used

[John Falco]: Marijuana cultivators shall use the best practices to prevent pests and contamination as set forth in 935 CMR 500.1209.

[John Falco]: Four, marijuana cultivators shall comply with all regulations that may be promulgated by the Cannabis Control Commission.

[John Falco]: C, requirements specific to marijuana product manufacturers.

[John Falco]: Marijuana product manufacturers shall be subject to general law chapter 94g section 12 in the following restrictions to ensure the health, safety, and well-being of the public and limit any undue impacts of the natural environment as it relates to manufacturing shall apply.

[John Falco]: One, all marijuana product manufacturers shall use high efficiency lights and manufacturing equipment

[John Falco]: to limit energy and water usage demand.

[John Falco]: Two, all marijuana product manufacturers shall comply with all regulations that may be promulgated by the Cannabis Control Commission.

[John Falco]: D, requirements specific to independent testing laboratories.

[John Falco]: One, all independent testing laboratories shall use high-efficiency lights and equipment to limit energy and water usage demand.

[John Falco]: Two, independent testing laboratories shall be subject to the requirements of General Law Chapter 94G, Section 15, and any regulations that the Cannabis Control Commission may promulgate there under to ensure there are no undue impacts on the health, safety, and well-being of the public.

[John Falco]: E, requirements specific to Manor Water Retailers.

[John Falco]: Manor Water Retailers shall be subject to General Law, Chapter 94G, Section 12, and the following restrictions to ensure that there are no undue impacts on the health, safety, and well-being of the public.

[John Falco]: One, as defined in General Law, Chapter 94G, the number of Manor Water Establishments shall be limited to no more than 20% of the number of

[John Falco]: licenses issued within the city for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages not to be drunk on the premises where sold under general law chapter 138 section 15.

[John Falco]: In accordance with general law chapter 94g on the effective date of this ordinance the number of marijuana retailers shall be limited to no more than three.

[John Falco]: All marijuana retailers

[John Falco]: shall comply with all regulations that may be promulgated by the Cannabis Control Commission.

[John Falco]: Marijuana retailers shall not sell marijuana or permit marijuana as defined herein to be sold to a person under the minimum legal sales age or give gift or transfer of marijuana or marijuana products as defined herein to a person under the minimum legal sales age.

[John Falco]: For marijuana retailers,

[John Falco]: when selling or distributing marijuana or marijuana products as defined herein, shall verify the age of the purchaser by means of a valid government issued photographic identification containing the various date of birth and showing that the purchaser is 21 years of age or older.

[John Falco]: Five, all retail sales of marijuana or marijuana products shall be face-to-face between the seller and the buyer and occur only at the permitted location.

[John Falco]: Six, marijuana retailers should only be permitted in the C2 or industrial zoning districts as specified in the table of uses.

[John Falco]: Marijuana retailers shall not exceed 10,000 square feet in retail floor space.

[John Falco]: Section XX, unlawful acts compliance severability.

[John Falco]: A, unlawful acts.

[John Falco]: Number one, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any marijuana establishment

[John Falco]: the city in the city without a valid license issued by the state licensing authority under general law chapter 94 G. Two, when a marijuana establishment has received a renewal license from the state, the business shall submit a copy to the city clerk, chief of police, fire chief, building commissioner, and director of the board of health within 30 days of receipt.

[John Falco]: Three, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any marijuana establishment without a special permit from the special permit granting authority.

[John Falco]: Four, no person shall gift marijuana or marijuana products to a consumer contingent upon the sale of any other products.

[John Falco]: Five, no person shall accept or redeem, offer to accept or redeem or cause or hire any person to accept or redeem or offer to accept or redeem any coupon that

[John Falco]: provides marijuana or a marijuana product without charge.

[John Falco]: B, compliance, a special permit held by a marijuana establishment under this ordinance is conditional on the holder's continued compliance with all requirements and conditions that apply to the special permit into its compliance with all applicable local ordinances, state and federal laws and regulations.

[John Falco]: A violation by a marijuana establishment that holds a special permit of all requirements and conditions

[John Falco]: that applied to the special permit in with all applicable local ordinances, state and federal laws and regulations shall be good cause for, it may result in a penalty of $300 per violation.

[John Falco]: Each day the violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.

[John Falco]: C, separability.

[John Falco]: If any provision of this section is invalidated by subsequent legislation or regulation or held to be invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, then such provision shall be considered separately and apart from the remaining provisions which shall remain in full force and effect.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: On that motion offered by Councilor Knight, seconded by, was it Vice President Caraviello?

[John Falco]: Yes, sir.

[John Falco]: I just have to read the message from the governor.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18 in the governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance

[John Falco]: or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Whereas it prays that after due notice in hearing as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to excavate the public highways and to run and maintain underground electric conduits together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary for the transmission of electricity and underground conduits to be located substantially in accordance

[John Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to the excavation.

[John Falco]: 20-395 offered by Councilor Bears and Councilor Morell, whereas many food pickup and delivery apps and websites charge exorbitant fees and commissions that hurt our local restaurants, and whereas these fees may endanger the ability of local restaurants to survive this economic crisis.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Medford City Council expresses its support for HD,

[John Falco]: 5-0-5-4, an act relative to restaurant delivery commissions during the COVID-19 state of emergency.

[John Falco]: Be it further resolved that the City Clerk forward a copy of this resolution to the Medford Legislative Delegation, as well as House Speaker DeLeo, Senate President Spilka, and Governor Baker.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears with Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Clerk, do you have the wording of the B paper?

[John Falco]: No, I just want to make sure you have it.

[John Falco]: Yeah, I got it.

[John Falco]: OK, perfect.

[John Falco]: OK, any other questions from the council?

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to smoke the flag.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order, suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the Governor's March 15th, 2020 order, imposing strict limitations on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right

[John Falco]: and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Is that Councilor Knight?

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, would you like to suspend the rules?

[John Falco]: 54 and exempt $10,000 of fair cash value on personal property accounts to be taxed beginning in fiscal year 2021, beginning on July 1st, 2020.

[John Falco]: Let's see, 20-381, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, regarding ordinance amendment zoning change.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following amendment to the City of Medford zoning ordinance offered in accordance

[John Falco]: with the provisions of the revised ordinances of the City of Method and Mass General Lodge of the 3040A Section 5.

[John Falco]: Section 194-148 of the revised ordinances City of Method, Massachusetts is hereby amended as follows.

[John Falco]: Number one, table of use regulations in off-street parking and loading.

[John Falco]: table of use regulations for use 18 multiple dwellings not over three stories in height.

[John Falco]: Amend yes to SPC with footnote number three immediately following the word height to read as follows.

[John Falco]: A special permit shall require that 25% of the total gross floor area of the development contain non-residential uses permitted by right of which are authorized pursuant to a special permit in the underlying zoning district or where relevant overlying zoning district.

[John Falco]: For use 19, multiple dwelling, not over 75 feet or six stories in height, amended yes to SPC with footnote number three, immediately following the word height to read as follows.

[John Falco]: A special permit shall require that at least 25% of the gross floor area of the development contain a non-residential uses permit by right or which are authorized pursuant to a special permit in the underlying zoning district or where relevant

[John Falco]: overlying zoning district.

[John Falco]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[John Falco]: Respectfully submitted Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[John Falco]: Is there someone from the, actually Dave, oh, you got Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: There is a motion on the floor from Councilor Knight, seconded by Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Chief of Staff Dave Rodriguez, if you could please explain this paper or just give us an overview.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: So there's a number of Councilors that want to speak on this.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, are you pulling back your original motion and offering a motion to send this to the CD board?

[John Falco]: Chief of staff Rodriguez.

[John Falco]: Yep, let's let's let's let's let Chief of Staff Rodriguez finish then.

[John Falco]: Chief of staff.

[John Falco]: Chief of staff Rodriguez, you said you were going to move ahead.

[John Falco]: I apologize.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor, do you have any further questions?

[John Falco]: Okay, on the motion of council, I'd like to move to the CD board, seconded by?

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 30A, Section 18 in the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Bedford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: 20-327, we had a committee, the whole meeting on Thursday, May 7th, 2020.

[John Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to receive an update from the administration regarding the fiscal year 2020 budget.

[John Falco]: in fiscal year 2021 city budget.

[John Falco]: Let's see.

[John Falco]: All the councillors were in attendance along with Mayor Lungo-Koehn and also Mr. Roselli, who is a outside auditing consultant who works for the city.

[John Falco]: He explained the situation that the city is in with a shortfall of about $8 million, assuming a local aid cut of 20%.

[John Falco]: He explained that the motor vehicle excise, mail tax, rooms excise, and building permits are other major revenue components that make up the deficit.

[John Falco]: After speaking with the building commissioner, Mr. Roselli said that he's using a $2 million figure rather than a $4 million figure.

[John Falco]: He basically explained that the costs are already known.

[John Falco]: There's an $8 million, $2 million gap.

[John Falco]: That's an estimate.

[John Falco]: And the city will have more numbers within the next few weeks.

[John Falco]: But Mr. Roselli did say that the information will get better faster as more information comes in.

[John Falco]: But he believes that the $8.2 million gap is a worst case scenario.

[John Falco]: And after asking Mr. Roselli when it will be an appropriate time to meet,

[John Falco]: again to get an update.

[John Falco]: He said in early June.

[John Falco]: So I will move forward and try to schedule that meeting with the administration so we can get an update, so we can get an update.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight?

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes, that is fine.

[John Falco]: 19-659 and 20-042, May 13th, 2020, Committee of the Whole meeting.

[John Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the proposed marijuana ordinance.

[John Falco]: We thank the Subcommittee on Zoning for their hard work on the draft copy of the ordinance.

[John Falco]: Councilwoman Haynes summarized the changes that were made in the subcommittee.

[John Falco]: using the draft ordinance as a guide.

[John Falco]: Let's see.

[John Falco]: Council and I discussed the proposed members of the selection committee.

[John Falco]: So there's a lot of discussion with regard to the proposed marijuana ordinance.

[John Falco]: In the end, what we did is we actually sent it out to be updated and to get a new red line copy from KP Law and City Solicitor Scanlon.

[John Falco]: That has been returned and we will be meeting about that tomorrow night at 6 p.m.

[John Falco]: on Zoom.

[John Falco]: A motion of council, I'd like to approve the committee report, seconded by?

[John Falco]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: I have any affirmative, zero, and the negative, the motion passes.

[John Falco]: The 16th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members are present.

[John Falco]: At this time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag

[John Falco]: This meeting is being broadcast live on Channel 22 Comcast and Channel 43 Verizon.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions in the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 30A, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are able to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting,

[John Falco]: Hearings 20-343 Legal Notice City of Medford Five-Year Consolidated Plan 2020 Annual Public Action Plan Revised Public Hearing.

[John Falco]: This is a public hearing.

[John Falco]: A virtual public hearing via Zoom will be held by the Medford City Council on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: The purpose of the public hearing will be to invite the general public and representatives of public service agencies to express comments regarding the city's five-year consolidated plan and annual actual plan for community development and planning.

[John Falco]: The actual plan contains the proposed use of community development block grant CDBG funds for programming in 2020, which extends

[John Falco]: from July 1st, 2020 through June 30th, 2021.

[John Falco]: The consolidated plan includes broad goals and objectives to address priority needs with resources available from HUD, including a five-year strategy for use of CDBG funding for the years 2020 through 2024.

[John Falco]: The Office of Community Development will be requesting that the Medford City Council authorize Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, official representative of the City of Medford, to submit the 2020 through 2024 Consolidated Plan and 2020 Annual Action Plan application for funds in all assurances and certifications to the U.S.

[John Falco]: Department of Housing and Urban Development.

[John Falco]: The city's applying for $1,574,868 in CDBG funds.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodations slash aids.

[John Falco]: TDD 781-393-2516.

[John Falco]: Medford is an EEOAA 504 employer.

[John Falco]: Communications from the mayor, 20-355.

[John Falco]: Dear Council President Falco,

[John Falco]: and honorable members of the Medford City Council.

[John Falco]: As you are aware, the city is working in coordination with MassDOT to plan for safe routes to school project for the Brooks Elementary School.

[John Falco]: The project involves improvements to sidewalks that directly abut private residential parcels.

[John Falco]: The federal funding granted for this project requires that the right-of-way be in complete ownership and physical control of the city.

[John Falco]: The survey prepared

[John Falco]: for the project identify 12 private properties that contain public infrastructure or require a temporary construction easement.

[John Falco]: In order to meet the requirements of the projects, permanent easements will alter the High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street layouts to encompass the public infrastructure in temporary easements with

[John Falco]: will facilitate construction of sidewalks.

[John Falco]: The written offer was sent to the 12 property owners via certified mail on April 2, 2020, and Tim McGibbon, City Engineer, has been in contact with each owner to address concerns throughout this process, starting from the initial contact letter back in December 2019.

[John Falco]: easements were appraised by a certified general appraiser and those appraisals were reviewed by a certified general review appraiser to establish just compensation for the easements.

[John Falco]: I respectfully request that the city council vote to approve the attached order of taking associated with these easements at your regular May 12, 2020 meeting and therefore approve

[John Falco]: the alternations of High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street.

[John Falco]: The alternations of High Street, Mystic Street, and Walcott Street are approved by the Mayor and recommended to the City Council by the Community Development Board via unanimous vote on March 25, 2020.

[John Falco]: Mr. McGibbon will be in attendance to answer any questions on this matter.

[John Falco]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[John Falco]: Additional documents may be inspected in the office of the city clerk, Bedford City Hall, Bedford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Okay, let's see.

[John Falco]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[John Falco]: 20-344 offered by Councilor Knight and Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Whereas the question was raised at a recent meeting by the Zoning Court of Appeals as to whether or not experiences are authorized in the City of Medford.

[John Falco]: And whereas on July 19, 2016, the City of the Medford City Council approved paper 166-586.

[John Falco]: which requested a written legal opinion from the city solicitor as to whether or not use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: And whereas, on August 12, 2016, the city solicitor provided the requested legal opinion to the city council, which determined use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: And whereas, this opinion was not challenged by any entity in any legal form.

[John Falco]: And whereas, the Medford City Council failed to approve Papers 1-7

[John Falco]: and 18-354 seeking the deauthorization of use variances in the City of Medford and whereas on April 24, 2018, the Medford City Council approved

[John Falco]: 18-376 in a super majority roll call vote, calling for the adoption of the city solicitor's opinion and authorization to amend the codified ordinances to reflect the finding of his opinion.

[John Falco]: And whereas the Medford City Council in the city of Medford is the city of Medford legislative body enabled as the sole authority responsible for the passage of local zoning law, be it resolved that the Medford City Council requests

[John Falco]: The city solicitor Scanlon forward to the Zoning Board of Appeals a copy of the solicitor's opinion and other documents deemed necessary at her discretion.

[John Falco]: And be it further resolved that the city clerk provide copies of Papers 16-856, 17-007, 18-354, and 18-376 to the Zoning Board of Appeals.

[John Falco]: We have further resolved that the Medford City Council respectively requests that the Zoning Board of Appeals acknowledges and affirm by way of roll call vote the following.

[John Falco]: Number one, the Zoning Board of Appeals has been provided a copy of the city solicitor's opinion on August 12, 2016, determining use variances are permitted in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Number two, the Zoning Board of Appeals has been provided with council papers

[John Falco]: 16-856, 17-007, 18-354, and 18-376.

[John Falco]: Number three, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that the Medford City Council is the City of Medford's legislative body enabled as the sole authority responsible for the passage of local zoning law.

[John Falco]: Number four, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that the question as to whether or not use variances are authorized in the City of Medford has been addressed

[John Falco]: by way of the August 12, 2016 legal opinion and council passage of paper 18-376.

[John Falco]: Number five, the Zoning Board of Appeals recognizes that use variances are authorized in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: 20-352 offered by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: We have resolved that the Medford City Council request the Recreation Department expand programming surrounding socially distanced recreational activities and opportunities.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Okay, it looks like we lost you.

[John Falco]: I was just going to add in, I know, you know,

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, you there?

[John Falco]: This is about a 45 second gap.

[John Falco]: Where was I?

[John Falco]: If I may.

[John Falco]: So I've been helping out since coronavirus started.

[John Falco]: My wife and I have been helping out during lunch hour to go down and give out meals.

[John Falco]: And the whole meal program that's

[John Falco]: given out, you know, the meals that are given out during lunch in different locations throughout our city.

[John Falco]: Uh, that's, that's really, that's operated by the recreation department.

[John Falco]: So as I go pick up my meals each day, I see Kevin Bailey, I see, I see Danny, Danny folks and Kate Quinn, and they're picking up meals every day and they have their own stations where they're giving out meals.

[John Falco]: They're even hand delivering meals as well.

[John Falco]: Um, so they, they're out in the community hand delivering meals and they're, I mean,

[John Falco]: Unfortunately, it's a recreation department of only three people.

[John Falco]: It's not like, you know, our neighbors next door that have, you know, you know, probably 10 to 15.

[John Falco]: But there's only three.

[John Falco]: So I know they're working hard.

[John Falco]: They're doing a lot of work.

[John Falco]: You know, they're trying to maintain the

[John Falco]: you know, the daily programs and putting in online content as well, as well as, you know, you know, prepping for summer programs and contingency planning as well if those summer programs don't happening, it don't happen depending on what happens with COVID-19.

[John Falco]: But I know that they are hard at work.

[John Falco]: I know that they're working nonstop, especially on the meals program.

[John Falco]: So I just wanted to bring that to light and make sure that people know that.

[John Falco]: I mean, it's,

[John Falco]: not a big department, but that department is working continuously each day, especially with the meal distribution during COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And on top of it, they're refurbishing the gym down at the, uh, uh, down at the Chevalier, uh, the, the, the rec headquarters.

[John Falco]: So, um, so there's a lot going on, um, and they're doing a lot of work, but I just wanted to mention that as well.

[John Falco]: Uh, did anybody else want to comment on this resolution?

[John Falco]: Councilor Caraviello, was that your hand up or were you just throwing something?

[John Falco]: Let's see, we have

[John Falco]: Communications from the mayor.

[John Falco]: June 0-356, joint resolution to petition the federal government for emergency financial relief.

[John Falco]: It is hereby resolved by her honor, the mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, the Honorable Medford City Council and the Honorable Medford School Committee that whereas on March 11th, 2020, the World Health Organization designated the COVID-19 outbreak

[John Falco]: pandemic health emergency.

[John Falco]: And whereas on March 20th, 2020, the governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts issued a declaration of a state of emergency to respond to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And whereas on March 16th, 2020, her honor

[John Falco]: The mayor and the Medford Board of Health announced that a local state of emergency exists in the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: And whereas the public health crisis has precipitated an economic collapse that has affected every sector of the local, state, and national economies.

[John Falco]: Whereas, following this collapse, municipalities across Massachusetts and the United States are facing a fiscal crisis that threatens the ability for cities and towns to deliver critical services to our community.

[John Falco]: And whereas, the delivery of these services directly and critically affects the quality of life, safety, education, and health of the Medford community, now therefore be it resolved

[John Falco]: that the city of Medford by her honor, the mayor, the honorable city council and the honorable Medford school committee.

[John Falco]: Number one, the federal and state governments by and through the city's elected delegations continue engaging with cities and towns to determine budget needs and solutions at the municipal level.

[John Falco]: And number two, the federal and state governments consider it an urgent and emergency need to provide adequate financial support to cities and towns to weather the current economic and fiscal crisis in the form of direct stimulus and relief as soon as possible in order to continue to provide the high quality of critical services upon which the Medford community relies.

[John Falco]: The original paper filed in the office of the city clerk

[John Falco]: Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: On the motion to approve by Vice President Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight, Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: 70 affirmative, zero in the negative, the motion passes.

[John Falco]: Okay, pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 orders suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18 and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting in the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media website an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Before we adjourn, I just wanted to mention really quick, I've received a,

[John Falco]: a request from the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust to appoint someone to be the council representative to M-Belt.

[John Falco]: And Councilor Bears has expressed interest in this role.

[John Falco]: So I'm going to appoint Councilor Bears as the city council representative to the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust.

[John Falco]: So congratulations.

[John Falco]: Congratulations, good luck.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: And Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: On the motion of council, Vice President Caraviello to adjourn the meeting.

[John Falco]: Seconded by.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes, 70 affirmative, zero in the negative.

[John Falco]: The meeting is adjourned.

[John Falco]: I hope everyone has a safe and healthy night.

[John Falco]: Be safe.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members are present.

[John Falco]: Can we all please rise to salute the flag?

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020, order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 30A, Section 18.

[John Falco]: in the governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and your parties with the right annual requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the city of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post this on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media

[John Falco]: website and audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: 20-316, April 16th, 2020, to President John Falco, honorable members of the Medford City Council, from Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, regarding loan order city sidewalks, dear Mr. President and city councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order.

[John Falco]: City method loan order citywide sidewalks, be it ordered that the sum of $500,000 be hereby

[John Falco]: is appropriated to pay the cost of repairing, constructing, and reconstructing various sidewalks throughout the city, including engineering and design services, and for the payment of all costs incidentally related thereto, that to meet this appropriation, the city treasurer, with approval of the mayor, is authorized to borrow said sum under Mass General Law, Chapter 44, Section 7.1, as amended and supplemented or pursuant to any other

[John Falco]: and to issue bonds or notes of the city thereof.

[John Falco]: Therefore, any premium received upon the sale of any bonds or notes approved by this order, lest any such premium applied to the payment of the cost of issuance of such bonds or notes may be applied to the payment of costs approved by this order in accordance with Mass General Law, Chapter 44, Section 20, thereby reducing the amount authorized to be borrowed

[John Falco]: to pay such costs by a like amount.

[John Falco]: If further order, that the city treasurer is authorized to file an application with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Municipal Finance Oversight Board to qualify into Chapter 44A of the general laws, any and all bonds or notes of the city authorized by this vote or pursuant to any prior vote of the city and in connection.

[John Falco]: therewith to provide such information and execute such documents as the Municipal Finance Oversight Board of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts may require, very truly yours, Mayor Brianne Alago-Kern.

[John Falco]: So last week, this paper came before us.

[John Falco]: There were a number of questions that the councilors had for the administration.

[John Falco]: We received some responses earlier today from

[John Falco]: Let's see he's from my chief of staff Dave Rodriguez.

[John Falco]: They were forwarded to us by Club her to bees did everyone have a chance to read those or what we can do is I can actually go through the questions and read up the answers so everyone can I

[John Falco]: see what the responses were from the administration.

[John Falco]: Vice President Caraviello had the first question.

[John Falco]: He offered an amendment requesting information on whether the mayor and the DPW have looked into the pilot program mentioned in January to repair sidewalks for less money than it costs to replace them and whether method reached any agreement with Walden.

[John Falco]: The answer, I assume that this question is regarding the request from the council that the administration explore the option of utilizing a method of sidewalk repair that involves grinding

[John Falco]: and not full replacement.

[John Falco]: The requested funding is for the continuation of a previously procured contract with an existing contractor, La Rovere Construction.

[John Falco]: I'm not aware of any negotiations or discussions that have been had by the administration with the city of Malden regarding sidewalk replacement.

[John Falco]: We will look into the feasibility of the sidewalk repair method vendor in future contracts.

[John Falco]: So that was the answer to the first question.

[John Falco]: Second question was asked by Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Council Marks offered an amendment requesting the answer to the following question.

[John Falco]: Is the administration working from a list?

[John Falco]: The answer, yes.

[John Falco]: While the pavement condition index, the PCI project is set to begin this summer, the mayor has asked the DPW commissioner and city engineer for a list based on their experience of sidewalks that are in the most need

[John Falco]: of replacement, the sidewalks to be replaced and selected by using the following criteria in no particular order.

[John Falco]: One, age of the request.

[John Falco]: Two, condition of the surrounding sidewalks and driveway aprons.

[John Falco]: Three, geography, an attempt is made to spread it out equitably throughout the city.

[John Falco]: Part B to the question, if there is a list, what percentage of the work on this list is being done with this $500,000?

[John Falco]: The answer, it depends on the on the ground conditions for each sidewalk.

[John Falco]: The hope is to stretch the work as far as possible.

[John Falco]: Last year, the city was able to replace 232 sidewalks of varying lengths under the current contract in 2019.

[John Falco]: Part C, is there a priority list?

[John Falco]: The answer is yes, based on the criteria above.

[John Falco]: Part D, when will the work take place?

[John Falco]: Answer, upcoming construction season.

[John Falco]: Number three, Councilor Morell offered an amendment requesting answers to the following questions.

[John Falco]: A, can the administration please clarify what phase three is and are there additional phases?

[John Falco]: B, does the administration anticipate making another request for funding sidewalk repairs and to when does that carry us?

[John Falco]: The answer is,

[John Falco]: that this is the second part of a two-year contract.

[John Falco]: Sidewalk repair replacement is constantly needed and subject to availability of funds.

[John Falco]: Number four, Council appears off an amendment requesting answers to the following question.

[John Falco]: How does this project in its funding fit into the COVID-19 impact on city finances?

[John Falco]: And does this funding request need to be pared back?

[John Falco]: Answer, the administration is currently working on understanding the extent of COVID-19 we'll have on our city finances for current and future fiscal years.

[John Falco]: A request has been put forth to complete a current contract.

[John Falco]: The city's finance team believes that this is within our capacity at this time.

[John Falco]: Question five, what is the current free cash balance?

[John Falco]: The answer is approximately $12 million.

[John Falco]: Number six, what is the city's current bonding capacity?

[John Falco]: The answer, the city is authorized to borrow up to 5% of the equalized values in the community.

[John Falco]: City is currently borrowing less than 1% of the EQB.

[John Falco]: The city's borrowing capacity currently exceeds $500 million.

[John Falco]: So those are questions that the administration, well actually these are the questions and answers, the answers from the administration.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'll recognize Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Treasurer Papio.

[John Falco]: Before we adjourn, I'm just gonna read a quick announcement that came in just as we started the meeting from the DCR.

[John Falco]: It's a DCR traffic advisory for Fellsway West.

[John Falco]: Starting on Monday, May 4th, 2020 and continuing through June 11th, 2020, excluding weekends, the Department of Conservation and Recreation, the DCR, will implement lane closures and parking restrictions along Fellsway West in the City of Medford from Salem Street to St.

[John Falco]: Francis Street outbound in I-93 and Salem Street inbound to accommodate paving operations

[John Falco]: During this time, work will fluctuate between day and evening operations.

[John Falco]: Additionally, a police detail will be on site, traffic patterns will be marked, and signage regarding parking restrictions will be posted.

[John Falco]: This will be from Monday, May 4th, 2020 through Thursday, June 11th, excluding weekends.

[John Falco]: the city of Medford from Salem Street to St.
