[John Falco]: 14th, 13th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members present at this time, I'd ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Okay, so if everyone can just bear with me for a few minutes.

[John Falco]: I'm actually working with Patrick to see if I can get this pre-recorded for the next meeting, but I have to read a number of meeting notices.

[John Falco]: So the first one, here we go.

[John Falco]: The agenda is a revised agenda.

[John Falco]: The original agenda was posted at 119 p.m.

[John Falco]: on April 16, 2020.

[John Falco]: This agenda was last revised on April 17, 2020 at 10.02 a.m.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18,

[John Falco]: In the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with a right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we aren't able to do so, despite best efforts, we will post it on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media

[John Falco]: website in audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: All messages from the Governor of Massachusetts, Charles D. Baker.

[John Falco]: Order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 20.

[John Falco]: Whereas on March 10, 2020, I, Charles D. Baker, Governor of

[John Falco]: Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, acting pursuant to the powers provided by Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 and Section 2A of Chapter 17 of the General Law, has declared that there now exists in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts a state of emergency

[John Falco]: due to the outbreak of the 2019 novel coronavirus COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And whereas many important functions of state and local government are executed by public bodies, as the term is defined in general law chapter 30A, section 18, in meetings that are open to the public, consistent with the requirements of law and sound public policy, and in order to ensure active,

[John Falco]: public engagement with contribution to and oversight of the functions of government, and whereas both the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, CDC, and the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, DPH, have advised residents to take extra measures to put distance between themselves and other people to further reduce the risk of being exposed to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: Additionally, the CDC and DPH have advised high-risk individuals

[John Falco]: including people over the age of 60, anyone with underlying health conditions, or a weakened immune system in pregnant women to avoid large gatherings.

[John Falco]: Whereas Section 7, 8,

[John Falco]: In 8A of Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950, authorize the governor during the effective period of a declared emergency to exercise authority over public assemblages as necessary to protect the health and safety of persons.

[John Falco]: And whereas low-cost telephone, social media, and other internet-based technologies

[John Falco]: are currently available that will permit the convening of a public body through virtual means and allow real-time public access to the activities of the public body.

[John Falco]: And whereas Section 20 of Chapter 30A in implementing regulations issued by the Attorney General currently authorize remote participation by members of a public body subject to certain limitations.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, I hereby order the following.

[John Falco]: Number one, a public body as defined in section 18 of chapter 30A of the general laws is hereby relieved from the requirement of section 20 of chapter 30A that it conduct its meeting in a public place that is open and physically accessible to the public, provided that the public body makes provision

[John Falco]: to ensure public access to the deliberations of the public body for interested members of the public through adequate alternative means.

[John Falco]: Adequate alternative means of the public access shall mean measures that provide transparency and permit timely and effective public access to the deliberations of the public body.

[John Falco]: Such means may include, without limitation, providing public access through telephone, internet, or satellite-enabled audio or video conferencing, or any other technology that enables the public to clearly follow the proceedings of the public body while those activities are occurring.

[John Falco]: We are allowing for active real-time participation by members of the public is a specific requirement of a general or special law or regulation

[John Falco]: or a local ordinance or bylaw pursuant to which the proceeding is conducted, any alternative means of public access must provide for such participation.

[John Falco]: A municipal body

[John Falco]: The municipal public body that, for reasons of economic hardship and despite best efforts, is unable to provide alternative means of public access that will enable the public to follow the proceedings of the municipal public body as those activities are occurring in real time, may instead post on its municipal website a full and complete transcript, recording, or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as practicable upon conclusion of the proceedings.

[John Falco]: This paragraph shall not apply to proceedings that are conducted pursuant to a general or special law or regulation or local ordinance or bylaw that requires allowance for active participation by members of the public.

[John Falco]: A public body must offer its selected alternative means of access to its proceedings without subscription, toll or similar charge to the public.

[John Falco]: Number two, public bodies are hereby authorized to allow remote participation by all members in any public

[John Falco]: in any meeting of the public body.

[John Falco]: The requirement that a quorum of the body in their chair be physically present at a specified meeting location as provided in general law chapter 30a section 20d in 940 CMR 29.10

[John Falco]: 4B is hereby suspended.

[John Falco]: Number three, a public body that elects to conduct its proceedings under the relief provided in sections one or two above shall ensure that all party entitled or required to appear before it shall be able to do so through remote means as if the party were a member of the public body and participating remotely as provided in section two.

[John Falco]: Number four, all other provisions of section 18 to chapter,

[John Falco]: 25 of chapter 30 a and the attorney general's implementing regulations shall otherwise remain unchanged.

[John Falco]: If fully applicable to the activities of the public bodies, this order is effective immediately.

[John Falco]: It shall remain in effect until it's rescinded or until the state of emergency is terminated.

[John Falco]: Whichever happens first governor of Massachusetts, Charles D Banker.

[John Falco]: I have a motion to suspend the rules, to take communications from the mayor, seconded by?

[John Falco]: Second, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Vice President Caraviello, Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Seven in the affirmative, zero in the negative.

[John Falco]: The rules are now suspended.

[John Falco]: Communications from the mayor, 20-316.

[John Falco]: April 16, 2020, to President John Falco and honorable members of the Medford City Council.

[John Falco]: From Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn regarding loan order citywide sidewalks, dear Mr. President and city councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order.

[John Falco]: City of Medford loan order citywide sidewalks, be it ordered that the sum of $500,000 be in hereby is appropriated to pay the cost of repairing, constructing and reconstructing various sidewalks throughout the city, including engineering and design services and for the payment of all costs incidental and related thereto.

[John Falco]: that it meet this appropriation, the city treasurer with approval of the mayor authorized to borrow said sum under and pursuant to Mass General Law, Chapter 44, Section 7, one as amended and supplemented or pursuant to any other enabling authority in to issue bonds or notes of the city therefore.

[John Falco]: any premium received upon the seal of any bonds or notes approved by this order, lest any such premium applied to the payment of the cost of issuance of such bonds or notes may be applied to the payment of costs approved by this order in accordance with Mass General Law, Chapter 44, Section 20, thereby reducing the amount authorized to be borrowed to pay such costs by a like amount.

[John Falco]: In further order,

[John Falco]: that the city treasurer is authorized to file an application with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Municipal Finance Oversight Board to qualify under Chapter 44A of the General Laws, any and all bond or notes of the city authorized by this vote or pursuant to any prior vote of the city in connection therewith.

[John Falco]: to provide such information and execute such documents as the Municipal Finance Oversight Board of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts may require.

[John Falco]: Very truly yours, Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God,

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's microphone.

[John Falco]: Yeah, I have to read this communication.

[John Falco]: So if you give me a few minutes, I'll get through this and then we'll move forward with the meeting.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law Chapter 38, Section 18 and the Governor's

[John Falco]: March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: Specific information and the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found

[John Falco]: on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to learn or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website in audio or video recording, transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: Thank you for that.

[John Falco]: And now I have to read one more notification from the governor of Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law, chapter 30.

[John Falco]: Chapter 38, section 20.

[John Falco]: Whereas on March 10th, 2020, I, Charles D. Baker, Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, acting pursuant to the powers provided by Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 in Section 2A of Chapter 17 of the General Laws, declared that there now exists in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts a state of emergency due to the outbreak of the 2019 novel coronavirus COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And whereas many important functions of state and local government are executed by public bodies, as that term is defined in general law chapter 38, section 18, the meetings that are open to the public consistent with the requirements of law and sound public policy in order to ensure active public engagement with contribution to and oversight of the functions government.

[John Falco]: functions of government, and whereas both the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, CDC, and the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, DPH, have advised residents to take extra measures to put distance between themselves and other people to further reduce the risk of being exposed to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: Additionally, the CDC and DPH have advised high-risk individuals, including people over the age of 60,

[John Falco]: anyone with underlying health conditions or a weakened immune system in pregnant women to avoid large gatherings.

[John Falco]: Whereas Section 7, 8, and 8A of Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 authorize the governor during the effective period of declared emergency to exercise authority over public assemblages as necessary to protect the health and safety of persons.

[John Falco]: And whereas low-cost telephone, social media, and other internet-based technologies are currently available

[John Falco]: that will permit the convening of a public body through virtual means and allow real-time public access to activities of the public body and whereas Section 20 of Chapter 30A and implementing regulations issued by the Attorney General.

[John Falco]: currently authorizes remote participation by members of the public body subject to certain limitations.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, I hereby order the following.

[John Falco]: Number one, a public body as defined in section 18 of chapter 38 of the general laws is hereby relieved

[John Falco]: from the requirement of section 20 of chapter 30A, that it conduct its meetings in a public place that is open and physically accessible to the public, provided that the public body makes provision to ensure public access to the deliberations of the public body for interested members of the public through adequate alternative means.

[John Falco]: Adequate alternative means of public access shall mean measures that provide transparency

[John Falco]: and permit timely and effective public access to the deliberations of public body.

[John Falco]: Such means may include, without limitation, providing public access through telephone, internet, or satellite, enabled audio or video conferencing, or any other technology that enables the public to clearly follow the proceedings of the public body while those activities are occurring.

[John Falco]: While allowance for active real participation by members of the public is a specific requirement of the general or special law or regulation or a local ordinance or bylaw, pursuant to which the proceedings is conducted in alternative means, a public access must provide for such participation.

[John Falco]: a municipal public body that for reasons of economic hardship and despite best efforts is unable to provide alternative means of public access that will enable the public to follow the proceedings of the municipal public body as those activities are occurring in real time may instead post on its municipal website a full and complete transcript reporting or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as practicable upon the conclusion of the proceedings.

[John Falco]: This paragraph shall not apply to the proceedings that are concluded pursuant to a general or special law or regulation or a local ordinance or bylaw that requires allowance for active participation by members of the public.

[John Falco]: A public body must offer its selected alternative means of access to its proceedings without subscription toll or similar charge to be public.

[John Falco]: Number two,

[John Falco]: public bodies are hereby authorized to allow remote participation by all members in any meeting of the public body.

[John Falco]: The requirement is a quorum of the body in the chair be physically present at a specified meeting location as provided in general law chapter 30A, section 20D and in 940CMR 29.104B

[John Falco]: is hereby suspended.

[John Falco]: Three, a public body that elects to conduct its proceedings under the relief provided in sections one or two above shall ensure that any party entitled or required to appear before it shall be able to do so through remote means as if the party were a member of the public body and participating remotely as provided in section two.

[John Falco]: Number four, all other provisions of sections 18 to 25 of chapter 30A in the attorney general's implementing regulations shall otherwise remain unchanged if fully applicable to the activities of public bodies.

[John Falco]: This order is effective immediately and shall remain in effect until rescinded or until the state of emergency is terminated, whichever happens first.

[John Falco]: Okay, thank you for listening to that.

[John Falco]: So as we move forward, and I open up the meeting tonight, I'd like to, before we move forward with the meeting, this week, the city lost one of our, someone actually very special to our city, and that is Joe McGonigal.

[John Falco]: For those of you that don't know Joe McGonigal,

[John Falco]: He was a city clerk from 1967 to 1996.

[John Falco]: That spans four decades, almost 30 years of service to our community in that one capacity.

[John Falco]: And for those that knew Joe, he was a pretty

[John Falco]: uh, you know, pretty amazing guy.

[John Falco]: I mean, I didn't get to know him till after he retired his clerk, but, uh, very nice man, uh, active in the community.

[John Falco]: And, um, I think we should, uh, start this meeting, uh, you know, by having a moment of silence for him.

[John Falco]: But I just think that he should be recognized for someone who served as long as he did.

[John Falco]: That's, you know, from 1967 to 1996 is a very long time and he was very committed to our community.

[John Falco]: And so I think we should start off by having a moment of silence for him.

[John Falco]: But I would first also like to recognize Vice President Caballero.

[John Falco]: Uh, we, uh, we have, uh, let's see, uh, councilor Peters.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Any other councilors?

[John Falco]: Let's see.

[John Falco]: Okay, the 11th regular meeting of the council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Present, seven present.

[John Falco]: We will begin the meeting.

[John Falco]: Thank everyone for being here tonight.

[John Falco]: And like I said in our previous meeting, we try to make this as authentic as it usually is at City Hall.

[John Falco]: So at this time, I would ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 18, and the Governor's March 15, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place, this meeting of the Medford City Council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance or members of the public will be permitted, but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so, despite best efforts, we will post on the city of Medford or Medford community media website, an audio or video recording transcript or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: At this point, I'm required to read the following message from the Office of the Governor.

[John Falco]: Charles Baker.

[John Falco]: Order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 38, Section 20.

[John Falco]: Whereas, on March 10, 2020, I, Charles D. Baker, Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts,

[John Falco]: Massachusetts, acting pursuant to the powers provided by Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 and Section 2A of Chapter 17 of the General Laws declare that there now exists in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts a state of emergency due to outbreak of the 2019 novel coronavirus COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And whereas many important functions of state and local government are executed by public bodies,

[John Falco]: As the term is defined in general law, chapter 30A, section 18, in meetings that are open to the public, consistent with requirements of law and sound public policy, and in order to ensure active public engagement with contributions to and oversight of the functions of government and

[John Falco]: whereas both the Federal Center for Disease Control and Prevention, CDC, and Massachusetts Department of Public Health, DPH, have advised residents to take extra measures to put distance between themselves and other people to further reduce the risk of being exposed to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: Additionally, the CDC and DPH have advised high-risk individuals

[John Falco]: including people over the age of 60, anyone with underlying health conditions or a weakened immune system, and pregnant women to avoid large gatherings.

[John Falco]: Whereas Section 7, 8, and 8A of Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 authorized the governor during the effective period of the declared emergency to exercise authority over public assemblages

[John Falco]: OK.

[John Falco]: Whereas low-cost telephones, social media, and other internet-based technologies are currently available that will permit the convening of a public body through virtual means and allow real-time public access to the activities of the public body.

[John Falco]: and whereas Section 20 of Chapter 30A in implementing regulations issued by the Attorney General currently authorized remote participation by members of a public body subject to certain limitations.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, I hereby order the following.

[John Falco]: One, a public body as defined in Section 18 of Chapter 30A of the general laws is hereby relieved from the requirement of Section 20 of Chapter 30A

[John Falco]: that it conduct its meetings in a public place that is open and physically accessible to the public, provided that the public body makes provisions to ensure public access to the deliberations of the public body for interested members of the public through adequate alternative means.

[John Falco]: Adequate alternative means of public access shall mean measures that provide transparency and permit timely and effective public access to the deliberations of the public body.

[John Falco]: Such means may include, without limitation, providing public access through telephone, internet, or satellites-enabled audio or video conferencing, or any other technology that enables the public to clearly follow the proceedings of the public body while those activities are occurring.

[John Falco]: where allowance for active real-time participation by members of the public is a specific requirement of a general or special law or regulation or a local ordinance or bylaw pursuant to which the proceeding is conducted.

[John Falco]: Any alternative means of public access must provide for such participation.

[John Falco]: A municipal public body that, for reasons of economic hardship and despite best efforts, is unable to provide alternative means of public access that will enable the public to follow the proceedings of the municipal public body as those activities are occurring in real time, may instead post on its municipal website a full and complete transcript, recording, or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as practicable

[John Falco]: upon conclusion of the proceedings.

[John Falco]: The paragraph shall not apply to proceedings that are conducted pursuant to a general or special law or regulation or a law ordinance or bylaw that requires allowance for active participation by members of the public.

[John Falco]: A public body must operate selected alternative means of access to its proceedings without subscription toll or similar charge to the public.

[John Falco]: Number two, public bodies are hereby authorized to allow remote participation by all members in any meeting of the public body.

[John Falco]: The requirement that a quorum of the body and the chair be physically present at a specified meeting location as provided in general law, chapter 38, section 20D and in 940 CMR 29.104B is hereby suspended.

[John Falco]: Number three, a public body that elects to conduct its proceedings under the relief provided in sections one or two above shall ensure that any party entitled or required to appear before it shall be able to through remote means as if the party were a member of the public body and participating remotely as provided in section two.

[John Falco]: All other provisions of Section 18 to 25 of Chapter 30A and the Attorney General's implementing regulations shall otherwise remain unchanged and fully applicable to the activities of public bodies.

[John Falco]: This order is effective immediately and shall remain in effect until rescinded or until the state of emergency is terminated, whichever happens first.

[John Falco]: So at the last meeting we had last week, we had a hearing that was tabled and that was 20-084.

[John Falco]: Would someone like to make a motion to take that from the table?

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Caraviello to take paper 20-084 from the table.

[John Falco]: Seconded by?

[John Falco]: Second.

[John Falco]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Clerk Hernebiz, would you please call the roll?

[John Falco]: Okay, okay, then we don't have to take them both then, right?

[John Falco]: Correct.

[John Falco]: Okay, my apologies.

[John Falco]: Okay, 20-084, hearings.

[John Falco]: This is a notice of a public hearing.

[John Falco]: Hearing is 20-084, City of Medford.

[John Falco]: Notice of a public hearing.

[John Falco]: The Medford City Council will hold a continued public hearing via Zoom on Tuesday evening, April 7th at 7 p.m.

[John Falco]: on a petition from Anne Bakery, Carla Barile,

[John Falco]: 17 Placestead Road, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, for a special permit to amend its hours of operation in accordance with Method Zoning Ordinance Chapter 94, Section 94-145, to operate extended hours at its business at 17 Placestead Road, Medford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Said site

[John Falco]: being located in a commercial 1C1 zoning district as follows.

[John Falco]: Extended hours of operation requested, 6 a.m.

[John Falco]: to 7 a.m., seven days per week.

[John Falco]: Petition and plan may be seen in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: Number three, Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2501 for any accommodations, aids, TDD 781-393-2516

[John Falco]: The City of Medford is an EEO-AA-504 employer.

[John Falco]: For information, contact the City Clerk at 71393-2425 by order of the City Council.

[John Falco]: Adam L. Hurtubise, City Clerk.

[John Falco]: This was advertised in the Medford transcript on March 12th and March 19th.

[John Falco]: 20-042 offered by Councilor Morell, whereas the City of Medford currently exercising the local option for tax deferments

[John Falco]: in accordance with Mass General Law, Chapter 59, Chapter 5, Paragraph 41A.

[John Falco]: And whereas the upper income limit set by the City of Medford for eligible residents 65 and over is $20,000 per year.

[John Falco]: The result of this, Medford City Council discussed raising the income limit to better reflect the cost of living, the cost of living and housing in Medford.

[John Falco]: Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Okay, on the motion of Council Morell to raise the cap to $50,000, seconded by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: 2-0-288, offered by Councilor Morell and Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Whereas Massachusetts House Bill 4440 seeks to allow all independent public retirement systems subject to oversight by the Public Employee Retirement Administration Commission, PRAC, to divest their holdings in full or in part from the fossil fuel industry.

[John Falco]: And whereas H4440 authorizes independent public retirement systems to exercise their fiduciary duty

[John Falco]: as defined in Mass General Law chapter 32, section 23, 3, with respect to continued investment in the fossil fuel industry.

[John Falco]: And whereas such authorization is required by PRAC, PRAC communications to the Cambridge Retirement Board, CRB, dated October 23, 2017,

[John Falco]: and to the Salvador Retirement Board, SRB, dated November 7, 2017.

[John Falco]: And whereas communities throughout Massachusetts, including Amherst, Boston, Brookline, Cambridge, Concord,

[John Falco]: Falmouth, Framingham, Great Barrington, Lexington, Lowell, Newton, Northampton, Provincetown, Somerville, Sudbury, and Truro have passed resolutions in support of fossil fuel divestment and be it resolved that the Medford City Council express its support for House Bill 4440 and urge the Massachusetts Legislature

[John Falco]: to take action to pass this measure to enable independent public retirement systems to use their prudent judgment in regards to fossil fuel divestment and

[John Falco]: We have further resolved that the city clerk forward a copy of this resolution to the Medford legislative delegation, as well as the chairs and vice chairs of all committees to which H4440 is or will be assigned.

[John Falco]: House Speaker DeLeo, Senate President Spilka, and Governor Baker.

[John Falco]: Councilor Morell, would you like to speak of it?

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: 2-0-300 offered by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the city administration establish a housing stability task force

[John Falco]: to pull together information and guidance regarding housing resources and assistance for Medford residents.

[John Falco]: Be it further resolved that the city of Medford establish a housing stability hotline that residents can call to receive information about federal, state, and city resources regarding housing stability.

[John Falco]: Be it further resolved that the city of Medford work together with private landlords to cease all activities that require landlords, inspectors,

[John Falco]: or assesses to enter housing units with current occupants for the duration of the crisis, to seize any threat or eviction or utility shutoffs, to provide information about state and federal resources regarding mortgages and other available assistance to tenants and homeowners, and to work with tenants and landlords facing financial hardships to address rent payments.

[John Falco]: If I could call on the senior member of Council of Marks to take the chair to read 2-0-3-0-8, please.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Larkin.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Back on March 11th, I went through the 40B training that was held at City Hall.

[John Falco]: I was there with Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: I think Councilor Morell was there as well.

[John Falco]: And it was actually a pretty good training session.

[John Falco]: Judy Barrett was the person, I believe, that hosted the session.

[John Falco]: And she was very knowledgeable with 40Bs.

[John Falco]: She's pretty much an expert in it, but very knowledgeable.

[John Falco]: She had a significant amount of experience.

[John Falco]: She talked specifically about 40Bs.

[John Falco]: We have 340B developments coming into our community and this is something that we really need to get on top of as a community.

[John Falco]: I mean, we have a lot going on right now, of course, with COVID-19.

[John Falco]: I'm not sure if it's a pandemic, but we really need to also jump on this as well.

[John Falco]: We need to find out, or actually the city can hire a peer team to help us out with regard to these developments.

[John Falco]: So we can hire architects, traffic engineers, civil engineers, 40B consultants that basically can help us through the process with regard to these developments that are experts in these areas that will really help the city and help safeguard

[John Falco]: you know, our best interest as a community and as a city.

[John Falco]: So simply stated, we just want to see, you know, when these peer consultants will be hired, what type of peer consultants will be hired, and if I could amend the resolution to see who is going to actually be in charge of the hiring process.

[John Falco]: Is it going to be the mayor, which I think it is, but if we could get some clarification from the administration on that, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: So next up is our reports of committees.

[John Falco]: One nine dash two eight seven.

[John Falco]: City Council's

[John Falco]: I'm sorry, with the city's chief procurement officer.

[John Falco]: And the end result was basically that an RFQ is going to go out

[John Falco]: And we should actually, I think, be getting an update on that soon.

[John Falco]: But actually, as you heard just a second ago, Councilor Caraviello offered a resolution to get a further update on that.

[John Falco]: But that was basically, we basically decided that an RFQ process would go into effect.

[John Falco]: And Ms.

[John Falco]: Khan, Shab Khan has been working on that.

[John Falco]: The 10th regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Clark Herbies, would you please call the roll?

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco?

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: All seven members are present.

[John Falco]: If I could start off the meeting just by thanking everyone for attending tonight.

[John Falco]: And if I could also just ask everyone to just please be patient.

[John Falco]: The technology is new to some of us.

[John Falco]: Some of us have had experience with it.

[John Falco]: But we're definitely learning as we go here.

[John Falco]: This is the first time we've actually had a

[John Falco]: meeting on Zoom in the history of the City Council.

[John Falco]: So we ask you for your patience and understanding.

[John Falco]: And I have a feeling by the time we get done with this, we'll all be pros.

[John Falco]: But what we're going to try to do is bring to you a meeting tonight, just as if it was like in City Hall.

[John Falco]: So at this point, I'd like to ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

[John Falco]: So tonight's broadcast, the meeting is being broadcast live on channel 22 Comcast and channel 43 Verizon.

[John Falco]: Pursuant to Governor Baker's March 12th, 2020 order suspending certain provisions of the open meeting law, general law chapter 38, section 18, and the governor's March 15th, 2020 order imposing strict limitation on the number of people that may gather in one place.

[John Falco]: This meeting of the Medford city council will be conducted via remote participation to the greatest extent possible.

[John Falco]: specific information in the general guidelines for remote participation by members of the public and or parties with the right and or requirement to attend this meeting can be found on the City of Medford website at www.medfordma.org.

[John Falco]: For this meeting, members of the public who wish to listen or watch the meeting may do so by accessing the meeting link contained herein.

[John Falco]: No in-person attendance of members of the public will be permitted.

[John Falco]: but every effort will be made to ensure that the public can adequately access the proceedings in real time via technological means.

[John Falco]: In the event that we are unable to do so despite best efforts, we will post on the City of Medford or Medford Community Media an audio or video recording, transcript, or other comprehensive record of proceedings as soon as possible after the meeting.

[John Falco]: I'm also gonna read a notice from Governor Baker.

[John Falco]: This is Office of the Governor of Commonwealth of Massachusetts, State House, Boston, Massachusetts, 02133.

[John Falco]: Order suspending certain provisions of the Open Meeting Law, General Law, Chapter 30A, Section 20.

[John Falco]: Whereas on March 10, 2020, I, Charles D. Baker, Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, acting pursuant to the powers provided by Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 in Section 2A of Chapter 17 of the General Laws, declare that there now exists in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts a state of emergency due to the outbreak of the 2019 novel coronavirus, COVID-19.

[John Falco]: And whereas,

[John Falco]: Many important functions of state and local government are executed by public bodies, as the term is defined in general law chapter 38, section 18, in meetings that are open to the public consistent with the requirements of law and sound public policy in order to ensure active public engagement with contribution to and oversight of the functions of government.

[John Falco]: Whereas both the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the CDC, and Massachusetts Department of Public

[John Falco]: The DPH have advised residents to take extra measures to put distance between themselves and other people to further reduce the risk of being exposed to COVID-19.

[John Falco]: Additionally, the CDC and DPH have advised high-risk individuals, including people over the age of 60, anyone with underlying health conditions or a weakened immune system, and pregnant women to avoid large gatherings.

[John Falco]: Whereas Section 7, 8, and 8A of Chapter 639 of the Acts of 1950 authorized the governor during the effective period of a declared emergency to exercise authority over public assemblages as necessary to protect the health and safety of persons, and whereas

[John Falco]: low-cost telephones, social media, and other internet-based technologies are currently available that will permit the convening of a public body through virtual means and allow real-time public access to the activities of the public body.

[John Falco]: And whereas Section 20 of Chapter 30A in implementing regulations issued by the Attorney General

[John Falco]: currently authorized remote participation by members of public body subject to certain limitations.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, I hereby order the following.

[John Falco]: Number one, if public body is defined in section 18 of chapter 38 of the general laws is hereby relieved from the requirement of section 20

[John Falco]: of chapter 38 that conduct its meetings in a public place that is open and physically accessible to the public, provided that the public body makes provisions to ensure public access to the deliberations of the public body for interested members of the public through adequate alternative means.

[John Falco]: Excuse me.

[John Falco]: adequate alternative means of public access shall mean measures that provide transparency and permit timely and effective public access to the deliberations of the public body.

[John Falco]: Such means may include, without limitation, providing public access through telephone, internet, or satellite,

[John Falco]: enable audio or video conferencing or any other technology that enables the public to clearly follow the proceedings of the public body while those activities are occurring.

[John Falco]: We have allowance for active real-time participation by members of the public is a specific requirement of a general or special law or regulation of law ordinance or bylaw pursuant to which the proceeding is conducted.

[John Falco]: Any alternative means of public access must provide for such participation.

[John Falco]: A municipal public body that, for reasons of economic hardship and despite best efforts, is unable to provide alternative means of public access, that will enable the public to follow the proceedings of the municipal public body as those activities are occurring in real time, may instead post on its municipal website a full and complete transcript, recording, or other comprehensive record of the proceedings as soon as practical

[John Falco]: upon conclusion of the proceedings.

[John Falco]: This paragraph shall not apply to proceedings that are conducted pursuant to a general or special law or regulation, or a local ordinance or bylaw that requires allowance for active participation by members of the public.

[John Falco]: The public body must offer its selected alternative means of access to its proceedings without subscription, toll, or similar charge to the public.

[John Falco]: Number two, public bodies are hereby authorized to allow remote participation by all members in any meeting of the public body.

[John Falco]: This requirement that a quorum of the body and the chair be physically present at a specified meeting location as provided in general law chapter 38, section 20D and in 940 CMR 29.104B is hereby suspended.

[John Falco]: Number three, a public body that elects

[John Falco]: that elects to conduct its proceedings under the relief provided in sections one or two above shall ensure that any party entitled or required to appear before it shall be able to do so through remote means.

[John Falco]: And if the party were a member of the public body and participating remotely as provided in section two.

[John Falco]: Number four, all other provisions of section 18 to 25 of chapter 30A and the Attorney General's

[John Falco]: implementing regulations shall otherwise remain unchanged and fully applicable to the activities of public bodies.

[John Falco]: This order is effective immediately.

[John Falco]: It shall remain in effect until rescinded or until the state of emergency is terminated, whichever happens first.

[John Falco]: So before I begin, I want to thank everyone for participating tonight.

[John Falco]: All of us on the city council hope that you and your family are well.

[John Falco]: I know we have a lot of people joining us tonight.

[John Falco]: And just to, so as I began, I just want to say, if you need assistance during these times, please go to the city website for information regarding food or other resources that are available.

[John Falco]: And please reach out to myself or any of my colleagues if we can help in any way.

[John Falco]: All of our contact information is on the city website as well.

[John Falco]: This is an unprecedented event that has solicited an unbelievable amount of support from the community.

[John Falco]: We would like to thank City Hall employees, volunteers, the administration, and our first responders, and our school teachers, and our school administration as well.

[John Falco]: And we'd also like to thank our health care workers for working so hard during these unprecedented times.

[John Falco]: So we thank everyone for logging in and being part of this meeting tonight.

[John Falco]: Like I said in the beginning, we ask you for your patience.

[John Falco]: This technology is new to a lot of people that are on this meeting tonight.

[John Falco]: And we will work together to move the meeting forward

[John Falco]: hopefully have it resemble a meeting that we would have normally at City Hall.

[John Falco]: So at this point here, we will begin with our first hearing.

[John Falco]: We have a number of hearings tonight.

[John Falco]: Relative to a proposed amendment by the Medford City Council to amend chapter 94 zoning article five, four.

[John Falco]: section 94-141 for adding a new general provision that states two principal structures shall not be permitted on the same lot if the principal use of both structures is residential use.

[John Falco]: The provision would apply in all districts except mixed-use zoning districts.

[John Falco]: A full copy of the text of the amendment is available at the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: Room 103, Medford City Hall, please call Medford City Clerk's office at 781-393-2425

[John Falco]: for any accommodations or aids by order of the Medford City Council, Adam L. Hurtubiseas Clark.

[John Falco]: So if I may, this is an issue that came before us previously, and we sent this to the CD board.

[John Falco]: We received a letter from Andre LaRue, the acting chair of the Community Development Board, and I will read that to you now.

[John Falco]: John T. Falco, Jr., president, Medford City Council, from Andre LaRue, acting chair, date February 5th, 2020.

[John Falco]: Council resolution 1965-2, proposed amendment to chapter 94, zoning to add a general permission to section 94-141 that prohibits two principal structures on the same lot if the principal use of both structures is a residential use.

[John Falco]: Following a duly advertised public hearing conducted on

[John Falco]: January 29, 2020, the Community Development Board voted to recommend that the Bedford City Council not adopt the proposed amendment.

[John Falco]: The Community Development Board also voted to recommend that the City Council consider a six-month moratorium on permits for two principal structures on the same lot if the principal use of both structures is a residential use.

[John Falco]: During the moratorium, the Building Commissioner would develop design guidelines.

[John Falco]: This moratorium shall not apply to permit applications filed before the date of the council vote.

[John Falco]: An exemption could be made at the discretion of the building commissioner to allow two residential structures if it results in the preservation of a historic structure on the site.

[John Falco]: Thank you for consideration of these recommendations.

[John Falco]: Andre LaRue, acting chair.

[John Falco]: And this was CC'd to Mayor Mungo Kern, Kimberly Scanlon, the acting city solicitor, Adam Hurtubise, the city clerk, and Paul Moki, the building commissioner.

[John Falco]: Medford, Massachusetts City Clerk's Office.

[John Falco]: You are hereby notified by order of the Medford City Council, a public hearing will be given via remote access utilizing Zoom on Tuesday, March 31st, 2020, on a petition of National Grid for permission to excavate the public highways and to run and maintain underground electric conduits together with such sustaining and pertaining fixtures as it may find necessary for the transmission of electricity

[John Falco]: designed or intended to protect or operate said mains and accomplish the objects of said company.

[John Falco]: In the digging up and opening the ground to lay or play same, College Ave, Medford, Massachusetts, and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk, Medford City Hall, room 10385, George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: The following are the streets and highways referred to.

[John Falco]: to install and maintain approximately 180 feet of eight-inch plastic gas main along College Avenue, Redford, Massachusetts, as shown in the plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: Location approximately as shown on the plan filed in the office of the city clerk.

[John Falco]: This is approved by the city engineer with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: Number one, the grant of location is limited to 180 feet of gas pipe as shown on the plan attached to the petition dated February 12th, 2020.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit

[John Falco]: pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: The SOP application must include a street traffic management plan.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, and any other appearances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: National grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to excavation.

[John Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[John Falco]: Number four, the sidewalk and street restoration shall be done in consultation with the engineering division in further requirements of an approved street opening permit.

[John Falco]: Number five, the proposed gas main crosses and runs parallel to the MWRA water mains.

[John Falco]: National grid must obtain

[John Falco]: 8M permits from the MWRA prior to applying for SOP.

[John Falco]: The 8M permits should be included with the SOP application.

[John Falco]: Number six, the proposed gas main is located in an area with two ongoing construction projects, the Tufts Joyce Cummings Center and the Green Line Extension Project.

[John Falco]: Traffic management plans and surface restoration must be in coordination with

[John Falco]: These projects will be reviewed during the SOP application review.

[John Falco]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations or aids.

[John Falco]: Adam L. Hurtubise, City Clerk.

[John Falco]: 2-0-089, offered by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Whereas rule 37 of the Medford City Council reads, insofar as these rules are not statutory sources of origin.

[John Falco]: The same may be amended, repealed, or suspended at any meeting by the vote of four councillors, with the exception of papers to be submitted under suspension, which requires two-thirds approval of council.

[John Falco]: Any paper to be submitted under suspension shall be read prior to the vote for suspension.

[John Falco]: Any suspension of the rules shall be put on paper prior to the vote of the suspension, so all councillors will be fully informed of the matter on which he or she will vote.

[John Falco]: If any action is taken inconsistent with these rules, the same shall be construed to have been taken in suspension thereof, provided four counsels concur in such action.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council amend Rule 37 by striking this section in its entirety and replacing it with the following.

[John Falco]: Amendment or suspension of the rules.

[John Falco]: Insofar as these rules are not statutory sources of origin, the same may be amended, repealed, or suspended at any meeting by the vote of four Councilors, with the exception of papers to be submitted under suspension, which requires two-thirds approval of the counsel.

[John Falco]: Any paper to be submitted under suspension shall be read prior to the vote for suspension.

[John Falco]: Any suspension of the rule shall be put on paper prior to the vote of the suspension so all consulars will be fully informed of the matter on which he or she will vote.

[John Falco]: Number one, papers offered under suspension for immediate consideration shall be limited to public service announcements, condolences, recognition, celebratory, and emergency matters.

[John Falco]: Number two any other papers offered at the suspension of the rule shall be tabled following in duck introduction by the sponsor without Further debate and placed on the agenda for the next regular meeting If any action is taken and consistent with these rules the same shall be construed to have been taken in Suspension there are provided for consulars concur in such action Council night

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Please have your name and address for the record.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor Peers.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Council members, if you could please have your name and address for the record.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Caraviello to move this paper to the city solicitor for legal review.

[John Falco]: All those opposed?

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: 20-090, offered by Council of the Night.

[John Falco]: Ordinance establishing an extended illness leave bank.

[John Falco]: There shall be an extended illness leave bank for employees of the city who participate therein.

[John Falco]: Extended illness advisory board appointment eligibility term.

[John Falco]: There shall be an extended illness leave bank advisory board.

[John Falco]: This board shall consist of five members that are city employees appointed by the mayor no later than 30 days following passage.

[John Falco]: These appointments shall be subject to council approval.

[John Falco]: Board members will serve a term of 24 months from the date of council confirmation.

[John Falco]: No more than two board members shall be employees at will.

[John Falco]: Administration.

[John Falco]: The director of personnel shall administer the bank in accord with the rules and regulations established by the Extended Illness Leave Bank Advisory Board and shall be precluded

[John Falco]: from serving as a member of this board.

[John Falco]: Implementation, participation requirements.

[John Falco]: The Extended Illness Advisory Board shall prescribe regulations governing its operation no later than 60 days following confirmation of its fifth member.

[John Falco]: The Extended Illness Advisory Board may alter, amend, and update these regulations from time to time thereafter by majority vote of its members.

[John Falco]: This shall make one-time investment of 75 leave days to establish the Extended Illness Leave Bank.

[John Falco]: Thereafter, any employee of the City who has completed one year of service may participate by donating to said bank any earned sick, personal, or vacation leave time in such amount

[John Falco]: with such frequency as said regulation shall permit to maintain a sufficient balance in the bank, but not less frequently than annually.

[John Falco]: Upon medical verification pursuant to such regulations, a participating employee with an extended illness who has exhausted all other earned leave

[John Falco]: And who has been on leave because of such extended illness for not less than 20 consecutive work days may obtain from said bank additional paid leave or not more than 120 days in any two year period.

[John Falco]: Current employees with all other earned leave exhausted who have been on leave because of extended illness shall be eligible to seek benefits from the Extended Illness Leave Bank retroactively to January 1st, 2020.

[John Falco]: It shall not be required to donate to said bank any earned sick, personal, or vacation leave time to participate.

[John Falco]: Said regulations shall provide safeguards against use of said bank by employees who have improperly used existing sick leave.

[John Falco]: The head of each city department shall not less than twice annually provide written notice to each employee of the opportunity to participate in said bank.

[John Falco]: Upon receipt of the first such notice, each employee shall be required to sign a form issued by the city indicating that such employee has been informed of the opportunity to participate in said bank.

[John Falco]: Nothing contained herein shall affect existing collective bargaining agreements containing provisions relating to the establishment of extended illness leave banks.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Councilor Scarpel.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, thank you for bringing this forward.

[John Falco]: I think it's long overdue.

[John Falco]: I'm glad that you brought this forward tonight.

[John Falco]: So the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Scarpelli to move this to Committee of the Whole meeting, and we will invite the city solicitor and the director of personnel.

[John Falco]: On that motion, all those in favor?

[John Falco]: All those opposed?

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: 20-091, offered by Councilor Knight, whereas Rule 18 of the rules of the Medford City Council reads, every order and resolution must be endorsed.

[John Falco]: No order or resolution shall be received or acted upon unless endorsed by a member of the Council.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council amend Rule 18 by striking the section and replacing it with the following.

[John Falco]: Every order and resolution must be endorsed.

[John Falco]: Filing of petitions.

[John Falco]: For the purposes of the section, the following definitions shall apply.

[John Falco]: Order defined as a local bylaw enacted by the City Council.

[John Falco]: Resolution defined as a paper stating an expression of opinion, fact, principle, or purpose.

[John Falco]: petition defined as an application requesting council action as required by law.

[John Falco]: No order or resolution shall be received or acted upon unless endorsed by a member of the council.

[John Falco]: The filing of petitions shall be reserved only for matters requiring council action per law, including but not limited to special permits, grants of location, signed variances, and common vigila licenses.

[John Falco]: Only petitions filed

[John Falco]: Only petitions filed meeting this criteria shall be assigned a council paper number.

[John Falco]: All other petitions filed shall be placed on the public participation portion of the agenda and not assigned a council paper number.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: And if I may add, I've had the pleasure of knowing Hank and Dennis most of my life.

[John Falco]: And Mrs. Morse did a

[John Falco]: And her husband did a fabulous job raising Hank and Dennis.

[John Falco]: They're two of the finest people I know.

[John Falco]: And our thoughts and prayers go out to the Morse family.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I'd ask everyone to please rise for a brief moment of silence.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: 20-093 offered by Council and I be it ordered that the Medford City Council hereby establish a minimum wage for all individuals in the employee of the school district and city of Medford by adopting the following ordinance.

[John Falco]: There shall be a minimum wage for all city and school district employees.

[John Falco]: This minimum wage shall be set at no less than $15 per hour.

[John Falco]: In the event the Massachusetts minimum wage exceeds $15 per hour, the employee shall receive the state minimum hourly wage.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: You are correct.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, thank you for bringing that forward.

[John Falco]: Please have your name and address for the record, please.

[John Falco]: Yes, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Knight, seconded by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: All those in favor?

[John Falco]: All those opposed?

[John Falco]: Parking spaces not enclosed in a structure may be provided anywhere on the lot except in inner court, except that no parking may be provided within the required front yards in

[John Falco]: SF1, SF2, and GR district.

[John Falco]: parking within the required front yards in SF1, SF2, and GR district.

[John Falco]: When parking is provided in a front yard, buffer strips at least three feet in width and planted with dense planting material or an opaque fence or uniform appearance should be provided on the sides of the parking area visible from the abutting streets and lots.

[John Falco]: Dear City Council, on the date of February 25th, 2020, Medford City Council, City of Medford, 85 George P. Hanson Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: Dear City Council of the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation, the DCR is considering the purchase of the fee or lesser interest including but not limited to a

[John Falco]: Permanent and perpetual easement in land located in the city of Medford state regulation at 301 CMR 5 1.0 0 Required DCR to provide written notice of any planned purchase to you in certain other public officials at least 120 days prior to purchase

[John Falco]: This letter is intended to serve as such notice.

[John Falco]: The property is located at 99 Riverside Avenue, Medford.

[John Falco]: This unique parcel is a portion of land owned by BNYH Medford LLC along the banks of the Mystic River.

[John Falco]: It shall be part of a bikeway and pedestrian pathway to be known as the Clippership Connector.

[John Falco]: The property under consideration contains 5,220,000 square feet of land.

[John Falco]: The locus map exhibited exhibit A.

[John Falco]: shows a property in which we are interested.

[John Falco]: The current owner use of the property is undeveloped open space.

[John Falco]: If acquired by the state, DCR will retain the property easement for the purpose of stated above.

[John Falco]: The applicable regulations require that an agency proposal to acquire property to be made public in a local forum.

[John Falco]: To comply with this requirement, we ask that the Board of Selectmen

[John Falco]: Announce the Commonwealth is considering the acquisition for the above stated purpose at its next regularly scheduled meeting and document the announcement of the enclosed form and return it to us in a self-addressed envelope enclosed for your convenience.

[John Falco]: Should you have any questions regarding this matter, kindly contact Sean Getchell, Director of Government Affairs at 617-626-4991.

[John Falco]: For your information, the DCR has sent similar notices to Representative Paul J. Donato, Senator Patricia Jalen, and the Metropolitan Area Planning Council.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much.

[John Falco]: Very truly yours, Arthur C. George, Assistant General Counsel.

[John Falco]: So, just wanted to bring that to everybody's attention.

[John Falco]: You're very welcome, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council,

[John Falco]: Members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts 02155 regarding Community Preservation Committee.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and City Councils, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following recommendation of the Community Preservation Committee.

[John Falco]: Number one, requesting the appropriation of $50,000 from the CPA Historic Preservation Reserve to the City of Medford Cemetery Board of Trustees in the Department of the Veterans Services for the Oak Grove Cemetery World War I Memorial Restoration Project.

[John Falco]: Petition for grant of location, National Grid, North Andover, Massachusetts, underground electric conduits.

[John Falco]: Thank you on the motion of console tonight to waive the reading for a brief synopsis by the petitioner seconded by console appears all those in favor all those opposed the motion passes at this time I would ask the representative from National Grid to please step forward and give us a brief synopsis of the project if you could start off by please stating your name and address for the record

[John Falco]: And you are in favor of the petition?

[John Falco]: Yes, I am.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: You're welcome.

[John Falco]: Please come forward.

[John Falco]: Hearing and seeing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition of the petition?

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition?

[John Falco]: Anyone in opposition?

[John Falco]: Seeing and hearing none, I declare this portion of the hearing closed.

[John Falco]: If you could please come forward again.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Are there any questions from the council at this point?

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: And I just want to make a quick note, and that is that the engineering division did review this application in a, if I'm just going to read further, just that the engineer division recommends that this grant of location be approved with the following conditions.

[John Falco]: The grant of location is limited to 60, uh, two foot, uh,

[John Falco]: Duck Bank is described in the GOL documents as follows.

[John Falco]: National grid to install beginning at a point approximately 190 feet southeast of the central line of the intersection of Winter Hill Road and continuing approximately two feet in a southwest direction.

[John Falco]: National grid to install two to four inches of conduit to riser pole 590, that's 590, to pad 87 located inside the customer's property.

[John Falco]: Number two, before starting work, the contractor shall notify dig safe and shall obtain all applicable permits from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: The project must obtain a street opening permit pursuant to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[John Falco]: Number three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other apparatances are adversely impacted.

[John Falco]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[John Falco]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[John Falco]: Asphalt must be replaced with asphalt.

[John Falco]: Number four, installing the proposed conduit will disturb the existing driveway apron for 87 Medford Street.

[John Falco]: The existing apron has hairline cracking which will worsen with this installation.

[John Falco]: The engineering division recommends that the entire driveway apron be removed and replaced.

[John Falco]: The new apron shall be six inch depth of concrete and be installed per city standard.

[John Falco]: So those are the recommendations from the engineering division.

[John Falco]: At this point, I'd recognize Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Council Knight, seconded by Councilor Bears, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Consulate Knight, seconded by Consulate Beers to approve the paper as adopted, as amended, with the conditions by the Engineering Division.

[John Falco]: On that motion, Clerk Hurtubise, please call the roll.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: The fifth regular meeting of the Medford City Council will now come to order.

[John Falco]: Present.

[John Falco]: Seven present.

[John Falco]: At this time I would ask everyone to please rise to salute the flag.

[John Falco]: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Caraviello, seconded by Councilor Knight to suspend the rules to take paper out of order.

[John Falco]: All those in favor?

[John Falco]: All those opposed?

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: 20-059, communications from the mayor.

[John Falco]: Joint resolution to make Medford hunger free.

[John Falco]: It is hereby resolved by her honor, the Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, the Honorable Medford City Council and Honorable Medford School Committee that.

[John Falco]: Whereas hunger and poverty are issues of grave concern in the United States, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and the city of Medford.

[John Falco]: Whereas Medford is committed to educating people about food insecurity and the importance of food banks and alleviating hunger in our communities.

[John Falco]: Food insecurity is a persistent and significant reality in Medford, where 1 in 10 people, 1 in 8 children, and 1 in 14 seniors do not know where their next meal will come from.

[John Falco]: Whereas the Greater Boston Food Bank and its member agencies provide vital hunger relief services to our most valuable neighbors,

[John Falco]: Whereas, Medford shall strive to work with hunger relief organizations to make Eastern Massachusetts hunger-free by supporting access to three healthy meals a day for our residents in need.

[John Falco]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the City of Medford, by her honor, the Mayor, the Honorable City Council, and the Honorable Medford School Committee, that one, Medford will set the goal to be hunger-free no later than January 1st, 2028, and two,

[John Falco]: that all residents of Medford are respectfully requested to take note of this joint resolution and participate fittingly in achieving this important and worthwhile goal.

[John Falco]: If we could please have your name and address for the record, please.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Excuse me, if you could come forward, just because there's people watching at home on TV, and so everyone gets the correct information.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Okay.

[John Falco]: Oh, Councilor Marks first.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: And before I call the roll, or before the clerk calls the roll, I'd just like to thank everyone for coming down tonight to speak on this issue.

[John Falco]: It's a very important issue that actually, it has an impact on so many people throughout this community.

[John Falco]: And I think far too many times people think, or just under the assumption that everyone has a meal, when everyone does not.

[John Falco]: And it's something that needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: 20-053 offered by Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council meet in Committee of the Whole to discuss the report of the acting city solicitor regarding a draft ordinance enabling the establishment of a payment in lieu of taxes pilot commissioned as requested by Councilor, I'm sorry, as requested by the Council in paper 20-021.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: On the motion of Councilor Bears, seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: All those in favor?

[John Falco]: Aye.

[John Falco]: All those opposed?

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: I would ask at this point if Councilor Marks could please share the next two motions.

[John Falco]: There you go.

[John Falco]: Turn these off for you.

[John Falco]: You don't have to turn it off.

[John Falco]: You know what?

[John Falco]: Yeah, I can get it for you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: As Councilor Caraviello noted, we actually talked to the representative, or representative at the MMA conference.

[John Falco]: And it's definitely, I think, something that we should pursue.

[John Falco]: And that's why we're recommending a pilot program, thinking that this would be a nice idea to try out on some of our streets.

[John Falco]: It would definitely save the city some money.

[John Falco]: And it definitely has some benefits as well.

[John Falco]: I mean, if you take a look at the number of streets that we're repaving each year, we're very limited to what we can do with the funds that we have.

[John Falco]: So this is kind of an out-of-the-box, kind of thinking out-of-the-box type of solution where we could do something with the recycled asphalt.

[John Falco]: And there's definitely some benefits to it.

[John Falco]: It uses in-place materials that are already there in front of you.

[John Falco]: They actually do it all right there, recycle it right on site.

[John Falco]: And like I said, it saves money.

[John Falco]: It's a shorter construction time to actually repave a road.

[John Falco]: And it's easier to work around catch basins, manholes, water valves, and other type of things that you'll find in the middle of the street when you're repaving a road.

[John Falco]: And it also lowers the engineering and traffic control costs as well.

[John Falco]: So this is an idea that we wanted to bring forward.

[John Falco]: We think it would be beneficial to our community and actually save the community money as well.

[John Falco]: So at this point I'd like to move for approval.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Yeah that If I may I think there'll be a pretty big capital cost to buy that machine I think the best thing in my own speak for Councilor caviar, but I think we would agree in this I think through the pilot program if we could pick out You know a handful of streets that this probably bring in a rep from one of these companies because I'm sure there's many that do it and actually talk to them and

[John Falco]: and see, well, what type of streets will this work on?

[John Falco]: And then pick a handful of streets, come up with a pilot program, and just resurface those streets with recycled asphalt.

[John Falco]: And then, of course, get a price.

[John Falco]: So I mean, get a price beforehand.

[John Falco]: But see how many streets we could do.

[John Falco]: Try to figure out if we could have like a, the mayor has some sort of a budget for this.

[John Falco]: And then see what we can do.

[John Falco]: And it's definitely more efficient, I think, in lower cost than what we're doing now.

[John Falco]: We have very limited funding, chapter 90 funding for street repair.

[John Falco]: So I think this would hopefully allow us to do more streets.

[John Falco]: just make our money go further, so I think developing a pilot program around this would be something that would be beneficial.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: And this here is another solution where it's just a more efficient solution, where it's not going to cost as much money.

[John Falco]: Because with a lot of these trip sidewalks, trip and fall sidewalks, it's just an edge that pops up.

[John Falco]: So what they do is they literally cut the edge, flatten it down.

[John Falco]: They don't have to replace the whole panel.

[John Falco]: It doesn't take days, it literally takes probably hours.

[John Falco]: The sidewalk's not out of service, it's not costing you as much money because you don't have to replace the whole thing.

[John Falco]: You don't have to worry about someone destroying the cement when it's trying to dry.

[John Falco]: So it's definitely more efficient.

[John Falco]: It's a concept that's used in other communities, Cambridge, Quincy, Newton, Lowell, Salem, Swampsford, Haverhill, Westfield, Peabody.

[John Falco]: So that's just some of them.

[John Falco]: They use this, I guess, at Gillette Stadium as well.

[John Falco]: And they use it at different colleges, BC, UMass, Lowell.

[John Falco]: So there's a bunch of colleges that use this as well.

[John Falco]: So it's definitely more efficient for our community, and it would save the community money as well.

[John Falco]: So I'd just like to move the paper forward at this point in time.

[John Falco]: Move for approval.

[John Falco]: want to read it?
