[John Falco]: We have one more paper, Councilman.

[John Falco]: Vice President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Of course, I'm in full support of this.

[John Falco]: This is something that many residents have called about.

[John Falco]: I think our goal is always to try to get more people involved in government in what's happening throughout the community.

[John Falco]: And a way of doing this is to actually have meetings that make sense for the majority of the population.

[John Falco]: Having meetings during the afternoon does not work for a lot of people.

[John Falco]: And for many people throughout our community, you know, having meetings at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

[John Falco]: I think Councilor Marks, you mentioned it earlier with regard to the Verizon hearing.

[John Falco]: I mean, that doesn't make sense.

[John Falco]: It doesn't really make sense to have meetings at 2 o'clock in the afternoon if you want the general public to attend.

[John Falco]: Most people are working.

[John Falco]: They're picking up their kids from school.

[John Falco]: They might have other appointments as well.

[John Falco]: So I think, you know, having meetings anytime after 6 p.m.

[John Falco]: makes complete sense.

[John Falco]: Most of the general public can come to meetings at that time, and I think it's something that we need to make sure that this happens, to make sure that, you know, in the sense of transparency, in the sense of getting people involved in what's going on throughout the community, I think it'd be in the benefit of most people throughout this community, and the city in general, that we make sure that these meetings are held, you know, anytime after 6 p.m.

[John Falco]: So I thank you very much.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight, as well.

[John Falco]: All those in favor?

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: Reports of committees, 2-0-017, Committee of the Whole meeting report, Wednesday, January 15, 2020 at 6 p.m.

[John Falco]: in room 207, Council Office, Medford City Hall.

[John Falco]: We met last Wednesday as a Committee of the Whole to discuss the priorities for the Medford City Council for this year, 2020.

[John Falco]: We went through

[John Falco]: A number of items ranging from the basic city services and how to actually provide them more efficiently.

[John Falco]: We talked a little bit about headcount in each of the departments and hopefully increasing headcount.

[John Falco]: We talked about meetings, regular meetings with department heads ahead of the budget season.

[John Falco]: So if we have any questions we can ask them.

[John Falco]: before the budget is crafted for the upcoming year.

[John Falco]: We talked a little bit about strategic about a strategic master plan.

[John Falco]: We talked about meeting with the mayor and we will I'll be scheduling that soon.

[John Falco]: I'll be reaching out to the mayor's office to discuss our priorities with her so we can invite her to committee the whole meeting.

[John Falco]: We talked about housing, inclusionary zoning,

[John Falco]: We talked about the traffic commission meetings as well.

[John Falco]: We also talked about

[John Falco]: Let's see we talked about actually the city council Having a legal services line item so that the council can have its own legal counsel of various priorities including city ordinances in other Items, and I think that's something that the council agrees on would go a long way Especially the number of ordinances that we're trying to write at this point in time We talked about revenue priorities.

[John Falco]: We talked about various ordinances that we have to work on in the upcoming year and

[John Falco]: We talked about citywide technology, pedestrian safety.

[John Falco]: We talked about the behavioral health commission.

[John Falco]: We talked about breweries ordinance, food trucks.

[John Falco]: Talked a little bit about taxes.

[John Falco]: So the meeting wasn't limited to that, but we talked about a far-ranging number of issues and priorities for the upcoming year.

[John Falco]: And to say the least, it will be a very busy year, a lot of meetings, but I think there's a lot of work that needs to get done, and I know we can get it done together.

[John Falco]: So on the motion of Councilor Caraviello to approve the committee report, seconded by Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: If I could?

[John Falco]: Yes, of course.

[John Falco]: Karl Marx.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: I'm looking to, like I said, schedule a meeting soon with the mayor, and have the mayor come to Committee of the Whole so we can all talk together, and then we'll hopefully schedule some department head meetings after that to get working on those issues.

[John Falco]: At this point, I recognize Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Not just spreadsheets.

[John Falco]: Back a few years ago, when I first got on the council, that was one of my big priorities, was getting a budget with a narrative.

[John Falco]: Correct, so we're hoping to continue forward with that, and I would think and hope that the mayor would as well.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Consulate Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Consulate Beers.

[John Falco]: Thank you very much.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Consulate Beers.

[John Falco]: Seconded by Consulate Morell.

[John Falco]: All those in favor.

[John Falco]: All those opposed.

[John Falco]: The motion passes.

[John Falco]: There you go.

[John Falco]: Yes, I do.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: I'd like to congratulate Kevin Wright on earning his Eagle Scout.

[John Falco]: As we all know,

[John Falco]: Earning the rank of Eagle is not easy.

[John Falco]: And it's hard and takes a lot of commitment and dedication.

[John Falco]: I've known Kevin for a long time.

[John Falco]: He goes to Bedford Public Schools.

[John Falco]: He's dedicated to our community.

[John Falco]: His Eagle Scout project was to build a park bench.

[John Falco]: He built a park bench and a lending library for the senior center.

[John Falco]: And so he worked hard on that.

[John Falco]: And he's been volunteering for many years throughout the community along with his parents.

[John Falco]: And I'd like to invite him to a future council meeting to be recognized by the Medford City Council and congratulate him on earning the rank of Eagle.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: As we all know, you know,

[John Falco]: Our fine city has become a very popular place to rent, buy a home, or raise a family.

[John Falco]: Being only five miles north of Boston, Medford is a very desirable location with great schools, direct access to Boston, and access to a lot of green space.

[John Falco]: We also know that to buy a home in our community, it takes a lot of money.

[John Falco]: Homes that once sold for $300,000, $400,000, $500,000 are now selling for $600,000, $700,000, $800,000, if not higher.

[John Falco]: And I know as I walk and see people throughout the community, this always comes up as an issue.

[John Falco]: And a lot of people ask, well, where will the kids that are growing up today in our city, will they be able to afford to buy a home here in our city, a city that we all love?

[John Falco]: And that really becomes a really tough question to answer.

[John Falco]: And if you go online, you'll see many articles regarding the housing crisis, not only in Boston, but also in the greater Boston area, but here in Medford.

[John Falco]: Tonight, I ask my colleagues to support this resolution that I offer tonight.

[John Falco]: I firmly believe that it's time that we establish an affordable housing trust.

[John Falco]: Although the concept is not new, there are many communities throughout the Commonwealth that have shown increased interest in forming their own municipal housing trust funds.

[John Falco]: In 2005, the state legislature passed the Municipal Affordable Housing Trust Fund law to simplify the process of establishing local housing trust funds.

[John Falco]: Since the law passed, 98 communities in Massachusetts have established Municipal Affordable Housing Trusts, raising the overall total number of communities with housing trust to approximately 109.

[John Falco]: Examples of what a local affordable housing trust can do include provide financial support for the construction of affordable homes by private developers, both for-profit and not-for-profit, rehabilitate existing homes to convert to affordable housing, increase affordability in new housing development projects, develop service municipal land or buildings, preserve properties faced with expiring affordability restrictions,

[John Falco]: and support rent assistance for low and moderate income households.

[John Falco]: What funds can local housing trusts use?

[John Falco]: The sources of funding can vary.

[John Falco]: You can use community preservation CPA funds.

[John Falco]: They can use inclusionary zoning payments, negotiating development fees.

[John Falco]: developer fees, the municipality's general fund, tax titles and sales, payments from special bylaws and ordinances, cell tower lease payments, private donations, that's to name a few.

[John Falco]: But it seems like in most communities, CPA funds are definitely, you know, what's used I think most of the time.

[John Falco]: So in your package tonight, I included a boil plate template of some draft language

[John Falco]: that we could use to establish a Municipal Affordable Housing Trust Ordinance.

[John Falco]: Now this is an extant stone.

[John Falco]: I mean, what I'd like to see is us as a committee meet to actually work through this ordinance and actually develop something that's gonna benefit our community.

[John Falco]: There are many resources that we can use to do this.

[John Falco]: So this is just a boilerplate template of what we need to do and what one would look like.

[John Falco]: So at this point, I would ask my council colleagues to support this resolution.

[John Falco]: And I would ask that we move this

[John Falco]: to the committee the whole and the reason why I don't want it to go to ordinance committee or I wish for it to go to committee the whole as I think this is a great learning opportunity for all of us over the next you know I think during this term there's going to be a lot of issues that come before us with regard to zoning with regard to housing and I think it's important that we all work on this together because I think this is going to benefit our community we should all have a say in this so at this point I would ask

[John Falco]: my council colleagues to support this, and if you could move this to Committee of the Whole for further review and debate.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello, and thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Those are just options.

[John Falco]: I'm not recommending that we do that.

[John Falco]: Like I said, this is a boil plate.

[John Falco]: It's something to look at to get the conversation started.

[John Falco]: That's why it would go to committee of the whole to actually go through those list of options of what's available to us, not holding us to anything here.

[John Falco]: Nothing's etched in stone here.

[John Falco]: This is just some of what other communities have used.

[John Falco]: I just literally went through a list of things that I saw in the research that I did.

[John Falco]: But I'm not saying we have to do this.

[John Falco]: I completely understand your concern and it's valid, but I was just laying it out there as options of what other communities have done.

[John Falco]: But by no means am I saying that anything is final here.

[John Falco]: This is boilerplate, sample language, sample ideas, that's all it is.

[John Falco]: My goal tonight is basically just to get everyone on board of You know moving this to committee the whole so we can talk about it and work through and build an ordinance of our own That's basically the goal for tonight.

[John Falco]: There's no specifics as to what I want to do here with regard to You know how we would spend the funds or obtain the funds or anything like that So, thank you.

[John Falco]: Records.

[John Falco]: The records of the meeting of January 7th were passed to Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Communications from the Mayor.

[John Falco]: 20-013, December 31st, 2019, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155.

[John Falco]: Dear Mr. President and city councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following home rule petition to be sent to the general court regarding certain funds and expenditures by the city of Medford received through its surrounding community agreement.

[John Falco]: homeowner petition, an act of authorizing the city of Medford to utilize funds received from the surrounding community agreement entered into between the city of Medford and Windmass LLC for the purposes set forth in the agreement.

[John Falco]: Be it hereby resolved that the Legislature of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts enact this Home Rule petition to allow the City of Medford to utilize funds received from the Surrounded Community Agreement executed on April 11, 2014 between the City of Medford and Windmass, LLC.

[John Falco]: or its surrounding, I'm sorry, or its successors or assigns for the purposes that are set forth in said agreement or as amended.

[John Falco]: To accomplish these purposes, the city of Medford is authorized without the necessity of any further approval to create a special revenue fund.

[John Falco]: The legislature may reasonably vary the form and substance of the requested legislation within the scope of the general objectives of this petition.

[John Falco]: be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives in general court assembled and by the authority of the same as follows.

[John Falco]: Section 1, notwithstanding any provision of the Massachusetts general laws or the provisions of any general law, special law, or regulation to the contrary,

[John Falco]: The City of Medford, through the Mayor of the City of Medford, may, without further appropriation, utilize and expend all funds received by way of the surrounding community agreement executed on April 11, 2014, between the City of Medford and Windmass, LLC, or its successes or signs, for the purposes that are set forth in the said agreement or as amended.

[John Falco]: Section two.

[John Falco]: This act shall take effect upon its passage and shall be effective during the present fiscal year.

[John Falco]: Respectfully submitted, Mayor Stephanie M. Burke.

[John Falco]: We have a representative from the administration here tonight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Council Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Marks.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilmarks.

[John Falco]: Council Morell.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Morell.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Bears.

[John Falco]: Point of information, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: Councilor Knight, one minute please.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I want to thank Councilor Scarpelli for bringing this forward tonight.

[John Falco]: and all the play structures, just to make sure everything's safe, especially after the winter and the cold weather when things rust and things crack and break and whatnot.

[John Falco]: So if we could have those inspected as well.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Yes I do, Mr. President, thank you.

[John Falco]: We had a subcommittee on zoning on February 6th, 2018 at 6 p.m.

[John Falco]: And the members of this subcommittee are myself, Councilor Knight, and Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[John Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to review all papers assigned to the subcommittee of zoning and ordinances and to review zoning.

[John Falco]: So at the beginning of this term, Mr. President, you decided to split these former zoning and ordinance subcommittee to two separate subcommittees.

[John Falco]: One was zoning and one is ordinance.

[John Falco]: So what we did is we actually just went through the papers that were in committee and we moved

[John Falco]: Papers 16555, 16660, 16705, 17542, 17094, 17321, and 17320 to the subcommittee on ordinances.

[John Falco]: Papers 16-359, 16-338.

[John Falco]: 16, 6, 2, 6, and 16, 6, 6, 6 are staying in the zoning subcommittee.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. Superintendent.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Chief Sacco.

[John Falco]: I find everything to be very alarming.

[John Falco]: As a father of three kids in the Medford Public Schools, I always feel that my kids are safe.

[John Falco]: And now I see something like this today, and I feel they're safe, but I have concerns.

[John Falco]: And I think they're very valid concerns.

[John Falco]: You know, as far as, you know, when we notify police about an incident like this, do we have a clear policy as to when?

[John Falco]: I mean, to me, there should be a clear, you know, I watch the commercials, I hear it on the radio, I see it on TV.

[John Falco]: See something, say something.

[John Falco]: I tell my kids that.

[John Falco]: You know, and I think it's a good theory to go by.

[John Falco]: Because I think, you know, we need to,

[John Falco]: keep law enforcement active and engaged in what's going on.

[John Falco]: To me, this is a clear case where see something, say something should have been the appropriate choice.

[John Falco]: Do we have a clear policy that says in this situation, there's some sort of ammunition and I'm no gun expert, but there's some sort of weapon that we contact the police.

[John Falco]: Yes, I have.

[John Falco]: What I would like to see is I would like to see the school committee work on a clear policy.

[John Falco]: But I think the parents as well, because if you're going to notify the school committee, that's going to go out to the general public.

[John Falco]: So the general public should hear from our school leader, the superintendent saying, this is a concern.

[John Falco]: This is what's been found.

[John Falco]: This is what we think is happening.

[John Falco]: I mean, getting input from the chief as well.

[John Falco]: I think, you know,

[John Falco]: You know, I understand that there are probably certain issues that are minor, that maybe not everyone needs to know about, if there's a fight in the playground or something like that.

[John Falco]: But something like this, where there's a piece of ammunition that's found, you know, within the school building, that that's a concern.

[John Falco]: And that's a concern that many people have here tonight.

[John Falco]: There's many people that are watching at home that have this concern.

[John Falco]: And I know all of us behind this rail have the same concern.

[John Falco]: Mr. Superintendent, I would honestly like to see you, the police chief Sacco, and the

[John Falco]: the mayor and the school committee come together and formulate a policy as to, you know, when, you know, to actually put a policy in place, when should the police be contacted about an issue like this?

[John Falco]: Because I think there needs to be a clear definition, in my opinion.

[John Falco]: I mean, I'd like to see that.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: There was a matter earlier tonight, the Committee of the Whole, to review a open meeting law complaint.

[John Falco]: And we found that the complaint was not valid.

[John Falco]: Yes, and the city solicitor will be writing up a response to the person that made the claim to, I believe, the Attorney General's Office.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Caraviello.

[John Falco]: Thank you, President Caraviello.

[John Falco]: I will actually read this so everybody can hear it.

[John Falco]: Whereas the City of Bedford has long been a municipal leader in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in environmental stewardship, including creating the first municipal climate action plan, erecting the first municipal scale wind turbine in the state, installing solar panels in energy efficient LED lighting, among other initiatives.

[John Falco]: Whereas the city of Medford is blessed with nearly one-third open space with its 8.6 square miles, including the Mystic Lakes, Mystic River, and Wrights Pond, which provide valuable habitat for wildlife and recreational opportunities for residents.

[John Falco]: Whereas millions of non-biodegradable plastic bags are used in Medford each year, creating litter, polluting our streets, parks, and waterways, harming wildlife, and potentially causing harm to human infants.

[John Falco]: Whereas plastic bags are difficult to recycle and frequently contaminate material and damage equipment used to process items collected through the city's single stream curbside recycling program.

[John Falco]: Whereas reusable bags are considered to be the best option to reduce waste

[John Falco]: and litter, protect wildlife and conserve resources, and that many inexpensive and convenient varieties are increasingly available and used by Medford residents and visitors, whereas a number of businesses in the city have already taken affirmative steps to encourage the use of reusable bags by their patrons.

[John Falco]: Whereas 61 cities and towns in the Commonwealth, including neighboring Somerville and Arlington, and nearby Cambridge, Boston, and Melrose have enacted ordinances governing the use of plastic bags in their communities.

[John Falco]: Be it resolved that the City of Medford, working with the Medford City Council, the Energy and Environment Health and Law Departments, the Energy and Environment Committee, SEEM, Student Environmental Advocates of Medford,

[John Falco]: the Medford Chamber of Commerce and city merchants and its citizenry create an ordinance that will govern and ultimately phase out the use of plastic bags at all points of sale in the city to decrease damage to our environment, reduce litter and waste removal costs, and improve public health without being detrimental to conducting business in our city.

[John Falco]: Mr. President, if I may.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Tonight I offer this resolution because I believe it is an important issue that has a deep and lasting negative impact on our city, its residents, and our environment.

[John Falco]: There are many reasons why we should ban plastic bags.

[John Falco]: I'll name a few but there are plenty.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags create a major litter problem.

[John Falco]: Visual blight when they blow into trees.

[John Falco]: They're the third largest type of litter from land-based sources found on U.S.

[John Falco]: coasts.

[John Falco]: They pollute our oceans, rivers, and landscapes.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags are a hazard to marine life, seabirds, animals.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags do not biodegrade, and although they do fragment through mechanical action and photodegradation in the presence of light, these processes are slow, taking an estimated 200 plus years to complete.

[John Falco]: Polyethylene bags are made from non-renewable fossil fuels.

[John Falco]: The over 100 billion plastic shopping bags used each year in the United States are made up of the estimated equivalent of 439 million gallons of oil.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags clog storm water drains.

[John Falco]: They're consumed in extremely high volumes.

[John Falco]: Consumers, more often than not, do not recycle plastic bags.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags contribute to overburdened landfills.

[John Falco]: While researching this issue, and I mentioned this earlier, plastic bags are banned in over 60 plus cities and towns in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: Plastic bags are banned in over 40 countries.

[John Falco]: It is time that we add our city to the list of the 60 plus cities and towns that have ordinances that ban plastic bags.

[John Falco]: Recently, I was approached by individual residents, organizations, and students

[John Falco]: with regard to offering a resolution to banning plastic bags in our community.

[John Falco]: At Medford High School, we have a great program called the Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility.

[John Falco]: Within the Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility, we have seen student environmental advocates of Medford.

[John Falco]: This group has been working hard on this issue and other environmental issues along with the Energy and Environment Committee as well.

[John Falco]: Surveys have shown that plastic carryout bags are used for approximately 12 minutes and then discarded.

[John Falco]: With that being said, we need to evaluate if we as a community value the use of a plastic bag often used for a few minutes more than protecting our environment from the devastating long-lasting effects of plastic bags.

[John Falco]: As a father of three children, it is my hope to leave this community a better place for our children and our grandchildren.

[John Falco]: This is a start.

[John Falco]: Let's use this resolution tonight as a launching pad to develop a city ordinance to ban plastic bags in the City of Medford.

[John Falco]: I thank you for your time and I respectfully ask my colleagues for the consideration

[John Falco]: And I believe that we should move this to the subcommittee on ordinances, where we can have an ordinance developed and designed.

[John Falco]: And if I may, Mr. President, I'd like to amend this resolution.

[John Falco]: And I'd like to amend it until we actually get an ordinance in place.

[John Falco]: I'd like to see the city set up plastic bag recycling stations in each of our public buildings, City Hall.

[John Falco]: the library, we can come up with a list.

[John Falco]: But I think that we should do that to actually at least get the ball rolling until we actually have a formal ordinance in place.

[John Falco]: At this point in time, I know there are a number of people that would like to speak on this issue.

[John Falco]: If I could bring up Rubia, who is from the library.

[John Falco]: for Medford High School, and she has a number of packets that she'd like to give out as well.

[John Falco]: She's from the Student Environmental Advocates of Medford.

[John Falco]: Do you want to speak if we so if we made this seems to be.

[John Falco]: a little discussion, I guess, as to where they should go next.

[John Falco]: And I know for me, one of the big pieces of this resolution in coming up with a final resolution and adopting resolution is to make sure there's involvement from the different groups that are here tonight.

[John Falco]: Because a lot of these people here tonight are on the front lines.

[John Falco]: They have experience in this area.

[John Falco]: They've researched this already.

[John Falco]: So I want to make sure that they're involved, and that's important.

[John Falco]: I think at this point the best bet is why don't we

[John Falco]: move it to Committee of the Whole, get input from, actually no, let's do this.

[John Falco]: I think the best thing is, let's go to City Solicitor Romley, let's get a draft first of what we think it should be, what he thinks would be a good way to start, I guess, looking at other resolutions, or other ordinances, I guess, from other cities, and then we'll push it to Committee of the Whole to have, I think, probably the Council weigh in, and then,

[John Falco]: I want to make sure there's plenty of community involvement.

[John Falco]: There's a lot of groups here, a lot of people here that are interested in something, that are interested in the ordinance, but I want to make sure that we're starting off with something.

[John Falco]: And I think if we all get into a room, we're just throwing thoughts and ideas around, it could get kind of messy.

[John Falco]: So I'm thinking if we start off with getting some sort of a draft resolution,

[John Falco]: from the city solicitor, and then from that point, we can get together and bring in the groups and the council as well to give input.

[John Falco]: Yes, that would be the that would be the point of bringing it back to community the whole because I want to make sure that each consulate gets to weigh in.

[John Falco]: But I want to make sure that the residents get to weigh in, especially, you know, rubia and the students at Bedford High School that have been working on this.

[John Falco]: I mean, I believe you've got a number of you had a petition that went out as well.

[John Falco]: So a lot of people are interested in this and it needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: But I want to make sure there's plenty of community involvement.

[John Falco]: And that's what this is all about.

[John Falco]: There are a lot of people that want to weigh in on this issue.

[John Falco]: But I think we need to start somewhere.

[John Falco]: So I think if we have a draft.

[John Falco]: Exactly.

[John Falco]: So I mean, I think we have a bunch of people in a room just firing ideas around.

[John Falco]: I think that might get kind of messy.

[John Falco]: So I think if we have some sort of a draft resolution first and then we can make adjustments and changes, that would probably be the best.

[John Falco]: Every ordinance goes through three readings.

[John Falco]: Absolutely.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Councilor McGrath.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: This is an item that I have brought before the council before in the past, and the council supported it unanimously in the past and has not been included in past budgets, and it's something that

[John Falco]: I've strongly advocated for before, and I continue to do so.

[John Falco]: We expect our residents to clear their sidewalks after it snows, and the city should be doing the same thing with regard to city properties and sidewalks as well.

[John Falco]: You know, we see our students, you know, they walk to and from school, residents walk when it snows out, and it's important to keep our sidewalks clean of snow.

[John Falco]: And it's basically a public safety issue.

[John Falco]: And now when you bring the Chevalier Theater on board now with running shows during the winter and whatnot, you know, we're asking people to walk from the parking lots here at City Hall

[John Falco]: to Chevalier Theatre, and that's another reason why we should have a piece of machinery like this that can clear the snow.

[John Falco]: And it's important that we give our city workers, the DBW workers, the tools that they need, and I'm happy to say that we received a paper tonight

[John Falco]: from the mayor's office, and I'll read it.

[John Falco]: It's in response to the resolution that I offered, and it's from, let's see, it's from Brian Kerentz.

[John Falco]: It's a commissioner of public works, and it's in response to Councilor Falco's resolution.

[John Falco]: 18-008.

[John Falco]: After meeting with Mayor Stephanie M. Burke on Thursday, December 28th, regarding the purchase of a trackless plow for the Department of Public Works to better clear sidewalks during the winter months, we will be purchasing one for $130,545.

[John Falco]: The machine is called the Holder, and it is made in Canada.

[John Falco]: The local dealer for this machine is in Chelmsford, Massachusetts.

[John Falco]: The machine will have a snowblower attachment, a power reversible plow blade, and a dump body and a sander unit.

[John Falco]: So happy to say that this issue sounds like it's being addressed.

[John Falco]: Mr. President, if you wouldn't mind, if we could get just a further answer with regard to the timing on this, when we should actually see this piece of machinery here in our city and when we could actually see, may possibly see it in service.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: That means shut it down.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Who actually put limitations on the stop work order, or the cease and desist order?

[John Falco]: And I also want to find out when it was issued.

[John Falco]: I know you came down and we actually, Councilman Markson.

[John Falco]: If we can just get confirmation on that.

[John Falco]: But I do agree, I think a

[John Falco]: Okay, then I do agree that an emergency meeting is warranted and we should be doing that.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I was actually on the way to work this morning and coming on the on-ramp onto 93 and driving by 101, George P. Hassett Drive.

[John Falco]: The address is 101, but you can see it's the building is boarded up, but in the lower half of the building towards the basement, there is a board.

[John Falco]: The boards have fallen off the building and the windows are broken and the whole bottom half of the building is exposed.

[John Falco]: Anyone can get in there, kids, homeless people, I mean anyone has access to it.

[John Falco]: So it's a bit of a safety concern that needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: So if we could have the administration reach out to the landlord of that building to have that boarded up immediately, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: And if I could further amend the paper to basically get some sort of an update from the landlord as to

[John Falco]: what they plan to do with the building.

[John Falco]: I believe it's going to be a hotel, or at one point we were told it was going to be a hotel, but maybe get an update on the timetable.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: City solicitor Romley, if I may ask a few questions.

[John Falco]: So is this enforceable as far as if we were to vote for this change?

[John Falco]: I mean, is it enforceable as far as from, I mean, I guess you could always appeal it, but I mean, do we have any grounds to enforce this, I guess?

[John Falco]: So I mean, I think it's interesting, and I think it's definitely, I definitely like notifying more people.

[John Falco]: I think that's a good thing.

[John Falco]: I just have, I guess, some concerns that there's like unintended consequences here.

[John Falco]: So for like the local person that's trying to make a home improvement, put a deck on the back of their house, and they need a variance, maybe they're too close to the property line.

[John Falco]: So if they have that type of a situation, that person is going to have to notify

[John Falco]: everyone within that 400 foot?

[John Falco]: That's my concern, because I definitely like the idea of making sure that we notify more people.

[John Falco]: But I guess I'm worried about once you get into the neighborhoods, if you're doing something to increase the value of your property.

[John Falco]: Maybe you're putting on a deck.

[John Falco]: You're doing some sort of home improvement.

[John Falco]: And it's not that major.

[John Falco]: There's a concern, I think, that you're adding a cost to that.

[John Falco]: And there's just a little bit of a concern there.

[John Falco]: So I think for big developments, this is something that's definitely needed and warranted.

[John Falco]: I mean, I think it's definitely something that would benefit the whole neighborhood.

[John Falco]: But for someone that's doing a small type of home improvement, I have some concerns there.

[John Falco]: my colleague wouldn't mind if we could amend this maybe just to projects that have to go through site plan review.

[John Falco]: And I'm not sure if that makes sense.

[John Falco]: Maybe you could weigh in on that.

[John Falco]: But I'm just thinking that if we're going to have local, my concern is that if we're going to have local neighbors that want to make an improvement and add cost to that and add more red tape to that, I think that's a little bit of a concern.

[John Falco]: So I'm just thinking if maybe we could have this applied to any type of

[John Falco]: project that requires site plan review.

[John Falco]: Maybe that's the direction we should head in, and that's an amendment to the resolution that I would offer if my colleague is willing to accept that.

[John Falco]: And I appreciate that.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: That's just my concern.

[John Falco]: I mean, I think it's a great, I mean, I like the resolution.

[John Falco]: I think it's, I think we should be reaching out to talk to more, to actually communicate with more people in the neighborhood when there's a project or development that's going to impact them.

[John Falco]: So more communication is definitely better.

[John Falco]: I just wonder if, you know,

[John Falco]: if there's some unintended consequences to this where we're gonna impact them financially and make a simple home improvement into a larger type of project.

[John Falco]: So that's why I offer the resolution if you're willing that maybe we have this apply just to something that requires site plan review.

[John Falco]: I'm done for now.

[John Falco]: Yes.

[John Falco]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[John Falco]: Is this the amendment, is this the motion with ritual methods?

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you.

[John Falco]: And I agree with the resolution.

[John Falco]: I think it's a good resolution, but I do think that, and I don't think you're trying to do this on purpose, but I think there's unintended consequences that we're really, there's a cost associated with this.

[John Falco]: And it's borne by the taxpayer, the person that owns the property.

[John Falco]: And that's the piece that I guess I'm guarding against.

[John Falco]: So the only thing I'm saying is if we add the amendment in, we're at least giving some guidance to the community development board to say, you know, there is an amendment here to see what the public thinks about the amendment.

[John Falco]: To send them the language, I think we're at least giving them a little bit more guidance if we're actually adding the amendment in as to what we're thinking.

[John Falco]: I mean, it seems like there's definitely some sort of an appetite for the amendment that was offered.

[John Falco]: If I may, because I think that is definitely a legitimate concern about when you're adding units to existing units.

[John Falco]: So if we can work on a compromise, I'm all for it.

[John Falco]: you know, something.

[John Falco]: A housing unit is to be added.

[John Falco]: Yeah, or if an existing unit is adding additional units, can we, can we, or if you have a recommendation as to some order.

[John Falco]: I'd be fine with that amendment.

[John Falco]: This issue is recently, actually, it's gotten better.

[John Falco]: in the morning, and that's helped out tremendously with regard to the traffic that flows down Brackett Street onto Andrew Street and all the surrounding streets, and it has significantly lessened the traffic on Fulton Street in the morning.

[John Falco]: You know, it's impossible to do constant nonstop enforcement.

[John Falco]: So there are people that do take that, depending on which way you're coming down Elm, they'll take a right or a left to go down Brackett.

[John Falco]: So I'm just basically asking that if we could have a no right hand.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I received a call from a number of residents down on Windsor Road regarding it's a divot.

[John Falco]: It looks like it's actually maybe some trench work that was done before in the past and it's sunk over time.

[John Falco]: So if we could just have the DPW go by and just try to fill that in.

[John Falco]: to level the surface in the interest of public safety.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: I received a number of calls from people in this neighborhood or residents in this neighborhood asking about placing a stop line on the ground next to the stop signs.

[John Falco]: This is a, it seems like with the

[John Falco]: So many people using Waze now, the app that sends people through neighborhoods that, you know, there's increased traffic and there's a lot of kids in this area that traverse back and forth to the Roberts Elementary School.

[John Falco]: And so this is a safety issue that needs to be addressed.

[John Falco]: So if we could have a stop line placed on both ends of that street in the matter of, in the interest of public safety, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: And if we could actually forward this to the Traffic Commission for their approval as well.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco?

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. Warren, for your presentation.

[John Falco]: Just a couple of quick questions here.

[John Falco]: So I've only been on the council for about two years now.

[John Falco]: And we own it, and we should be embracing this.

[John Falco]: This is a project that I think that's good.

[John Falco]: There's a lot of potential.

[John Falco]: Greatly appreciate it.

[John Falco]: And I second the motion.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: And the reason why I amended it was because it did come up at a police community meeting and the police officers that I talked to that were in the room and the detectives, they had mentioned that all the surrounding communities had these cameras in the very useful, uh, in, you know, especially if a crime has happened, you know, they can always consult the cameras or if there's a car chase or something like that, or if something happens in Somerville, uh, you know, and they come through Medford, you know, this, you know, they can actually see things on tape.

[John Falco]: Um, a lot of times, you know,

[John Falco]: When it comes to Medford, you can't see anything because there's no cameras.

[John Falco]: But they have them in all surrounding areas, surrounding cities and towns.

[John Falco]: And they've been extremely helpful.

[John Falco]: I know that things have happened in Medford where, you know, they've

[John Falco]: The people that have broken the law have gone down to cities and towns, and they've consulted these cameras.

[John Falco]: And it's really helped out a lot from what I was told that night.

[John Falco]: And they're all accessible right through the phone if they need to look at a camera right away.

[John Falco]: So I think it's a good way to possibly help to solve crimes.

[John Falco]: But I don't think it's a way to go out to see if someone's speeding or something like that.

[John Falco]: That's not the purpose.

[John Falco]: It would be to actually just to try to, after crime has been committed, to actually

[John Falco]: go back and look at a tape and say, OK, wait a second.

[John Falco]: They actually came running down Mr. Gabel, whatever it may be.

[John Falco]: But I think it's a good tool to have.

[John Falco]: And I think it's a really inexpensive option.

[John Falco]: I mean, cameras are pretty inexpensive these days.

[John Falco]: And so I don't think it's something that could be very beneficial to the police department in solving crimes.

[John Falco]: Councilor Falco.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[John Falco]: Thank you, Councilor Knight.

[John Falco]: The purpose of the meeting was to view and discuss government legislative management software, which includes the agenda, minutes, and video streaming the meeting.

[John Falco]: It was a good meeting.

[John Falco]: We actually asked a lot of questions.

[John Falco]: We got a nice presentation from Acela,

[John Falco]: They have experience with, we have surrounding communities that also use this type of product.

[John Falco]: They use it in Somerville, Melrose, I believe maybe Cambridge as well.

[John Falco]: It's basically a product that will bring a lot of transparency to the process and the way we view agendas and minutes here at City Hall.

[John Falco]: The public would have all the information at their fingertips.

[John Falco]: with regard to researching information if they wanted to.

[John Falco]: So it's a very powerful tool.

[John Falco]: I think it's great with regard to transparency.

[John Falco]: All the reports that we get back here, they will be able to access on their phones or laptops or iPads or whatever it may be.

[John Falco]: But I think it's a great tool with regard to transparency.

[John Falco]: Video streaming is a powerful tool as well.

[John Falco]: It would allow us to actually

[John Falco]: Filmer meetings, the city council office, if we choose.

[John Falco]: But with the agenda minutes meeting software, it would allow all of the boards and commission minutes, agenda minutes and software, all be online.

[John Falco]: So really, it benefits the community in many ways with regard to transparency.

[John Falco]: they'd actually be able to view and see the meetings whenever they want.

[John Falco]: So everything would be online.

[John Falco]: It was a great meeting, went really well, great questions.
